summary: During World War I, two British soldiers -- Lance Cpl. Schofield and Lance Cpl. Blake -- receive seemingly impossible orders. In a race against time, they must cross over into enemy territory to deliver a message that could potentially save 1,600 of their fellow comrades -- including Blake's own brother.

reviews.content:
If you want to watch a shallow lead painfully bumble through two hours of awful decisions no soldier would ever make while taking in a lot of really great cinematography - have at it.

The last 2/3 of the movie I was checking regularly to see how much more I would have to sit through.

It's sort of the movie equivalent of that dream where you know what you need to do but can't do it somehow. The whole movie - just bad decision after bad decision. Go into the undoubtedly-booby-trapped bunker and set off a booby trap. Investigate meaningless buildings instead of avoiding them. Don't check captured enemies for weapons. Stand in the fatal funnel when you open the door that you KNOW an enemy is behind. Go straight through the town. Drop your weapon. Wait for the sweet song to end before telling everyone why you're there.

If you know anything about soldiering and war - watching this is torture. It feels like a bunch of artsy historians and zero actual soldiers were consulted in the making of this film.

Stunning visuals of one of the worst wars in history are its only saving grace, but most of that's done by the halfway point.

personalmente en algún punto me es difícil ver películas sobre ejércitos o guerras ya que se me hacen muy monótonas pero esta cinta mostró una buena historia con una trama diferente pero aun con todo lo bueno de una cinta de guerra ,acción ,crudeza,seriedad ,intriga,drama ,sufrimiento etc ,todos esto lo logra gracias a un gran elenco con buenas actuaciones con ayuda de un guion de alta  intensidad y calidad ,increíble escenografía ,ambientación ,banda sonora y ritmo de la trama 
en conclusión 1917 es para mi de las mejores cintas de guerra gracias a una historia diferente que es entretenida.

"1917" directed by Sam Mendes, is a war film that depicts the harrowing journey of two young British soldiers, Schofield and Blake, who are tasked with delivering a message deep into enemy territory to call off a planned attack that could lead to the deaths of thousands of soldiers, including Blake's brother.

The movie was widely acclaimed and received numerous accolades for its exceptional cinematography, immersive storytelling, and compelling performances by the cast.

One of the most outstanding aspects of "1917" is the way it was filmed. The entire movie was shot to appear as one continuous take, giving the audience a sense of being alongside the characters on their perilous journey. The long takes and seamless camera movements were masterfully executed by cinematographer Roger Deakins, who won an Academy Award for his work on the film. The visuals are stunning, capturing the beauty and brutality of war simultaneously.

The film's storytelling is equally impressive, taking the audience through a range of emotions as they follow the two soldiers on their mission. The tension builds throughout the movie as the soldiers encounter various obstacles and challenges, and the audience is left on the edge of their seats, wondering if they will make it to their destination in time.

The performances by George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman, who play Schofield and Blake, respectively, were outstanding. The two actors were able to convey a range of emotions through their subtle gestures and expressions, making their characters feel authentic and relatable. The supporting cast, which includes Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, and Mark Strong, all deliver strong performances as well.

Overall, "1917" is a powerful and emotionally gripping film that captures the horrors of war and the bravery of soldiers in a way that is both compelling and unforgettable. It is a must-see movie for anyone interested in cinema, history, or human resilience.

A very very end to end engaging masterpiece.
Takes you to the warfront and you can join the epic journey of two messenger soldiers in the world war times.
Best camera works, great lighting and colour grading.
It makes you believe that its made through a single shot.
Sent chills down my spine. I must've seen it over five times ever since it came out, and yet, it still sends shivers down my spine without fail, every single time I watch it.

This film truly captures the brutality and horrors of the First World War. The cinematography is outstanding, with the camera work giving the viewer a real sense of the devastation and chaos of the battlefield.

The plot follows two young soldiers, Blake and Schofield, who are sent on a dangerous mission to deliver a message that could save the lives of 1,600 men. The journey is perilous and fraught with danger, as the two men must navigate enemy lines and treacherous terrain to reach their destination. One aspect of the film that truly impressed me was the way it portrayed the futility of war. The soldiers are depicted as pawns in a larger game, with their lives being sacrificed for the sake of political and strategic goals. This message is conveyed without being overly preachy or didactic, and it serves as a powerful reminder of the human cost of conflict.

The performances of the actors are also noteworthy. George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman deliver excellent performances as Blake and Schofield, respectively. The supporting cast, which includes Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, and Mark Strong, also gives strong performances. Overall, I highly recommend 1917 to anyone who is interested in history, war movies, or just great filmmaking in general. It is a gripping and emotional journey that will leave you breathless and with a newfound appreciation for the sacrifices made by those who fought in the Great War.

i didn't know how good this movie was and I didn't know that I would be hooked from the beginning to the end, cast and scenery and direction were really good, I liked how the whole movie was filmed using 1 camera following the protagonist along which added more into how horrifying the war is and thrilling journey.

i rarely rate movies 10 out of 10 but this war movie unlike many others has some uniqueness which again thanks to the direction and the places they chose to film, I highly recommend to give it try.
A daunting technological achievement, 1917 is a harrowing depiction of World War I up close, in no small part to Roger Deakins and Sam Mendes.
Really good movie. last movie at theater before Covid-19.
An absolute fantastic war film.
Masterpiece, nothing bad to say about it. Just amazing movie to watch, and i saw 4 times and it just get better. This is the kind of movie that in 20 years you would wanna see again.

Destaques, são vários destaques, roteiro levemente baseado nas histórias contadas pelo avô do diretor, um drama de guerra fantástico, as tomadas são magníficas, fotografia perfeita, lindo lindo... Oscar super merecido, provavelmente só não ganhou mais por conta do adversário grandioso, "O parasita"... Apaixonante, intenso, realista, tenso, dolorido e sangrento...

Sam Mendes has made this movie unique by the way he shot it. It's edited as if it was filmed in only one take, making the audience part of the action. The attention for detail and the special lighting and orchestration of the scenes, make 1917 a must see.

The technical and historical aspects of this film are excellent. The narrative is however merely passable at most times, and downright embarrassing at others. It's a shame the story couldn't be elevated to the same heights as the visuals.

1917 is a film about the First World War and we can learn more details about how everything happened. It also shows us the difficuilties of being part of the war on a day to day basis.

Schofield and Blake were two young English soldiers in the north of France. They were sent on a mission against time to prevent the other British soldiers from the Second Battalion from attacking and falling into the trap that the German army had set. With no other equipment than their weapons, some grenades and the letter with the order to cancel the attack, they set out on that mission.

In my opinion it´s a very good film that explains very well what the First World War was all about.

Excellent underlying logic, real historical reproduction, excellent camera movement and storyboarding, and good acting skills. The orgasm is lacking a bit. I like this movie very much, especially the one shot to the end, which is a test for the whole team. Regarding the plot part, the whole movie fully demonstrates the horror, cruelty and bloodiness of war. This is a very good anti-war movie.
Too long and had almost a documentary flavor, but excellent, overall.   The  union between the surviving soldier and the saved lieutenant seemed surprisingly dry.
Nearly as boring  as blade runner. Nothing happens, and I mean nothing. It's long and extremely dull from start to finish.
Immensely atmospheric and a thrill ride with a whole cast of great actors.
More style than substance.

Great movie.  It was shot like you were in a 1st person RPG at times.  Entering the city was the most haunting shot.  It was so eerie I was literally thinking Nazi zombies were going to show up lol.  The guy who played Will is going to be a star.  He can seriously act.  Im just glad this wasn't shot as a Gallipoli rehash.  I didnt want to see the end of that movie stolen for this one.
Really great movie that perfectly does what it wants. If you love great camera work and practical effects, this is the movie for you.

Visually spectacular, beautifully filmed and deeply touching, 1917 is a masterpiece as well as a profound exploration of World War I beyond the trenches and guns. It also shows that a good movie doesn't need a renowned cast.

It had the scenes ok, but it failed in so many ways.
All you see is solders in brand new kit, even when one says two years fighting, no way are they all new to front. Gun straps still shiny leather, clean uniforms.
Helping a German pilot without checking his weapons, opening a door while stood in front of it, I found it hard to keep watching, only hoping it might improve somehow, as it had such high ratings. Dissapointed, better films were made of this war, and this one failed.
It was very good, but not spectacular. Basically showed off a lot of CGI, the story was kind of lacking.....
It could have been better.  The last 15 minutes were uneven and somewhat unrealistic.

This film is nothing short of jaw-dropping and awe-inspiring. Sam Mendes provides the greatest WWI film of all time by retelling the war stories of his grandfather. His direction proves unbeatable and his story is moving, not to mention George McKay gives a perfect performance as Schofield. This, in my opinion, is the best-shot film of all time with ABSOLUTELY, INCREDIBLY, WONDROUS CINEMATOGRAPHY. This film is one of fortitude and perseverance and the finale had me in tears. This is simply one of my favorite movies of all time (and should've won Best Picture in 2020).

I mean - it was well filmed, I guess? The characters made unbelievably stupid decisions all throughout that had my group of friends laughing and taken completely out of the moment. What soldier would rescue an enemy combatant and NOT check them for weapons? What soldier would waltz up to someone in the dark, in enemy territory, and not have their weapon drawn until they could identify the other party? Dumb plot holes for drama. Regret buying this movie even from the discount bin I found it in.

An All Time Classic. The editing is world class which leads to incredibly tense pacing that never lets up because of the phenomenally done music, cinematography, rich environments and well acted characters. Even though the characters are not complex they are very likeable and because you never cut away you grow attached to them. One of the best edited films I've ever seen. Everyone should try this once.
Incredibly filmed movie and awe inspiring that they did it on one shot. Really great camera work
It was a perfect cinema experience ^^

In my opinion 1917 is the best War movie since Saving Private Ryan. While the story is abit simple, you really become invested in the two men and their mission. There are some great moments involving a plane, a town and of course the final charge at the end. The music is excellent and it makes those scenes emotional and impactful. Every actor did a great job but obviously George MacKay carries the film as he is the one we follow. Which brings me to the awesome "one take" camera work. It's always cool to see this type of thing happen in a certain scene, but to make an entire movie seem to be in one shot is something else.
LIked it, understated and realistic. Loved the camera method.
9.4 - score + cinematography

The best acting performance from George MacKay! With the best movie score ever composed! Plus, the best cinematography ever done in a movie! Also, the best sound mixing ever done in a movie! And the best sound editing ever done in a movie!
Must watch movie, add to your list.
Benedict, I'm in love with you.

A satisfying and tense experience, Sam Mendes takes us back to 1917 WWI and the results are a technically stunning film with great pacing and a well-told, thematically rich story. It may embrace all the cliches, but it's a worthwile watch.

I was lucky enough to experience this film in cinema. The story and plot is kinda there to serve as a vessel for one of the most well shot films in recent history. The whole film is a one long shot, which helps with the immersion and the realization of the hellish fact that WWI was (and wars in general). I saw it at home also, but some jaw-dropping sequences deserve to be experienced in the big screen (which will leave you baffled on how did Sam Mendes make this all happen in one-shot!). The acting is top-notch, thankfully not over the top. A marvelous achievement indeed.
1917 tells a tragic yet heroic story through the use of incredible one-shots and phenomenal acting. Sure to keep audiences on the edge of their seats nearly beginning to end, 1917 is a must watch.

You walk along the trenches, into the craters, across the barren fields, rained by bullets and shrapnel; you can almost feel drowning in the river and the acrid stench of the rotting corpses entering your nostrils. So much action and emotion leave little time to reflect on the absurdity of war. However, once the film is over, you cannot escape wondering how cruel and useless war is, and how stupid mankind can be!
Very gripping and well made film

Definitely a movie worth watching. At the time of seeing it, I thought it was absolutely astonishing. One of the best war movies out there. It tells a compelling war story and has a peculiar filming method of no cuts. Not a brand new concept, yet it was execute to perfection

This was a spectacular movie in all aspects. The screenplay, cinematography, direction and actor's performances were all incredible. Movies of this quality are rare.

This movie is great. Acting is great, story is superb, and the style of shots where it was one take is awesome. I really like the characters and felt really sad when Lance Corporal Blake was stabbed. I also really like the score for this movie. All around awesome movie. 8.5/10

This movie is about war only superficially. Both the style and the topics are about an initiatory journey, like in Epic Fantasy.
We follow the journey of the main character across different places (some quite surreal and fantastic) and challenges, meeting at each step new "creatures" who will help, guide, threaten, or test the young hero, like in an Epic story.
The long shot is the perfect tool for this kind of storytelling.
Certainly the best war film cinematography ever done. Possibly the best war film ever made.

This movie is unique in many ways. Amazing cinematography combined with proper CGI, delivers this masterpiece. The one-shot film camera style that never cuts is one of them. It is set at a very specific moment of WW1 and does not waste the time explaining the setting, instead, you are taken right into the story without any background of the characters, or who they are, it focuses on the horrors and drama of the war. But that's the beauty of this film. I had a blast watching it.

Someone once asked James Hatfield of Metallica "why do you have slow, quiet parts in your songs?" he answered "how would you know the music was and intense fast if you didn't have slow, quiet parts for contrast?"

This movie is brilliant. A nail-biting, edge of your seat thriller intertwined with humanity and empathy of characters that shouldn't be possible in such a short time. 

I can't wait to see where the cast and crew go next.
Impressive Camera work that feel realistic. 1917 is balanced between real work and the horrors of World War One that keep you in the moment.

The film did a good job capturing the sights, sounds and horror of WWI, but it just wasn't terribly memorable, not like other war movies out there. Today, I honestly find it difficult to recall much about the story itself, even though certain scenes are still vivid in my memory. Worth a watch but don't expect too much.
The story was good, nothing special but the camera work was insane. Now I understand why they got an Oscar for that.

I thought I was not in the habit of commenting on movies I didn't like, because it's nicer to talk about what we like instead. But since there is no major Oscar-nominated performance this year (except of course the "Joker", which should be discussed somewhere else), and undeserved praise comes for really bad examples of movies that should not be watched, I decided to look back at the following title, from the director Sam Mendes, whose other films left me indifferent.

Please note that the commentary will consist mainly of spoilers, because there is nothing else to comment on. The only praise for this movie is the truly impressive long shots, which could be considered a masterpiece, if only they were better integrated with rather poor CGI effects, and served a basic story, that is pure cliché, and nothing more than that.

There is no comment on acting because there is no any reason for that. Benedict Cumberbatch and Collin Firth appear too briefly in the film to make any contribution to the plot, leaving only the wooden appearances of the other actors, in all either dull, or impossible situations. From the very beginning, the two main characters stand out from their surroundings, as they just exit from the beauty salon, unlike the other characters with faces and clothes dirty, as the soldiers should be. They are given an impossible task, which seem only they can accomplish. One dies in an attempt to rescue an enemy pilot without any logic. From that moment on, every step is predictable to the end. The rest of the hero arrives to meet even a female person who, apart from mere appearance, is of no relevance to the story. At crucial moments, he even leaves the weapon, so that by some miracle, avoiding all the bullets of the enemy, he will reach the target.

The most irritating of all l'art pour l'artistic shots, that are too many in this movie, is when the long run in front of the trench is shown at the end, when the unfortunate hero runs and collides with soldiers who, like a miracle, constantly emerge from the same trench, in order to get to the command and stop this futile attack (it would seem, as futile as this movie is). It would have been easier if he had remained to run in an empty trench, since the attack had already begun, when only these soldiers would not constantly sprout from nowhere. Or, to run behind, instead of in front of the trench, because there is no one there, but in that case we would not have such a long and beautifully shot frame, would we?

Unfortunately, this movie failed to be the anything else but the annoying attempt of an imitation of "Saving Private Ryan," portrayed in World War I. Why the title is exactly this year, and what does it have to do with the fictional event being described, remains a mystery.
A realistic and amazing depiction of World War I and the sadness of losing people in that war. Amazing cinematography and little CGI can make an amazing story.
The filmmaking Alone....

1917 is an extremely captivating film, I definitely recommend watching. It's filled with moments of true friendship during trying times and the will to keep going no matter what obstacles are in your way. It is filmed in the most breathtaking way and the scenery shots look almost exactly like what I have seen in photographs from the great war. If you like war movies it is a must see.
Amazing movie. It is rare for a movie to both give me chills and make me cry. The last movie I saw in theaters before COVID-19.
Worst history movie I've ever seen.
Featuring monumental direction and strong, haunting performances, what may be the best British World War I movie of all time is also a stunning work of all filmmaking facets.
A discrete methaphore of human purpose and drive. Exciting and emotional film. Should be seen by everyone. ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

2 years-- Immersive, brilliant directed, emotional, and utterly anxiety inducing. Strong acting met with an even stronger score. This film knows what it wants to do and does it masterfully, cementing itself as one of the best films of 2019
Inspiring and heartbreaking take off WWI trench warfare. Did a great job of creating atmosphere while maintaining a compelling story throughout.
What a film! Breathtaking journey to the world wide disaster that was happening a century ago, to show us how ugly war is and how big and small at the same time humans are.

I enjoyed this one as the visual filming of this true story throughout was incredible as it gave you a real feel of what it was like to be in those horrid trenches during the war. The only part I didn't like was how easily one of the main characters was killed off as you'd think they would have taken better precautions or done more to help the situation once it happened. Great job overall.
Amazing Camera work acting is very good and the directing is beautiful
Very good. Interesting seamless flow.
esta pelicula da una inmersion de guerras de trincheras cruda pero emocionante
A beautiful movie from start to finish.
Nicely done.  Characters were kinda stupid, but they were supposed to be young (been there, done that) soldiers and not seasoned veterans.
My rating for the film is a 8.6/10

This is for sure one of my all time favorites. The cinematography is top tier, it is for sure the best one shot movie of all time. They had amazing wide shots really showing the detail put into the set and scenery. Actors were nothing short of amazing, perfect fit for the movie. Great plot, kept me engaged from the start and didn't let me go until the end. 9.9/10

5.7/10 — "Mediocre"/"Passable"

Awesome trenches, long tracking shots, and a little Cumberbatch make a slow movie with a melodramatic soundtrack watchable enough.

The movie was very well made, however the plot was slow to develop and fairly anticlimactic. Plenty of cameo appearances from big name actors, yet their appearances were extremely brief and accomplished very little. Almost as if they were included solely to advertise the movie as having a stronger cast than was actually the case for the other 98% of the movie.
Good war movie with some great visuals.
More fun than it ought to be considering the subject matter
Yeah, this is better than CATS.

1917 was based on a true story or the way the soldier remembered it. Again the acting was outstanding. The location where they filmed it, seemed very real. If you know anything about WW1 you would agree. I felt they could edit the film to be a little shorter. The storyline in my opinion did drag a little. Overall, I would recommend you take the time to see it.
A really realistic interpretation of how sad and terrible WWI was.

1917 is 2019's Most Monumental and Mesmerizing War Film that is easily Mendes's Grandest Directional Works, and holds The Best Cinematic Experience of the Year.

Nava Medikonda | 4/5 Rating

1917 is a movie made for the big screen. Its thrilling action, to personal perspective storytelling enhances the audience's engagement for feeling and sparks a connection between its viewers and its characters.

Sam Mendes and Roger Deakins bring visually easy on the eye, spectacular shots to the big screen for 2019, and its decade for film. The movies natural look strengthened the story, and due to the correct use of specific color choices and amazing cinematography skills from Deakins, the film purifies and shows us the beauty side of war, and its attractivity of violence.

The impressive use of long tracking shots puts us in perspective of the film. Effortlessly the lacking in noticeability in cutting helps pull of such an effect.

This film also has its dark side, and being a war film, its easily understandably not its own fault. The audience doesn't need another war film to tell them about the crazy, treacherous side of war. For the viewers who want to watch that experience, its easily agreeable that Sam Mendes and Roger Deakins bring something to 1917 that not every other war film has been able to bring to the screen.

The film does a great job with identifying friendships during a war, and how an enemy solider has their own perspective of thought even when is the worst situations possible. The film explores how a civilian can be impacted, and how the rank hierarchy affects soldiers too, even when given specific rules to follow.

1917 has a runtime of 1 hour and 59 minutes, and was shot using the ARRI Alexa Mini LF. The camera is a digital cinema camera that pulls of a clean slick look, that other war films shot on film can not often do.

The films story is living moment by moment, as the characters can be affected so easily by a small crack in their path, its almost unrealistic how lucky, and easily the characters feel on their purpose in war. Yes there may be emotion, but the characters are easily changed and soon recovered back to their normal selves, and only strike back when something serious happens, the thought of their purpose in the film is upsettingly unrealistic due to their perspective during their "lucky" mission.

By the end of the film, with its closing shots, its brings the normal viewer relief, after a vicious desperate journey across the concept of war, and what soldiers had to experience, it serves as a salute to those whom fought, and to those whom passed. The film does an exceptionally outstanding job for that concept.
Was more complicated to appreciate the movie as a teen, but the movie is masterpiece.
It was good action. There were many scenes which had my heart pounding!

Amazing directing, it all looking like a one shot adds to the experience. Story is good and brought to light by the acting, at times the uninteresting moments of the movie you can overlook by the cinematography. It is worth the watch and you wont regret it.

This movie is a love letter to old-school storytelling and cinematography in particular. From the opening shot to the final cut, there was only one single absolutely justified disruption in the viewpoint of the audience. End to end, this brutal mission was a singular journey through blasted hell scapes, lush meadows, dark caverns, and erupting fields of fire. It is truly a master class in filmmaking to seamlessly tell a story in a single cut. 

The mission itself is the point, where the will to live and save lives, to sacrifice for the greater good, can infect even the most nonchalant of protagonists. In turn, such sacrifice can lead to inner peace and resolution of old hurts. 

There are moments of utter terror where our heroes are running for their lives and complete peace where they take a moment to enjoy the miracle of life itself. But all in all, this is one unforgettable war story, told in a single sweeping vision.

Not many WW1 films out there in modern times but this one, 1917, was absolutely fantastic from a certain way. Revolutionary in the camera work and with a simple story it held you at the edge of your seat, sometime of the way through. This movie can be taken by so many perspectives but here is the hard truth. It was a revolutionary film from a cinematographic aspect and the costumes/scenery was absolutely splendid but the story was simple and the acting from supporting characters were quite dull. What saves this movie is the fact that is plausible scenario in a time with no radios and most messages were either hand delivered or were by pigeon. Yes, I would watch it again but I am not sure I would get through it without falling asleep half way through. Fully recommend for your average movie goer and your military enthusiast but I don't see this as a rewatchable movie as what you see on the screen loses its flair after the first go. Written 06/14/2022 Full Review on my blog to come
I just wish i could've seen this movie in the cinema but even at home this movie is a captivating, technically brilliant and rewarding experience.

I'm generally not fond of war films as most of them glorify and romanticize war, but 1917 was an exception. The cinematography is extremely impressive and the acting is very notable. This is far and away my favorite war film because there aren't too many instances of glorification or romanticizing of war, as the film seems to acknowledge that war is hell.
Amazing filming and acting!  Great war classic
Watching this movie leaves you speechless. Shoutout goes to the amazing cinematography which is the highlight of the film.
A huge and beautifully made movie.  One of the best I've seen in a very long time.
Great film, really well done and moving

This was definitely one of the most interesting shot films I've seen. The one shot throughout allows for very good suspense. It's almost like a video game, you are along for the ride with these two young soldiers. 
The cinematography is amazing. The fact that they made a compelling story like this all with one shot is incredible!
Great acting too. It's cool they got some relatively unknown guys to play these roles. 
One of the best war movies I've seen!

This is among the best movies ever made, no doubt about it. Gorgeous to view, unique cinematic "one-shot" feel, fantastic performances that give insight into the horrors and anxiety of war. When a director and crew go above and beyond to create a masterpiece, it looks like this film. Well done!

A much reduced British version of Saving Private Ryan, only set in WWI.  While the sets and costumes are magnificent, the is very little substance to the movie.  It is basically two peoples' walking tour of various trenches during the war, from point A to point B.  That really is the sum and substance of the movie.  Despite the cameo appearances from some remarkable actors, they add nothing the the basic premise of a walking tour.

Very well done war flick.  It is maybe a bit in the shadow of 'Saving Private Ryan' which ramped up the realism to 11, but this is still a solid 9 or 10.  The long continuous shot is interesting, but maybe not necessary and takes away from the story, but it does look cool.  They also jam an unrealistic amount of WWI 'highlights' in a short period of time.  Oh look, trenches, shelling, a charge, booby traps, bi-plane attack, French woman hiding in the ruins, etc.  The scenery also changes rapidly, from shelled out bare dirt to forests, etc very quickly.  But it is hard to fault the film for exaggerating the drama.

One of the most realistic war films that you will ever see. The gripping nature of the film sucks you into the grueling reality of WWI. What makes this film better than many others is its outstanding cinematography.

Uma aula de cinema.
Um filme que captura uma gota no Oceano da História de uma maneira muito singular, bonita e impactante, apesar do horror que envolve todas as sequências.
Amazing shots. Dangerous Traps. No naps 😈

One of the best war movies in a long time, "1917" stands as not only a technical marvel, but a cinematic masterpiece that fully displays the talent behind the screens. Mendes once again proves himself to be one of the best directors of the 2010s, and the cast proves extremely talented in each of their roles. The cinematography was groundbreaking, and the special effects were done extremely well. The action and suspense was also done incredibly, keeping you entertained and hooked to the story while not feeling like too much is going on. The soundtrack was also fantastic and fit the film very well. Overall, a must-watch war movie that is sure to become a timeless masterpiece.

Wonderful film. Definitely worth a shot. The effects, cinematography, direction, writing and music are top class. It is often overlooked by common people which is very sad. It is emotionally heavy and a very different kind of war movie. Highly suggest watching it. 4/5.
It's good, just not my type, or else I'll rate it higher.
Outstanding entertainment!!!

It was an amazing movie great CGI and it felt so realistic like you were in the movie! and even though it is a bit violent and might be heavy for some people, but if you like historical war drama films 1917 is a great choice.
To me the only downside is that the cuts are easily spotted.

The story and historical perspective are excellent, the actors do a very good job, but the highlight is the cinematography and editing. It really looks like it was all shot in a single take. Quite remarkable!

It starts well with the 'one-shot' camera thing settling you in and taking you on the journey, but it soon becomes long, drawn out and boring. The action, and the way the hero survives the movie, is at best a little slapstick and at worst outright ridiculous.
The film it simple. It shows the tragedies and miracles in World War I in a clear way. And the story could neither have been directed nor acted more perfectly.
The best WW1 movie in decades. It was accurate, entertaining, and very high in production values.

Es una película disfrutable, exquisita de ver para los amantes del cine bélico y también una buena opción para comenzar a explorar este género. Mantiene en suspenso al espectador y al borde de su asiento en cada escena potentemente tensa. Sam Mendes reconstruye de una forma creíble y evocadora los escenarios requeridos para revivir la primera guerra mundial y convierte una historia sencilla en una experiencia repleta de suspenso y tensión acompañada de planos secuencia incesantes que consiguen capturar la emoción y brindar una experiencia sublime, que te hace sentir como si se estuviese viviendo la guerra en primera persona. NO es una obra que entrega violencia gratuita omnipresente, pero logra ser cruda y revivir una historia cruenta, lo cual me pareció excelente. Es una montaña rusa llena de altibajos, no es una cinta perfecta; en lo personal me pareció que la cinta fue decayendo en  la segunda mitad, siendo ocasionalmente inverosímil, reduciendo el suspenso y sustituyéndolo por acción, y culminando en un final que si bien no es malo, es bastante simple comparado con el desarrollo de la historia. Sin embargo, es una buena película, con buenos efectos especiales y CGI bien elaborados, pero con defectos que desmeritan su calidad. La recomiendo muchísimo para aquellos que disfrutan del suspenso y historias bien contadas y atrapantes. 7,9 de 10.

Beautiful, dramatic, peaceful, and horrific all at the same time. 1917 gives audiences an incredibly balanced movie in its various tones and scenes. You are immersed in experiencing the majesty of war, the disorientation, the horror, and the unpredictability of things going on around you. The story in this film is straightforward, but you get brief glimpses into how the war affects different people. These windows into other lives can amplify the chaos, intensity, and the uncertainty of war, or even provide a brief yet peaceful respite to the horrors. The acting in this movie is fantastic, the set pieces are unexpectedly gorgeous, cinematography, camera work, lighting, music, everything fits into a confined personal story through ever-changing settings and circumstances and is gripping from beginning to end.

This movie hit every single mark I have for a great movie, and it actually gets better with each viewing. Excelente película, una sorpresa para mi ya que no me suelen gustar este tipo de peliculas sobre guerra, ya que me suelen aburrir. Esta película, para empezar, tiene un buen ritmo; toda la premisa de la película se presenta en los primeros 5 minutos y comienza a partir de ahí. No es frenética, pero da una sensación real de primera persona y de que estás haciendo el viaje con el protagonista. Yo creo que lo que mas se destaca de la película es su hermosa cinematografía y paisajes asombrosos. También destaca el trabajo de cámara por parte de Sam Mendes, que hace un trabajo excepcional dando la sensación de que la película esta filmada toda en una sola toma, y eso esta implementado de una manera tremenda. Las actuaciones son muy buenas y realistas, destaco principalmente a George MacKay, aunque todo el reparto es perfecto. Además, la música y todo el sonido en general de la película es sobresaliente. Por otro lado, estuve entretenido durante toda la película; raro ya que este tipo de historias me suelen aburrir. Hay algunas pausas en la trama que le permiten al espectador recuperar el aliento. Finalmente, no me di cuenta del tiempo que pasaba con esta película, me quede con ganas de ver mucho mas. En conclusión, creo que es una obra maestra del genero bélico que logra cautivarte a través de su historia y de sus audiovisuales. Muy recomendada.

The attempt to give the impression that 1917 was shot in one take feels a bit disingenuous and can be distracting at times as you look for where the film was cleverly cut but, despite this, it remains a powerful war saga and an interesting story.  Two lance corporals are sent on a seemingly impossible mission – travel through potentially hostile territory to advise a nearby battalion to call off a scheduled attack on the German line that would result in massive casualties.  Roger Deakins' cinematography is stunning, director Sam Mendes does an excellent job choreographing the long takes and the score subtly helps build the suspense.  Despite the fact that the technique doesn't allow for much character development, it remains an impactful tale of duty and brotherhood.

If you can overlook the stupidity of the central premise of Sam Mendes' '1917', there's a good bit to enjoy about it. But, it can be difficult to ignore the idea that any General, worth his salt, would send two men through seemingly abandoned enemy lines to pass on a message to another position, when there is air power that can be utilised instead that would have a much better chance of success and at a speedier rate too. But the hook which Mendes hangs his narrative coat on sees two British Army non-coms, Tom Blake (Dean Charles Chapman) and Will Schofield (George MacKay), being "volunteered" to bring an important communique to the 2nd Batt. Devonshire Reg. to hold off on an attack on German lines south of Arras, on the Western Front in April 1917. The Germans have "retreated" (presumably to the Hindenburg Line) and the British believe that they have "the hun on the run". However, aerial reconnaissance has shown that this is not the case and sixteen hundred men are possibly heading into a trap. The mission also has a special added importance for Lance Corporal Blake as his brother is in the regiment that's set to go "over the top".

The fanciful set up of '1917' is certainly not anything we haven't seen in war movies before. Reducing the story down to a few individuals on a mission is a staple of war movies, as there is always the danger of audience confusion of who's who when confronted by too many characters, and armies, whether at platoon, battalion, brigade or whatever level have so many characters.to keep track of. So 1917's "men on patrol behind enemy lines" is familiar territory, even if the war it's taking place in hasn't been the subject of too many movies. There were, of course, "runners" who were used to send messages back and forth between the forward and rear trenches during the First World War (a certain Adolf Hitler was one) and it was an extremely dangerous job. But their utilisation here is a complete flight of fancy. But, if one ignores the unrealistic set up, there is enough realism to be found elsewhere for those of a certain bend toward that direction.

Of course, no war movie has ever been a truly realistic depiction of man's most awful pursuit, but the little details that '1917' gets right are pretty admirable in that regard. The long scene at the beginning of teh film detailing Blake and Schofield's meandering trek through their own forward trench shows us a decent representation of what it was like on the British front line. Likewise, the uniforms the two wear are quite accurate, including the badge on Lance Corporal Blake's Brodie helmet and the leather jerkins that were a common sight on "Tommies" during the period.

In fact, from a technical perspective, '1917' does an admirable job indeed and seen on a big screen it's a fairly immersive experience, especially if you have a interest in the war. It's just the story that lets it down, while not completely sinking the whole picture and, perhaps, if it wasn't so well produced, it wouldn't be getting the high praise that it has received upon its release, not to mention the Oscar nods. Obviously, central to this praise has the set design by Dennis Gassner and Roger Deakins' excellent cinematography, which has rightly been lauded, even though I wasn't that impressed by the pseudo one shot gimmick he employed. Curiously though, it's up for a Best Writing award too.

It's directed well enough, without any kind of revelations in that respect and it's acted decently by the two leads. There are also a number of familiar faced cameos to spot as well, for people who want to play that game.

'1917' is a pretty good movie, while never being amazing, and it has some gruelling battlefield scenes that can be wince inducing in a commendable way. It also offers some views of the First World War that are rarely seen in movies about that conflict as the story strays from the trenches that we are all familiar with and associate with that particular conflict. So, while I wouldn't expect to be bowled over by any of it, it's two hours are a relatively entertaining way to pass the time even if it's all rather predictable.

Of course, I had heard that the film appears to consist of only two continuous shots, and I wasn't sure how I'd feel about this. Well, the verdict is in: I loved it. Although my brain has been conditioned for scene-breaks at certain moments, I found the directorial decision refreshing. While all war is Hell, World War One's iteration is always considered some of the most hellish as men — boys really, a lot of them were just boys — scurry from their holes and rush headlong into certain death. The plot is a simple one, and one as old as time, as an "Accidental Hero," "False Protagonist," whatever trope you want to call it, Lance Corporal William Schofield (George MacKay) is selected to aid his comrade (Dean-Charles Chapman) in a death-defying mission simply because he was sitting nearby. The mission, if successful, will save (or prolong) the lives of 1,600 British soldiers. Lance Corporal Thomas Blake (Chapman) has a personal stake in the outcome — his older brother is with the frontline regiment — but Schofield solely has the motivation for duty to one's country; a duty that doesn't always seem worth it. What we get is a "man behind enemy lines" story that is filled with as much action as there are bloated bodies floating down the river. I'm annoyed with myself for not viewing 1917 earlier, as Dunkirk didn't wow me and WWI was more known for soldiers losing their minds in the underground tunnels from the incessant shelling than for gripping, cinematic heroics. As for "the run," the promotional scene for the movie, was better than I had imagined. We get snippets of some of our favorite British actors — Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Mark Strong, Richard Madden — but Andrew Scott as Lieutenant Leslie was my favorite supporting character, sending our two heroes off in a baptism of scotch. The ending said to me, "We might end up where we started, but we'll never be the same," and I liked that. 1917 reminds us why movies are special.
1917 is a master craft of the war genre. Is it as good as saving Private Ryan, no. But, it leaves on stamp on the genre and is a technical wonder to see.

Mind you! One of Spielbergs lesser movies - yup, that one about a horse! - depicted WWI more plausible and chilling than this film. WAR HORSE felt like a (flawed) movie with great scenes, 1917 feels like a video game with decent inbetween sequences. Where Spielbergs movie was clichéd about anything else, it was truthful about war. This movie, however, has no relation to war, it uses it as a backdrop for some borderline camp action set pieced, including Germans with stormtrooper aim, a waterfall in the pancake flat landscapes and Germans feeling like respawning Wolfenstein bots. It is skillfully executed and dishonestly disguised, sometimes pretentious war action schlock.

Worth watching for about 15 minutes worth of footage that depicts what life must've been like in the trenches, but that's about it. Otherwise, a woefully implausible plot, some terrible cinematography (the production on the nighttime bombed out village scene is simply awful) and the two lead characters a two dimensional and wall to wall annoying.

The fact that this is film appears to only be one shot and it is believable even though there are cuts is excellent. This is one of the only recent films that I could describe as clever, it has a new idea that has been executed brilliantly, every scene has had an immeasurable amount of time and effort placed within which makes every moment of the film is full of importance: thus the feeling that this film is one of the only films out there that is a much see that is possible to look away from because of the sheer quality and concentration of everyone involved into the production: the direction from Sam Mendes is once in a generation and this paired with the cinematography makes a breath taking experience that is a must see, with many films with a gimmick that is all there is to it but with this film the story is simple and elegant and that is the type of story that is needed for a film that only appears to be one shot because if there were multiple story lines with multiple main characters the gimmick of one shot would instantly shatter of not work at all: having one main character throughout the film with a few others along the way works really well because we get to know him well and feel the grave danger he is in because there is nothing else to distract from it, this being a war film also works really well because that is one film that only requires one main story and no other story, and this works well because it also creates an ambiguity of what is going in everything except the main story which creates a realism of a war, this for me is flawlessly portrayed by Benedict Cumberbatch's role of a general who's hope is snatched away from him by every other event in the film. Overall this is a great film with a gimmick that works only because of all the other parts make it fit into place excellently.

This is a first-class film and a first-class war film. The one-take approach is indeed one of the most engaging points of the film and contributes immeasurably to the immersion of the audience into the story and the mission that the lead characters are attempting to accomplish. More than that, however, "1917" captures very well the atmosphere of World War I and provides an insight into greater complexities of the war that popular memory sometimes omits. This military history student especially appreciated the attention to historical detail shown by the cast, creative crew, and the screenplay; the revised history showing senior officers being concerned about casualties and wanting to prevent unnecessary losses in contrast to the oft-repeated myth of "lions led by donkeys" is a welcome addition, as is the film's showing Indian Army soldiers assisting the British to remind us that the British Empire was represented by more than just white men, though the latter is somewhat anachronistic as most Indian troops had left the Western Front by 1917. The story is consistently engaging despite certain inconsistencies. In summary, "1917" is a high-quality war film and masterful technical achievement that is sure to bring World War I back into the spotlight and hopefully lead the way to further interest and study in the period.

On 6 April 1917, aerial reconnaissance has observed that the German army, which has pulled back from a sector of the Western Front in northern France, is not in retreat but has made a strategic withdrawal to the new Hindenburg Line, where they are waiting to overwhelm the British with artillery. In the British trenches, with field telephone lines cut, two young British lance corporals, William Schofield (George MacKay), a veteran of the Somme, and Tom Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman), are ordered by General Erinmore to carry a message to Colonel Mackenzie of the Second Battalion of the Devonshire Regiment, calling off a scheduled attack the next morning that would jeopardise the lives of 1,600 men, including Blake's brother Joseph, a lieutenant...

Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Hard-hitting, immersive, and an impressive technical achievement, 1917 captures the trench warfare of World War I with raw, startling immediacy." Several critics named the film among the best of 2019, including Kate Erbland of IndieWire and Sheri Linden of The Hollywood Reporter. Writing for the Hindustan Times, Rohan Naahar stated, "I can only imagine the effect 1917 will have on audiences that aren't familiar with the techniques Sam Mendes and Roger Deakins are about to unleash upon them." In his review for NPR, Justin Chang was less positive. He agreed the film was a "mind-boggling technical achievement" but did not think it was that spectacular overall, as Mendes's style with its impression of a continuous take "can be as distracting as it is immersive". Manohla Dargis of The New York Times called the film, "A carefully organized and sanitized war picture [...] that turns one of the most catastrophic episodes in modern times into an exercise in preening showmanship." Alison Willmore of Vulture compared it unfavourably to the war film Dunkirk (2017), writing, "The artifice of the aesthetic premise overwhelms any of the film's other intentions."

"1917" has great cinematography with never seems to end shots, editing, sceneries and direction from Sam Mendes. Plus the ending is just a puff of smoke to me. A disappointment in my book. Had huge hopes. The film was nevertheless a critical and box office success, grossing $384.9 million worldwide. Among its accolades, it received ten nominations at the 92nd Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Director, and three wins, for Best Cinematography, Best Visual Effects, and Best Sound Mixing.

A deeply visual, moving and realistic portrayal of the realities of warfare in the first world war. "1917" is a war movie directed by Sam Mendes. The two main actors are George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman. They both play British soldiers during first world war. The film is about these soldiers, Will Schofield and Tom Blake, who receive the order to deliver a message to the second battalion of the Devonshire regiment who are getting ready to launched an assault. But the enemy's positions being able to stop them, Schofield and Blake are the only ones able to avoid the slaughter. The plot could looks like weak but it is not. The movie give a gripping and unpredictable story with riveting twist. The choice of the director to make his movie like a single sequence put the spectator in the action like do video games. He also play with the light settings to make a breathtaking atmosphere but still realistic. These outstanding filming techniques make us live this absorbing adventure. The acting is convincing see spectacular, we feel the emotions of the characters like stress, sadness or hatred. And the script is easily understandable but so touching. I find this film one of the best war film ever seen, rewarded of 2 Golden Globes and 3 Oscars. I recommend this to every one who have two hours to spend.

1917 - 10/10. During the christmas holidays I went to see 1917 and was bowled over by the film. I forgot to write my review for it, so here's my review. Rather than making a traditional war film based around combat and the plight of soldiers, 1917's story is akin to Christopher Nolan's film Dunkirk. Like that film, the tension and theme is suspense and survival. We follow two soldiers who act as messengers between two british troops. They must warn the other troop to not go into battle, as they would be falling into a trap. Shot and edited to mimic a one shot visual experience, Sam Mendes and Roger Deakins create a tour de force experience. The two men have crafted a film based around the survival of these messengers, and how they must go against all odds to get their message to the receiver. There are some really amazing scenes in the film which use the one shot technique to its full capacity. Deakins has delivered some of his best cinematography in his career, and continues to show why he's one of the greatest cinematographers in film history. Mendes delivers his best film since Skyfall, as he brings a simple story into a crazy ride of survival. The way he flows from one setting to the other is spectacular, and he shows great attention to detail. The two lead actors do a splendid job with what they are given, with cameos from some famous british actors helping fill out the remainder of the cast. One of the best films of 2019 for sure.

I just don't get it? Why aren't more people annoyed by this film? I sat there fuming! Yes, I get that the cinematography is impressive (2 stars for that at least) but that's about it, isn't it? The film annoyed the hell out of me and all the single-sequence shots (or whatever they are called) in the world won't change that. The acting is nigh-on risible (could you have chosen 2 more wooden lead actors?), the dialogue boring, there is no deepening of character, the ridiculous coincidences (how likely was it that that plane would crash just a few feet away from them?), why did they go into the German bunker at all? Why didn't they just go round it? I could see that rat was going to trigger the tripwire from a mile off - why didn't they anticipate it quicker? And how come they weren't blown to smithereens? How come the Germans were such bad shots? I mean, running down an alley between 2 walls - you couldn't miss! Yet they all did. Except for one, when the British soldier was blown several feet backwards by the German sniper (whom he had wounded with a random shot through a window - okay, it could happen, but come on, but then he just banged his head and got up again - hold on, was he shot or not - I don't get it? And why exactly did he run through the troops storming over the top of the bunker when he could have just waited for them to leave the trench and THEN run to the commanding officer? Wouldn't that have been quicker? Duh. Listen, it's easy to pick holes in a plot, but there are so many in this film that it could be Swiss cheese.

The two main characters are intensely human and incredibly well acted, and continual appearance of well-known faces in minor roles seems to draw the audience into mimicking the soldier's respect of their leaders. By following the footsteps of the two protagonists we get a strong climpse of what the Front experience was like: the stress, the mess, the constant threat and psychological damage it caused. The film captures the importance of diplomatic solutions that we still need to internalise as a species.

Off the bat this movie is a 9/10, it's a great movie. The more you let this movie sink in the more you enjoy it on second rewatch. The two main characters have to cross enemy lines and the way they do it in the movie is so gut wrenching and enjoyable. This movie has some of the best cinematography with the greatest long take that I've seen in any movie. This movie didn't need long takes but it was incredibly appreciated and the way they blended in the cuts made it seem like the movie was just one long take, it was brilliant. The only reason this movie doesn't receive a 10/10 is due to some slow parts that didn't add to the story and were kind of pointless and aggravating in the end, but as the movie stands its an amazing watch from the cinematography alone. The acting is also very well done with actors playing great roles and adding emotional depth that is enjoyable to watch from beginning to end. If you like war movies or movies with just great camera work in general then this is a must watch for you.

The opposite side wasn't seen as these strictly evil beings on the opposite end of the spectrum from our protagonists, they're just other people caught up in this. The reason I liked it so much was they made War the real enemy. Not the opposing soldiers. War. There were no glorified action shots of the dog fight, no cool camera tricks when the main characters shoot someone to make it gruesome and Cool Looking, they just happen. They're not glorified, they're shown as they really are.

Corre 1917 en el frente francés. Dos cabos del ejército británico, William Schofield y Tom Blake (George MacKay y Dean-Charles Chapman, respectivamente) son enviados a llevar una nota para detener la ofensiva de otro batallón inglés sobre las líneas alemanas a las que cree en retirada, cuando en realidad los alemanes se replegaron allí para emboscarlo. Una verdadera misión suicida, estimulada sin embargo con el aliciente del reencuentro de Blake  con su hermano en ese batallón.

1917 es una asombrosa experiencia inmersiva en los horrores de la guerra de trincheras de la Primera Guerra Mundial, filmada en un (casi) plano secuencia que acompaña en todo momento a los protagonistas, por lo que la película transcurre prácticamente en tiempo real. En ciertos momentos, el carácter bélico cede su lugar prácticamente al cine de terror. La anécdota, entonces, es mínima, así como los personajes. La potencia de las imágenes, del sonido y de la música (de Thomas Newman) es portentosa. La fotografía de Roger Deakins (multipremiada, así como la película en general) es bellísima y sus virajes son fundamentales en la creación de los diferentes climas de la película. Hay una secuencia nocturna que es sencillamente antológica por su tensión, su estética y la variedad de sentimientos y sensaciones que pone en juego y produce.




Cierta crítica le ha objetado a esta película del ecléctico Sam Mendes dos aspectos centrales que en mi opinión son virtudes. Uno de ellos es que las peripecias de los protagonistas y el plano secuencia en movimiento asemejan la percepción de la película a la experiencia a un videojuego. ¿Y no será al revés?¿Los video juegos simplemente no reflejan acaso la experiencia de la guerra y sobre todo ahora con sus aspectos de control remoto y virtual? La Primera Guerra fue una guerra de trincheras laberínticas.

La otra crítica es la falta de "historia personal" de los protagonistas, lo cual les quitaría profundidad psicológica. 1917 en este sentido se parece a Dunkerque: aborda a sus personajes in media res, es decir, en pleno frente batalla. Pues debo decir que esa "falta" y la sencillez de sus motivaciones ubica a los protagonistas en la piel de verdaderos "soldados anónimos".

1917 es de esas películas que uno lamenta no haber visto en el cine, un despliegue cinematográfico con mayúsculas al servicio de una historia de guerra donde la desesperación y el deber se dan la mano.

It runs 1917 on the French front. Two British Army corporals, William Schofield and Tom Blake (George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman, respectively) are sent to carry a note to stop the offensive of another English battalion on German lines that he believes are in retreat, when in fact the Germans fell back there to ambush him. A true suicide mission, stimulated however by the incentive of Blake's reunion with his brother in that battalion.

1917 is an astonishing immersive experience in the horrors of the trench warfare of World War I, filmed in a (almost) shot sequence that accompanies the protagonists at all times, so the film takes place practically in real time. At certain times, the warlike character gives way practically to horror movies. The anecdote, then, is minimal, as well as the characters. The power of images, sound and music (by Thomas Newman) is prodigious. Roger Deakins' photography (multi-award winning, as well as the film in general) is beautiful and his twists are fundamental in creating the different climates of the film. There is a nocturnal sequence that is simply anthological because of its tension, its aesthetics and the variety of feelings and sensations that it brings into play and produces.

Some critics have objected to this film by the eclectic Sam Mendes two central aspects that in my opinion are virtues. One of them is that the adventures of the protagonists and the sequence shot in motion resemble the perception of the film to the experience of a video game. And will it not be the other way around? Video games simply don't reflect the experience of war and especially now with its remote and virtual control aspects? The First War was a labyrinthine trench warfare.

The other criticism is the lack of "personal history" of the protagonists, which would take away psychological depth. 1917 in this sense resembles Dunkirk: it addresses its characters in media res, that is, in the middle of the battle front. Well, I must say that this "lack" and the simplicity of their motivations places the protagonists in the shoes of true "anonymous soldiers."

1917 is one of those films that one regrets not having seen in the cinema, a cinematographic display with capital letters at the service of a war story where despair and duty go hand in hand.

This is such an AMAZING movie. I saw it with my dad in theaters before Covid-19 started, and it was SO good. This WWI movie has action, drama, persistence, and everything in between. If you haven't seen the movie and you're reading this review, go watch it NOW!

El cine siempre ha tenido un interés particular por retratar los horrores que ocurren en las guerras, por lo que películas e historias sobre este tipo, hay muchas. Pero son pocas las que en verdad logran impactar y destacar de manera sustancial en los espectadores. Y, 1917, es una de ellas.
1917 es una cinta que narra la historia de dos soldados británicos en la primera guerra mundial, Schofield (George MacKay) y Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman), quienes tienen una misión demasiado importante en sus manos, ya que son los encargados de entregar un mensaje que evitará un mortífero ataque contra los enemigos, en el que se podrían perder la vida de cientos de soldados, entre ellos el propio hermano de Blake. El único problema es que ambos están solos, van contra reloj y tienen que atravesar territorio hostil. 
Una película que dura cerca de dos horas, pero, a pesar de este tiempo y la temática bélica, no se vuelve tediosa o aburrida, sino más bien, desde los primeros minutos la cinta te atrapa y te hace partícipe de la misión de los protagonistas. Por lo que cuando menos sientes ya ha pasado más de la mitad del filme, y ni te has dado cuenta.
Esto debido a la impresionante puesta en escena que realiza el director Sam Mendes, junto a la fotografía de Roger Deakins, en el que utilizan el plano secuencia para narrar la historia. Un plano que sigue las acciones de los protagonistas de forma línea, adoptando puntos de vista de los soldados para lograr una inmersión del espectador en el drama que viven, haciéndonos un acompañante de ellos y compartiendo su angustia o espíritu de lucha.
El uso de esta falsa secuencia única hace que no te despegues de la cinta ya que no hay tiempo para poner una pausa o para volver atrás porque el tiempo está corriendo. En este sentido, el director también sabe jugar muy bien con la intensidad de la película y es que debido a ser una única toma por secuencia podría tornarse aburrida, sin embargo, se mezclan muy bien las secuencias llena acción para después ir un poco más lento y llenarnos de angustia.
Igualmente, Sam Mendes logra coordinar a la perfección todos los aspectos técnicos que ocurren en los sets a campo abierto dando la apariencia de que todo está planeado detalladamente. Hasta este punto me gustaría hacerte la invitación a ver el detrás de cámaras de la película ya que te sorprenderás sobre la forma en la que fue grabada esta cinta.
Así mismo, el uso que le dan a los escenarios con las trincheras es muy bueno ya que estas marcan una forma lineal que, indirectamente, dan la sensación de no acabar aumentando el suspenso en el espectador en especial al momento de crear el clímax final de la película.
Por otra parte, la banda sonora de Thomas Newman también es un punto importante a destacar, ya que aporta en la construcción de las escenas al momento de crear la tensión y suspenso con unos efectos de sonido muy buenos. Por lo que si vez esta película desde la comodidad de tu hogar te recomiendo el uso de audífonos o un buen equipo de sonido para una mejor experiencia.
Y si bien, el filme logra generar emoción, suspenso y un poco de terror ante lo que se muestra en pantalla, el desarrollo de los personajes se queda un bastante corto. Ya que en ningún momento se logra que el espectador se apegue o conecte emocionalmente con los protagonistas y que a partir de esto se generen esas sensaciones iniciales, sino que, más parece que en realidad es gracias a la experiencia que se vive junto a ellos y no por ellos.
Esto debido también a la falta de diálogos que hay en la cinta lo cual provoca que no se construya una narrativa a partir de los personajes sino a partir de lo que se ve que hacen. En este sentido, impacta bastante lo que ellos transmiten corporalmente porque así nosotros como audiencia que los acompaña sentimos en parte lo que ellos sienten.
En definitiva, esta película bélica se gana su puesto dentro del género y variando un poco en el contexto ya que visibilizan los hechos de la primera guerra mundial. Y también establece una reflexión enmarcada en un mensaje de esperanza e inspiración que se refleja más que nada en las acciones de los protagonistas en un gran despliegue técnico que se vuelve sublime.

You'd think that these long shots would make the film more realistic and immersive, but for me, it does the exact opposite.

You can't have a 2-hour timespan and a main character who covers no more than a few hundred meters of ground, while still mashing in a hundred unbelievable and life-changing events. Yet, that's what they did and the result is a pacing and a set that always feels incredibly 'off'.

I don't like the acting performance either, but I don't want to blame that on the actors themselves, but rather the writing. There's no way to give a believable performance when you've got a script that doesn't allow for any pause or moments of consideration. It all falls very flat if you ask me. Giving each act no more than 5 minutes of stage time might work well at a circus, but it's a poor way of making a movie.

The next time you need to deliver a message across a short field, just use a megaphone. This way of filmmaking would do a million times better if the film was far less eventful and gave more room for dialogue.

"1917" is one of the most recent movies about World War I, having seen it in cinema twice and four times at home, I might say that this is my favorite WWI movie, as it kept me on the edge of my seat until the end! One of the most astonishing parts of the movie is, of course, cinematography. The entire movie is filmed like if it does not have any cuts, although once you re-watch it, you can clearly see where they were put. The operator, Roger Deakins, did a tremendous job of letting the viewer dive into the feeling of World War I, for which he got an Oscar, which is absolutely deserved. 	
The movie is taking the viewer on a journey of two young men delivering a message to the commanders. While a viewer is on the journey, because of a marvelous work of both actors playing two main heroes, he is basically taking an emotional trip. In some moments of the movie I really felt what the actors felt, as the true horrors of war are shown, such terms as trench warfare and no man's land are described really clearly, as well as the movie is historically accurate, which is very rare for modern movies. One of the best moments in the movie is the plane scene, as it is one of the greatest scenes I have seen in years, as it is showing that both sides had feelings, human feelings, which were changed drastically because of the "War to end all wars".

Set during WWI, two British soldiers are tasked with getting an important message across enemy territory. 1917 is a wall-to-wall thrill ride done in a one-shot fashion that is amazingly unforgettable.

Acting: 10
George Mackay is brilliant as Lance Corporal Schofield. He takes you through the entirety of this journey as a man reluctant to accept the fate that's befallen him. His showcase of fear in the face of danger is really what drives the intensity of this movie.

Beginning: 9
Not the best first ten minutes of action, but a decent setup nonetheless. I was immediately drawn into this wartorn world and was curious to see what would happen next. Not perfect, but it's definitely full speed ahead from here.

Characters: 10

Cinematography/Visuals: 10

Conflict: 10

Entertainment Value: 10

Memorability: 10

Pace: 10
There is such a quiet intensity here that drives the pace of the story. Even when shots aren't being fired, I couldn't help but be on the edge of my seat. With danger around every single turn, the pace is phenomenal.

Plot: 10
The story is straightforward with a clear objective. Where the plot wins is with a few unexpected turns that throw you off course. Not to mention to be able to do all of this in a set of one shots is remarkable.

Resolution: 10

Overall: 99

1917 was British Empire propaganda. I went into this movie on February 1st, 2020. The first act of the movie was extremely good, but as soon as the two deuteragonists reached the farmhouse, the movie went down from there. I was expecting a similar tale to All Quiet on the Western Front, and the "camarade, camarade, camarade" moment with Paul Baumer.

What do we get instead? Bloodthirsty Germans with little describable difference between themselves and Nazis. When your life is saved and you're pulled from the burning wreckage of your plane, outnumbered 2:1, whose first response wouldn't be to stab and kill your saviors?  The majority of men in both World War I and World War II did not shoot to kill, as Lindybeige details in his YouTube video. You have to be trained to be that bloodthirsty, and that training did not exist in the German Empire.

Then, as one of the deuteragonists dies from blood loss in front of a BURNING BUILDING, neither of them think to cauterize the wound to try and stop the bleeding. Yes, soldiers actually did know what cauterizing a wound was in World War I. A short time later, and we then get essentially what is the same as the "White Savior" trope, where the heroic British soldier gives food to the starving French woman and child, suffering under the evil Germans.

Once again, there was a moment for a "camarade" moment with the young German, who is instead strangled to death. If the soldier had remained quiet, but the other drunk soldier had called the guards, then this would have been a much, much more powerful moment humanizing both the English and the Germans. Instead, it succeeds in further demonizing Germans as bloodthirsty devils as this movie has done excellently so far.

On a final note, it was obvious because of the trailer showing the deuteragonist running perpendicular to men rushing out of the trench that he doesn't make it there in time to call off the order. The trailer completely spoiled the ending of this movie.

It hurts me to see how low this movie's rating is. It is a dark, violent, scary war movie that does not let you breathe until the credits role. This one-shot style of filmmaking perfectly immerses you into the time period. Everyone should watch this as a tribute to what war is like. Not a fun movie, but it shows the resilience of the human body and spirit.

I'm not a fan of these 'one-shot' films: I always look for the cut/cuts.  Like in Hitchcock's "Rope", the cut occurs as a camera passes behind a man's black jacket.  Couldn't find the cut in "Birdman", but that was no Hitchcock film.  Here, In 1917, the cut was easy to see: after about an hour, the screen goes blank for about 5 seconds then the hero appears, having fallen down a concrete staircase.  The hero has been out for a while, so the cut works, but it's so obvious.  That said, once the tension ramps up after a rather slow 15 minute opening, the film never lets up. warning: there will be tears at your house.  The last hour or so is thrilling, horrific, beautiful, and oh so very sad.  Yes, as far as war films go, this is no "Apocalypse Now" or "Full Metal Jacket", but director Mendez hasn't reached the heights of Kubrick...although he might.  I found the performances solid, but not sensational. And the destruction of all that magnificent architecture, and of course the loss of almost an entire generation of young men, is so hard to accept.  Let's hope as humans we never see this type of thing - in the real world - again.

The one-shot real-time camera technique hasn't been played around with much since that crappy BIRDMAN dominated the Oscars 2015. Putting this style to use for a two-hour instance of war is exactly what the technique was born for. 1917's pros are its epic cinematography, engaging mission objective, uncomplicated plot, and several moments of edgy seat suspense. The only con lies in the downtime between the action sequences. Insipid conversation obviously happens in real life, so for "matter-of-factness" something like this is excusable.

Directed by Sam Mendes, starring Dean Chapman & George MacKay. A one-shot war epic that transcends film making. This movie is shot as a one-shot take. That means the movie never has a sudden break in camera movement and all shots are digitally edited together to make everything look like it’s in real time. The movie is considered boring by many people but it keeps viewers in awe by the technological achievement in cinematography. Both lead actors playing soldiers are very believable in their respective roles and the supportive cast consists of big time male actors, which comes off distracting at times. The story is quite beautiful and the musical score creates a beautiful sense of imagery on the theme of war. This is a war film people will definitely be taking about in years to come.

While the officers are played by screen legends, the soldiers are portrayed by relative newcomers.  We're put into the picture by the great work of cinematographer Roger Deakins. "1917" tells the story of two soldiers, Schofield (George MacKay) and Blake (Dean Charles Chaplin), who have to travel alone through German territory to deliver an order to save 1600 lives. Throughout the entire movie, it always felt as if Schofield and Blake were in danger, and that sense of intensity really carried the movie. The one-shot look of the movie looks really good; occasionally, you can tell when a cut occurs. Most of the time, it looks seamless. Another thing I noticed, I didn't care for the main characters as much as I did in other war movies. However, what the movie lacks in character, it makes up for in story and visual effects. I don't believe in half-stars, so I give "1917"... 5 stars.

After all the build-up, so disappointing.  1917 is like a video game in which the protagonist runs from one sparsely detailed scene to another.  Symbolic battlefield props are thrown in here and there - a skull in the mud, a large rat, a raft of corpses in the river (along with the ubiquitous fallen tree) - but these would be more befitting of a ghost train ride in a theme park, and come nowhere close to painting the true horror of the Western Front.  The troops are too clean and tidy, the fields are too fresh, the trenches have too obviously just been dug with a back hoe, and the field hospitals look like they were created with the last few dollars of the production budget.  Some plot elements reminded me of the movie Gallipoli, which was far more realistic in its representation of pointless slaughter.

The movie takes you down an unknown path with Corporal Scofield as the reluctant messenger of the British in an effort to save his fellow countrymen from a German trap. Along the way, he doges, swims, crawls and hides as he slowly makes his way to relay his urgent message. The film has all the typical elements one would expect from a WWI period movie, with the exception of any real battle scenes. I found it interesting to watch Schofield's (MacKay) apathy turn to determination after each obstacle to his progress is successfully removed. The movie is about duty and determination, but does not shy away from depicting the horrors of a pointless war. I enjoyed the movie, but in the end I was left feeling empty. It is a lonely journey.

1917 Review 
	1917 is loosely based on the true story of two World War 1 soldiers going on a mission to deliver a message to a colonel to warn him that he and his soldiers are falling into an enemy trap. 1917 enables audience to truly experience the terrors and horrors of World War 1 with its: cinematography, acting, and action so much that it makes us think no wonder why many soldiers suffer from PTSD after surviving a war. 
	1917 brilliantly shows us war and the lives of two troopers with one shot throughout all or at least most of the film no cuts, which is clever because it generates lots of occurrences. The certainty that the film is shot with one shot gives us the experience of experiencing combat with the two troopers because it's as if we're one of the cadets following them, and going into combat with them and this enables us to experience fearfulness and apprehension with them as well. The same kind of occurrence is experienced briefly in the war classic Saving Private Ryan where the audience briefly experiences World War 2 through Captain Miller's eyes when they are enabled to barely hear anything along with Captain Miller. There were even a couple moments where I cringed in fear not just because they were very loud moments but moments that felt so real. One occasion involving an explosion and another occasion involving a gunshot. 
	Dean Charles Chapman and George Mackay generate bravery yet also fear into the characters of Lance Corporal Blake and Lance Corporal Schofield with their acting ability. Dean Charles Chapman provokes plenty of fear and plenty of bravery in Lance Corporal Blake during his final times in the film. 
	1917 enables audience to fell all the pains of battle along with soldiers which creates lots of realism, and it is a must see just for this reason alone. I give 1917 a 9 out of 10.
