Also, for all the great camera work there seemed to be something wrong with the actual images, I don't know if it was the platform I was viewing (DVD) or filters used to achieve a muddy feel but everything seemed grimy, even things that shouldn't have been grimy.

1917 astonish the audience with the "One shot" way it is filmed. It truly felt like you were going back to World War One and following the protagonist from point A to point B this is one of the best movies not only of 2019 but also of the last decade.

Had it been based on a real story, or a post-film bio of fictional characters shown, it would have added tremendously to the movies likability. Much reminds me about Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk here - in that they're both war films which technically stunning, but are also laced with heart and soul. The cinematography will prove to be a high point in the career of Roger Deakins - a career littered with more remarkable achievements than most working in any area of film. Somehow he conjured images and moment of striking beauty, nightmarish hellscapes, touching intimacy - all without sacrificing the narrative propulsion which the apparent one-take style serves; we're left with the sense that this story is but one part of an endlessly, relentlessly flowing river which is sweeping a whole generation mercilessly along. 

Remarkable though his work is, it's not just Deakins' achievements that should be mentioned. The visual effects are more or less faultless; Thomas Newman's omnipresent score is startling; the story itself replete with razor-wire tension, humanity and emotion. It all manages to evoke the hell of war without giving in to the increasingly tiresome war-is-hell cinema clichés we've grown so accustomed to. 

What's rarely mentioned are the two central performances by George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman, perfectly understated enough to draw us in and take us into the heart of ordinary people caught up in events no one should ever have to experience. 

1917 is a brilliant, exhausting, thrilling, moving achievement to stand alongside Dunkirk to make a pair of modern war films that will stand as pillars of the genre.

I'm sure the randomness is supposed to come across as "real life".... but it didn't for me, it came off as boring and meandering.

From the first cinematic trailer 1917 had me hooked. Unfortunately I wasn't able to see it in Theater (which I definitely regret now), but watching it at home was still excellent. I've never before seen a movie shot like this, and it was a thrilling experience. The level of tension as scene after scene continued without a cut, the camera spinning or fixing in place at unpredictable intervals. Some times  you saw what was in line of sight for the characters and at others the angle allowed you to see what they couldn't but desperately needed to.

The design team did an incredible job of bringing 1917 to life. With incredible acting and story telling in addition, the mindset during The Great War was In clear focus here. The youth of the soldiers, horror of trench warfare and the pure mental, emotional and physical exhaustion extracted by a state of perpetual combat combined for an evocative experience that was simply overwhelming.

I loved this movie, I will most definitely be watching it again.

𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐲: A World War 1 action thriller that relies almost entirely on its two lead actors supported by brilliant directing and noticeably impressive cinematography. 1917 follows the urgent mission of Lance Corporal Schofield and Lance Corporal Blake as they attempt to infiltrate the German front lines to deliver a message to a battalion of thousands of men who are mere hours away from unknowingly charging into an ambush. 

Tense, thrilling, and without a weak scene throughout it's duration, I considered 1917 to be the clear favorite for Best Picture (𝘗𝘢𝘳𝘢𝘴𝘪𝘵𝘦) heading into Oscars night. While it took home "only" three victories, each of its 10 total nominations were truly deserved. With crafty camera work that gives the entire film the appearance of one long take, it is one of the most cinematically impressive and well-executed war movies ever made, which helps disguise a plot that is at times overly narrow in focus. It's not available for streaming, but it's well worth the rental fee if you're looking for a two hour movie that you can really invest in every moment of.

The cinematography of the film was great, I really enjoyed the lighting and scenery throughout the film. That was about it though, this was a one to two-time watch. The loss of the main character was premature for the length of the film and for full attachment to one of the main parts of the story. From beginning to end most of the scenes were predictable, I found myself guessing the next ten seconds to minute and being exactly right which was disappointing. I also thought for a war film the action was lackluster. We saw one to two people get shot and it was far and few between.

A breathtaking technical achievement. It tell quite a simple story of two soldiers tasked with delivering a message to another unit 8 miles away. But along the way, we encounter biplane dogfights, enemy trenches and shootouts with German soldiers. Many war films films have come before, but there are few that fully display the horrors that a young man in the trenches experienced. Its raw, its brutal, its heartbreaking and yet, its completely mesmerising.
Clearly, the MVP of this film, its the perceived 'One Take' approach to shooting. I personally love this style, with the opening number to La La Land and the chase scene in Extraction as examples that spring to mind. You cant help but respect and admire the level of skill that went into achieving this feat. Yes, there are moment when you can see where the cuts are, but they are minor, yet seamless. There are some questionable character movements and directions they take that are clearly there to cover the edit. But, it still feels like you are watching a two act play in the open world. 
The action isn't  the typical over the top war film action. There are no unnecessary explosions, no exaggerated stunt work, no gun fights with an unlimited supply of ammo. The action is grounded, some might argue its tame compare to the realities of war, but the actors are clearly in the thick of it and you believe every stumble or look of horror. There is no ridiculous and unrealistic CGI, you really believe they are blowing up trenches and setting fire to villages.
The direction is superb, the script is human and faultless, the cinematography is awe inspiring. But, what mustn't be forgotten or over looked is George McKay. I could not envision anyone else in this role. It would have been easy to but Matt Damon or Zac Efron in this role to increase market appeal. But they made a big budget war film with a relative unknown... and its better for it. His performance is sincere and heartfelt. He looks and behaves like a normal young man caught up in the First World War. He's out of his depth, he scared, hes saddened, but hes duty bound. There are some big name performances along the way, Andrew Scott, Benedict Cumberbatch, Richard Madden etc, but they are glorified cameos. And yet, they never steal the scene or take the focus away from McKay. There is a reason these big names where not on the poster. This isn't their film... Its George McKays.
The final 20 minutes alone, show that this an instant classic, and that George McKay is one to watch. The final act is so packed with emotion and stunning action work. This is a film that will stay with you for a long time.

Aside from being well-made from a technical standpoint, and ground-breaking from a cinematically one, 1917 tells a brutal but tender story about human willpower, and it's helped by a wonderful acting job by star George MacKay. The first 90-minutes is gripping.

Wonderful acting, outstanding camerawork, breathtaking long takes, and an incredible heroic journey. Unfortunately, the main character was entirely unrealistic.

Only in Hollywood can a person have a tripwire-grenade blow up in his face, followed by being piled upon by hundreds of pounds of broken concrete, to then get shot, followed by cracking the back of his skull open, to then be swept over a waterfall, followed by dodging mortar explosions on the battlefield, to then, somehow, end up in front of the colonel, unbroken, unbloodied, and clean-faced... all in the span of 24 hours.
an amazing masterpiece. incredible. this is the definition of art.

This movie made me so sad. As I watched, I felt as if I were walking a dog who strained at the leash in every-which-way. But let me begin by saying that I'm a fan of this era, and the reality its people went through that set the stage for who/what western civilization is today. However, this movie misses the mark on every level. It's over-reliance on modern affect-oriented storytelling destroys a viewer's ability to see the world of 1917 as it might have been. So much of what is developed as a plot line reveals the writer's weakness at character building or an understanding of the inner mind of a young man amid the violence of war. Not once during the entire course of the film do we see inside Will Schofield's motivation or get a sense of his resolve in the face the maelstrom. That it was developed from "fragments" of grandfather Mendes' stories is too plainly evident. The only through line ever developed is a soldier's willingness to follow orders, so that we wind up as far removed from Will as when we first met him. As a medium, it is well made, though the actors were left to wander about in a faux post-modernist way.

De las mejores cintas bélicas que haya visto. Sam Mendes nos demuestra nuevamente que él es capaz de hacer maravillas sin importar el género de la película. Dos soldados les ordenan ir a una misión casi suicida para salvar a un ejército que se dirige a lo que parecer ser  una trampa. La trama es emocionante y con mucha tensión, el guión de Sam Mendes y Kristy Wilson-Cairns es impecable y la cinematografía, que hace la ilusión de ser solo un plano secuencia, ayuda más a poner la atmósfera de que estamos en una carrera contra el tiempo y ayuda a ponerte en los zapatos del protagonista. Realmente puedes llegar a sentir la desesperación que él siente por salvar a sus compañeros de un inminente peligro. Lo único que en lo que tal vez no resaltó fue en las actuaciones, claro que George Mackay cumple su trabajo muy bien pero tampoco es sorprendente. Pero en general es una película casi perfecta y que te hará ver los desastres y lo inhumana que fue, y es, la guerra.

The story is two soldiers have to call off an attack or it will lead to a bloody massacre along with a brother of one of the soldiers, that's it. But within that little premise so much can and does happen. I don't want to spoil every action set piece that happens as I do want all of to go and experience it completely blind not knowing what's going to happen to our characters and the progression of the storyline. Luckily it's not all surviving and Dodging dangerous opticals as there are plenty of quiet 🤫 moments as to either build suspense and Character development giving us the audience time to breathe. The cinematography is the main selling point of the film 🎞 much like Birdman it's designed to feel like one continuous shot (with some clear cuts in certain places) but other than that it makes us feel apart of the story and like we're going on a dangerous journey with our protagonist with the main antagonist being the opticals they face, the environment and the war itself as we have to just sneak past it. The issue I do have with the movie 🎥 is the use of CGI on the animals like the rats 🐀 and cows 🐄, while used only sparingly and when needed it did really take me out of it personally. Overall it was still a great theater 🎭 experience and I wish I saw it in IMAX but sadly wasn't available anywhere near where I lived and I give it a 9/10.

This film opened in January and since then there have been only a handful of days where this movie is not on my mind. This film draws the audience in as almost a third character in the film so all the ups and downs of the characters become the ups and downs of the audience. The film is not as action heavy as the trailer shows, but the tension of every moment in the film is as strong as any battle scene, if not stronger. This movie is enjoyable for a wide audience and thanks to the character actions this film can be enjoyed by people that would not normally enjoy watching a war film. 
This film is made to be accepted by a diverse audience, but I think the diversity in thought makes it hard to be appreciated to its full value by all audiences. Most film experts have praised the technical aspects of the film, such as the amazing cinematography, but some of their biggest issues with the film have been lack of meaningful dialogue and character backstories. I disagree with these criticisms because I believe that anyone that understands military life, whether they have served themselves or have friends and family that have served, will understand the relationship between the two leads and how much story there is without the movie saying it. Another understanding from the military perspective is how attached you can become to someone in such a short amount of time. This is true for all military generations but especially during the two world wars because soldiers were dying in numbers never seen before and yet soldiers would make friends someone they met the day before just to have that friend die the next day. I have heard critics say that they didn't care as much about the characters as they should of because there wasn't enough backstory, but that is such a real military experience because these soldiers were losing friends left and right, friends they cared about but probably didn't know much better than a classmate you're doing a project with. I think this aspect of having probably about only 10 lines of backstory in the film is going unappreciated by film experts that grew up far from a military influence. Another issue I would dispute is that the movie is slow or doesn't have action scenes. Again this will be mostly appreciated by those familiar with military life because they wholeheartedly understand the motto hurry up and wait. The leads don't wait around, but since this is a 'single-shot' film putting these leads into action scene after action scene would be dishonest. There are a lot of tense moments and as any soldier can attest sometimes the downtime messes with your anxiety more. Soldiers are trained for battle so once the fighting starts your instincts takeover over and you don't really have time to think because everything is happening so fast, but the downtime when you don't know when the next big thing will happen is when your brain begins to panic because you have time to think about everything and dwell on every single one of your worst fears. The downtimes never get rid of the tension entirely and there is never a downtime long enough to forget the hardship of the mission that lies ahead. The lack of consistent makes this story more plausible because if the leads saw action for the entire hour and 59 minutes they would seem invincible like a Marvel superhero. 
Lastly I believe that even with film knowledge and military familiarity the movie still isn't full appreciated without an in depth knowledge of WW1 history. I am a history major and the accuracy of the film is impeccable. There are critics that say the film was fantastical and not based in reality but if they studied history for years like I have they would instantly be proven wrong. The Night Window scene is my favorite in the film and I was once told that it's pretty but weird that the Germans are shooting so many flares; no it's not. This is in the late stages of the war and this town was now a battlefield so with the Allies on either side of the city it is there job to keep watch 24 hours a day which includes night and rural France in 1917 was not known for its amazing electrical infrastructure. In order to protect a town at night you have to be able to see the town and even if they had lamps in that town they would be dimmer than a full moon so they used flares because lightbulbs were not that bright or cheap in 1917. Another important thing related to both military life and history is the date. The film begins on April 6, 1917 which is the day the United States joined the war which was very important for Europe, but there is not a single mention of it in the film. That is extremely realistic because as important as it is too history, to a single soldier on a mission it is not worth a mention. In military life there are times where the mission is the most important thing in the world and other times when the mission feels pointless because the war will keep killing people, but what this movie does well is show how many times a soldier can alternate those thoughts in a single day. The movie ends the way it started, under a tree. That serenity after the chaos of the movie will only last as long as the serenity of the first scene because despite a journey that most of us can agree is so harrowing that it should only be done once we also know he will be plucked from that tree again because he will still be a soldier tomorrow.  
George MacKay is fantastic in this film and all that character backstory is given through a few words and his deeply talented facial expressions. Everything important about his character, and the juxtaposition to the other lead, can be seen in MacKay's eyes. The music in the film is phenomenal and like the film is perfect without needing to be too fantastical. This film reminds me why I play my instruments, why I love history, and why I love movies. The Night Window scene is my favorite where every single aspect of filmmaking lines up from the cinematography to the music to the acting. This scene is one of the only moments in movie history that I can claim as absolutely perfect.

I enjoyed the accuracy of the trench warfare, the historical accuracy and the costuming. I was dismayed by the lagging storyline while the main character(s) were traveling by foot. I understand that it was part of the storyline, but some time lapse would have helped the boredom.

1917 is a YouTube 'special' bigged up to be a box office hit. Yes, I will admit that the filming and the methods that are used are fantastic, I would rate it as one of the most brilliantly and beautifully filmed War Movies I've watched. But... and this is a big one... but it's a film based on the FIRST WORLD WAR. One of/if not the most brutal war in human history where the sacrifice of 'everyday' men was beyond modern comprehension. This film shows non of that... absolutely nothing of the horrors of war, non of the gore or the emotional toll it takes on soldiers and men. The script and dialect of the actors says to me that they shouldn't be arsed with filming and that they wanted to go back to their nice warm hotels to get a shower. Which to me means that's the director or screenwriters fault and not the actors themselves as the cast line-up is one of the best britain has to offer. As for the other issues... well to start the rifle drills are appalling. Considering the main character has served at the Somme he seems very reluctant to cycle his rifle bolt to continue the engagement with the enemy. Secondly, the scenery changes too often with very little information to the viewer. First you start in a picture perfect representation of what the trenches were and then you end up in a farmhouse in the middle of nowhere. All of a sudden you are thrown out the back of a Bedford lorry with nothing around only to find that there is a half destroyed village just to your left, why the german sniper didnt start engaging immediately I dont know. Then once you go down a river you're in a new trench, freshly dug yet a completely different soil colour to the first (traditional salisbury plain) with no actual explanation or story might I add that leads to how far the character has travelled. There are many other problems with this film that will take too long to cover so to summarise this I will say that it is a brilliantly filmed movie, however it lacks the substance, storyline and accuracy to be a believable war movie that immerses the viewer into the First World War. As such, to say that the film is for Alfred H Mendes I find disappointing. No doubt he was an extremely brave man and deserving to be called a national hero as all of the service personnel were in their time, yet I wonder what he would think of the films depiction of the war... my great grandfather and childhood hero wouldn't be so full of praise.

I saw the trailers, reviews, and notices for this movie. But really, it was an interview with Nigel Farage that got me to watch this movie. This British patriot who admitted he was a Great War buff and came back satisfied.

	It was a great surprise because ever since the 1930's epic All Quiet On The Western Front, World War I movies have mostly been anti-war. People look upon that war shamefully, the Lost Generation as it was known in the years after it was fought and lost. But slowly and steadily movies set during this period were becoming more respected. Wonder Woman was set during World War I and it was phenomenal. With that experience, I was more than eager to feel this movie was more than worth it.

	It is that and more. Just like Birdman, this movie does an incredible job of using phenomenal camerawork in making this feel like it was filmed in one continuous shot. No doubt to simulate realism but more importantly the scope of the battlefield from start to finish to gain a real education into the fight that was first World War.

	There are plenty of familiar faces as well as some great moments but the whole film is a masterpiece and I am so glad to have seen it. Worth watching.

When I first heard of „1917", I feared that so soon after Nolan‘s „Dunkirk" it will feel like an unimaginative ripp-of of thereof, but I could not have been more wrong, as it is a completely different kind of a war movie. Here we have closer, more personal look at soldiers life rather than on the great scale of military operations. At the same time we don't loose the high stakes or epic magnitude of action, we just learn to see them from a more claustrophobic perspective, which is more that adequate, given the very nature of the trench war. And while supporting cast of really famous actors serves here its purpose, I found characters played by relatively unknown thespians, especially those playing two main roles, to be especially well-played.

"UN VERDADERO PORTENTO CINEMATOGRÁFICO"
Sam Mendes esta vez se paso, no hay forma sencilla de empezar hablar de esta obra maestra no solo del cine bélico,también del cine meticuloso, del cine espectacular, del cine emocionante.1917 logra la multi-tarea de conseguir tantas cosas a la vez de una visión inexplorada en el cine de guerra, desde ese plano de inicio espectacular de zoom out a los protagonistas descansando, anunciando el despertar de la travesía que les espera al ojo del huracán al que se adentraran para entregar ese mensaje que salvaría varias vidas, pero que al poner las de ellos en la linea cambiaría las suyas para siempre, desentrañando las consecuencias inertes en las acciones que una guerra rodea y con la nada menos que soberbia, fotografía de Roger Deakins de la cual es su sello reconocible y que no falla, permite darle a esos momentos de tensión una capa poética y profundidad humanística que solo me recuerda a cuando vi por primera vez Apocalypsis now, la decisión de dirección de simular una toma continua invita a no pestañear y no perderse nada y como esto múltiples cosas de las cuales se podría hablar de esta obra maestra moderna, lo único que me molesta es no poder borrarla de mi mente para poderla experimentarla de nuevo por primera vez.

The movie is incredible. The cinematography and editing is the best that I’ve seen in any movie in a few years, not only do they really make you feel immersed in the movie, but the movie says so much without any dialogue. One of my screenwriting professors always used to say to show instead of tell whenever possible, and 1917 excels at that. Coupled with the cinematography and editing, the movie’s soundtrack creates the tension that the movie needs. Whether on screen for two hours or two minutes, every member of the cast shines in such a waythat if I hadn’t known any better (and recognized a few faces), I might’ve thought I was actually watching World War 1. Watching the movie you can really feel Sam Mendes’s passion for the movie that he’s creating. My only complaint is that I didn’t see it in theaters while I had the chance.

There literally is only one thing to gripe about, and that is only if you're a stickler for 100% authenticity in historical epics - the location. The film is set near Ecouste-Saint-Mein in Northern France. The trailer depicts a scene where Will Schofield (George MacKay) jumps into a raging river. There are no rivers in Ecouste, aside from a very small stream. Other than that, the area around Ecouste and the film's shooting locations are similar. Not a big deal at all, but like I said, if I had to gripe about one thing, that would be it.

Sam Mendes directed this drama set during World War I about two British soldiers (George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman), who are ordered to deliver a message, across German lines, to call off an attack. One of the soldiers has a brother taking part in the attack. Mendes based the story on an incident from the war that was retold to him by his grandfather. Filmed by cinematographer Roger Deakins to look as if it was done in one fluid, continuous shot; the film is visually marvelous with several amazingly choreographed and staged action sequences. However, like other contemporary war movies about the other war from that period, "Saving Private Ryan" and Dunkirk," characterization and drama are minimized in favor of action to detrimental effect. The lead actors, who give good performances in their confined roles, don't have distinctive personalities to draw us in emotionally. This is about the visceral experience of war with nothing pertinent to say about war itself. There is one brief, touching moment where a soldier hides in the home of a German woman and her newborn and they are able to connect despite their different nationalities and language barriers. (This scene reminds us of Renoir's "Grand Illusion.") Written by Mendes and Krysty Wilson-Cairns. Music is by Thomas Newman. Won Oscars for Best Cinematography, Visual Effects, and Sound Mixing. With Mark Strong, Andrew Scott, Richard Madden, Claire Duburcq, Colin Firth, and Benedict Cumberbatch.

Sam Mendes' war thriller 1917 (2019) is a magnificent cinematic experience. It's all about the odyssey of what two young British soldiers endure to warn 2 battalions about a German trap to save 1000's of lives. Part Paths of Glory, part All Quiet on the Western Front, and part Dunkirk, 1917 tries and succeeds in making you feel sympathy for the average foot soldiers rendered helpless during WWI. I would say Saving Private Ryan, Patton, or The Thin Red Line are better war films, but 1917 has heart and skillful direction to keep you enthralled by the striking horror of it all. 

1917 is shot like you are running across No Man's Land or maneuvering through crowded trenches. It's an impressive technical feat as Roger Deakins' gorgeous cinematography appears as if 1917 was shot in one long take. It's a cool effect to be sure, but most effective in holding the audience captive like you are stuck on this suicide mission with these two brave, young men. I love the burning building shot at night as Deakins spins the camera around to give you a feel for how scary the situation would be. Mendes' direction is excellent and suspenseful as anything can happen at any moment.

Thomas Newman's score is haunting as he beautifully composed pieces for each and every little moment of 1917. I loved George MacKay's lead role in 1917. You see every bit of fear and courage he displays in a brave and vulnerable role for 1917. I liked Dean-Charles Chapman, but I feel like he not only got less to do than MacKay, but he was not as engrossing or mature. Colin Firth, Mark Strong, Andrew Scott, Benedict Cumberbatch, and Richard Madden all get neat cameos in strong shows of character acting from the lot of them. My only complaint is that each of them only gets a minute long cameo and that's it. I wish we got more time from each of them. Claire Duburcq gets a heartfelt cameo alongside MacKay for a nice quiet scene.

I enjoyed 1917 for its fast pace and impressive direction, but I wanted more from the other lead and more of the supporting cast in general. There's not that much action either, but there are riveting sequences in here scattered among the debris.

An absolute technical achievement in a motion picture. A must see with stunning set design and an amazing score. That great directing from Sam Mendes should inspire other filmmakers to do other amazing things in the future. Absolute must see! One of my favorite war movies.

There was a lot of hype surrounding this film on release, and it lives up to those expectations. Sam Mendes teams with Deakins to create a non stop thriller set in 1917. Technically speaking, this film is incredible to watch. The journey throughout the war torn country side is unsettling to watch, and those long takes pay off. 1917 always had an ambitious uphill battle, but I'm happy to say it is all worth it. The relatively unknown leads are surrounded by strong character actors in support. This is much in line with Dunkirk, with both Mendes and Nolan rising to fame in the same era. I'm happy this wasn't the best picture for 2019, I feel Parasite was the correct choice, but this is still a great film, just not an instant classic. #IMDb #MovieReview 4,0 ⭐️ Dois soldados recebem a missão de avisar agrupamento sobre armadilha dos alemães e evitar grande tragédia. Em plano sequência, tecnicamente impecável, lembra em momentos a jogos de vídeo game em primeira pessoa.

1917 is a stunning masterpiece with its impressive cinematography and cinematics. The single- sequence takes that underly the film are truly impressive, and deftly captures the atmosphere that defined the war.

An immersive cinematic experience, its impressive cinematography and editing, compelling characters and directing and gritty action makes for a viewing experience like watching a Call of Duty gameplay.

1917 is a simple story told in a magnificent way. The cinematography is like a well-choreographed dance, moving from scene to scene almost seamlessly. This film tugs at your heartstrings during some parts, then makes you hold your breath during others. Trust me, once this movie starts, it's hard to take your eyes off the screen.

Thought it was pretty good. But best war movie of all time? Not going in that direction. Platoon, Patton, Full Metal Jacket, Apocalypse Now, Black Hawk Down, Deer Hunter, Saving Private Ryan, Paths of Glory and Hacksaw Ridge are just some of the movies i put ahead of this. What struck me is the amazing war sets. Mendes must of really went out of his way to create those incredible shots. Just shows you that you don't have to get married to CGI to make you movie look amazing...

Definitely a great WW1 movie if I ever saw one. I just love Sam Mendez and his excellent directing. There was genuine suspense as I feared the surviving messenger would be killed and the platoon of soldiers would all meet a grim end because they weren't warned of the Nazi ambush.

Phenomenal storytelling. It has been a while since I have seen a movie that has captivated me this way. I sat on the edge of my seat throughout every scene. Very well written film. The cinematography is beautiful. In my eyes, this film is extremely timely. It is a story about our resilience as people. It reminded me about how much we encourage each other to carry on and moments of kindness which give us strength.
Totally loved it, great acting, direction and absolute masterpiece camera work! The story is really good it's definitely a must watch for everyone.

Unbelievable movie. Amazing cinematography. Great characterization and story line. Very compelling and heart wrenching. I would have tried to more backstory into these families a little more. Given them more who they were, and what they did, that could have ruined the overall experience though with too much backstory so the experience itself and what these two soldiers went through really was enough for this movie to show me how difficult this must have been.
Great story awesome visual.

A gargantuan technical achievement in direction, cinematography and visual effects. Deserves all the Oscar nominations and wins it got. The made to look like one shot approach is very convincing. It does a great job in depicting the brutality of war. But for all the story, it seems like the story is simplified to help the one shot approach. We don't learn much about the main characters, because of that we don't always feel connected with them and don't care that they are in danger. Nonetheless, a masterwork and worth watching.

An incredible achievement in Cinema. Finally a truly immersive first world war experience. I went to go and see this movie twice in cinema and each time i had the chills. The way Mendes can create such a tense experience is incredible and just proves how he is one of the best in the industry at the minute. And how can i not talk about the Cinematography and in this instance Roger Deakins smashes it out the park with some of the best one takes of all time.  I do feel though that Dean Charples Martin deserved a bit more screen time as he was such an enjoyable character yet i suppose it as meant to show how quickly war can change at any time. But  i feel the true standout was George Mckay who lost himself in his role and really carried the movie into history.
Final Verdict:
Grade: A
Enjoyment Scale: 90%

It's no Saving Private Ryan, but it was a decent war movie.  The "nonstop" camera shot is neat, but it results in a lot of lulls in the movie in order to offer some semblance of believability.  It didn't really feel particularly satisfying in the end, either, which surprised me.  I know it's supposed to be historical, and history doesn't always play out like a movie, but it just kind of ended.  I'm sure they could have done more with it if they'd used a more traditional filming style, but I still think there are better ways you could have tied up the ending.

Go see this film in the theater right now. See it in DOLBY or IMAX. Do not wait for any streaming service or DVD release. This film is a must see. This is NOT a story about war. It is a story about purpose, perseverance, bravery, courage, loyalty, humanity, brotherhood, family and love. There was so much symbolism and creative cinematography all throughout that I could not help but immerse myself within each step of the journey. If you will allow it, this is a film experience that you actually FEEL as you watch. I found myself hanging on every breath with every turn; then catching a break only to be wakened by the immediacy of life’s fragility. The realism of each scene was so well done it’s easily one of the best films, of its kind, that I’ve seen in the last decade. Yes. This one ranks very high. Sam Mendes deserves high accolades for this thrilling and technically stunning masterpiece. Like I said, go see it. Tonight. Tomorrow. This week or next weekend. Just don’t miss it in a theater near you!

The movie is great: it has an amazing cinematography, the colors are amazing, the textures, the music, the acting is not bad at all, and all in all it is a work of art. The only problem that I have with this film by Sam Mendes, is that the story hasn't got anything special: it is another war film and period. There are emotions and the story is beautiful, but that's it, there's nothing special about the story and there's nothing that stands out about it. A great movie needs to have great visuals and audios, but the story is one of the, if not the most important factor of them all, because that it the entire purpose of films: to tell stories that make something, change something or teach something, and sadly, 1917 doesn't accomplish that.

Simple plot - deliver the message. 
In some films, it's the twists and turns of the plot that keeps you on the edge of your seat. However, this film in an odd way, took a simple plot and essentially enabled you to immerse yourself in the experience as you were following the character throughout the entire film as if you were there, with him, accompanying. The way this was filmed, the cinematography, editing, sound, camera angles, everything ... it truly felt like I had oculus 3D glasses on and I was in the film experiencing everything.  Because it was edited to be continuous shots, it really truly allowed you to be immersed in the experience to the point that I was not distracted by anything else but the mission of the plot, it really gave me anxiety at times as I was so carried away with it. The actors were great; love that they used actors who weren't famous as that tends to ruin the experience for me as it sometimes pulls me from the experience as I become aware of the famous actor acting. This was well done, well filmed, great casting. Awesome.

Obviously, an exceptionally well-made movie.  The single-shot decision was a mixed bag.  (I found myself distracted wondering HOW they made some of the scenes or watching the motion of the camera, as opposed to watching the acting.)  But is had three big flaws to me.  (#3) BORING ENDING. The end was predictable, and it just... stopped.  Almost like they ran out of film.  (#2) BORING CHARACTERS. Mendes's decision to have two "everyman" soldiers made it emotionally distant. I didn't know the dudes, didn't care about them. (#1) TOLD THE WRONG STORY. It's 2019, can we stop having movies with a cast of 99% white males? (And this coming from me, a white male.) OK, yes, the British military in 1917 was probably 99% white. So, it's not the casting that's the problem... it's the story Mendes chose to tell. The most interesting character in the movie with the best story, we saw for five minutes -- a young woman caring for an infant that wasn't her own in a bombed-out city. Who is she, how did she get there, and WHAT HAPPENS to them?  I want THAT movie, not the two nobodies racing to a conclusion I already know about before it starts.

Spoiler alert but maybe I can save you some time you will never get back. My girlfriend and I really wanted to like this movie and were excited because of the great reviews. For starters, it drastically under represents the vastness of WW1 when the characters keep arriving at their destinations so quickly, "oh, they are there already?". Our eventual main character gets a bad cut holding barbed wire at the barb... really? Ok... things happen I guess. A rat almost kills them...sure, why not? Save a German from a horrific flaming death, then leave him unguarded and unrestrained? Doesn't seem logical during war but at least we are minus 1 character I didn't care at all about. Whoah, a company of soldiers just appears in the no man's land that they have been fighting for every inch up to... hmmm. Onto a truck then about a mile to the burned out city (maybe 2 miles total travel at this point). Kill the sniper, then when a German in plain sight in open ground fires at our hero, a trained combat soldier in a war zone, he runs away. Our brave character, seeking a hiding spot, meets a girl and baby and he suddenly has loads of food and milk he fortuitously filled his canteen with, never mind that there's no way to give it to the baby or that it wouldn't last but a feeding or 2... the baby is saved. Back out to the city where he happens upon upon a young German soldier and puts his hand over his mouth... gee, that didn't work so he somehow strangles him then heroically drops his weapon and runs away from a drunken German soldier who can barely stand up. Our weaponless warrior then bravely runs through enemy fire where he jumps into river rapids and "escapes". I'm about ready to leave the theater but Iv'e invested time, I'm trying to see it through. Another few hundred yards and he finds the troop he was looking for listening to some guy sing a boring song that we are forced to sit through as well... yawn, falling asleep. Some other stuff happens, not paying much attention at this point. Another couple hundred yards and he  arrives at the front lines where he is to stop the battle. He makes it to a commander as the troops are leaving the trenches to get slaughtered and the commander, like a true bad-ass who commands young men during wartime, is crying like a baby. That's it, I throw up my arms and leave the theater to wait for my girlfriend outside. She said I didn't miss anything. I should have walked out like I did when Forest started running in that other academy award winning piece of garbage. On a positive note, I thought the costumes were great and I hope they won the academy award for it but the academy awards are irrelevant now anyway, since they just pander to the wokest tripe, so actually... whatever.

Way too bravura for its own good. The over-intrusive camera work called to mind a Blair Ditch Project. And as a purported one-2-hour-long-tracking shot, it's not even that. So the point is--? Just to make us admire the camerawork?? Not what I go to a movie for.

It does has a good sense of place, of course, a big plus. Some of the set pieces are quite nice, some only a little annoying, and a few are damn close to intolerable. 

I just saw "All Quiet on the Western Front" another--one of a whole category--film on the horrors of war. So there's NOTHING new here, it's just one movie-trope after another. Finally--and what a shock--that woman in the bombed out house just happened to be young and ravishingly beautiful. It's this kind of retro cliché--as well as the anachronisms in the dialogue ("Fuck off," "I hate to interrupt your busy schedule," etc.) that put the lie to the intolerable pomposity of the direction/storyline.

1917 maintains intimacy amongst the madness of battle. With a unique lens on the emotional journey of its leads, while lensing the outstretched and scorched landscapes of war, Roger Deakins and Sam Mendes give Lubezki and Innaritu of Revenant fame a run for their money. The scope, both large and small, is just why the film is so powerful. The screenplay is a carefully crafted, neatly unfolding portrayal of vulnerability, loss and growing up in the most treacherous and horrible of places. But what's magical about the film, if we can use such a term for a "war movie," is that it simply doesn't feel like any other film about war. 1917 is a story about relationships, about love, about loss and brotherhood - and this is all achieved while barely knowing anything about our characters lives outside the unfolding action and the present demands upon them. That is an accomplishment in storytelling, and in this case, kudos to all departments for helping create what we see one moment after the next. Indeed, the film moves fluidly by, and when it was over it felt like I'd seen a slice of life and a glimpse into war I had not known before. It felt new, and felt, fresh.

1917 is a reminder of how good a cinema experience can be. Astounding attention to detail, excellent cinematography, a field-day for Roger Deakins. Well paced out sequences; the 'single-shot' style is seamless and plays into the film well. Tonal changes are executed very well and visually with the visceral changes in scenery. The segway at the midpoint of the film is excellent. Broader themes are hinted at but never brought to any justification; the story is incredibly simple, relying on visual experience to encapsulate the audience, which it notably succeeds in. 1917 is not focused on its depth, but consistency, technicality and precision are so skilfully executed it is undeniably fascinating to see.

After a few years of boring and repeating superhero movies, 1917 steps in to bring some of the missing drama and atmosphere of one of the most devastating historical events that humankind has ever faced.
The movie reminded me of the similarly executed "Thin red line", bringing together the human and the personal struggles of the great war.
A lovely direction just positioning the audience directly into the events manages to bring the spectator directly into the scene, rather than letting him feel like a witness of events.
If you are expecting to see an action film, then this film surely will not match your expectations, it was never meant to do that, but rather set you in an emotional journey of the sufferings and the sacrifices made by those during the great war. If you ever loved books like "Forgotten Voices of the Great War" or "All Quiet on the Western Front" then this movie will surely match your taste and expectations.

While his film was a visually fascinating, I found the "one cut" approach to be a little on the tedious side. Certainly, it conveyed the urgency and immediacy of the situation and the story, but it distracted horribly from the audience's ability to absorb and understand what was happening. In order to optimize the horrors of war an audience (especially one over a hundred years removed from an event) that has no historical or collective memory of the event, needs a background on which they can contrast the action on the screen. the actors did a magnificent job with what they had to work with. However, I felt that not even they had enough understanding of the situation and its gravity historically or personally to have developed the depth of character one hopes to see in a good film. I cannot say that I was ever able to empathize with any of the characters, I did not know; who they were outside of their names, where they came from, their family status, their backgrounds, experiences, aspirations or anything else about them that would have made it easier for me to relate to them. All of these things are easily established with bits of dialogue. And getting to know something a wee bit more personal about the character is how a filmmaker gets us emotionally invested in his characters and ultimately his story and film. that emotional investment is what creates the lump in our throats or the tears in our eyes when one of the main characters loses his life or whatever. I haven't seen "Saving Private Ryan" in a decade or more but I still remember that Tom Hanks' character was a schoolteacher before the war. I couldn't tell you what Lance Corporals Blake and Scofield had done before the war and I just walked out of the theatre less than an hour ago. the failure of the director to develop the identities and depth in his two main characters was the single most distracting element of this film. it made his characters two dimensional and thus his film no matter how stunning it was visually could not get beyond two dimensional at best itself. if you want to understand what I am talking about watch the 1981 Classic directed by Peter Weir and titled "Gallipoli", a quite similar story but directed with infinitely more feeling and understanding.

History is very important for all of us, so we must keep up on the learning and remembering of the present and past. Hopefully, we can learn from mistakes and appreciate the sacrifices made by our soldiers.

There are so many war movies and anthologies that it can be hard to see how any new entries can break new ground or showcase anything truly unique. This film manages to do that by focusing on a simple story and only a few characters, as well as via mind-boggling effects wizardry that makes the whole picture feel intimate and seamless. This is a heavy, emotional film, but also a significant one.

Lots of emotions towards this movie. First impression was to complain about another World War movie. The ending quote brought a lot of questions. A dedication to Sam Mendes' grand-father « who told us the stories ». Here I was in a theatre, seeing another World War movie in this desire of keeping the memory of those who fought. Another Great Britain memory to keep the history in our minds. I Think I've had enough of that story. 

That said, i'm not asking to forget. Never forget. Here comes my contradiction. To never forget you have to tell the story in repeat. Specifically to those who weren't there, those that look at history as something from the past. 

The consequence of history, creates the present as we know it. 

I'm concerned about all those stories that we might have never heard of. Here, in great America. First nations. Massacres. Blood on hands of the colonizers. Same colonizers who created the history that have been told in my early school years. In their perspectives to remember part of it and an attempt to minimize, erase other less infamous parts of it. 

I need to see more diversity. We all deserve to know where we come from to truly understand who we are to build a clearer knowledge surrounding history. All part of history. Know the responsibilities that comes from our past.  

Looking at Chile made me realize the effect of forgetting the past. A story of a dictature that wasn't really told. A population incapable to communicate their stories to their children. Scared of the consequences after seeing so much violence. The country evolved without evolving. Justice was never made. The perpetrators still in power with the money. Here we are, years later, to see the story happening again with the same ugliness but in a different way. 

Stories need to survive time, but I guess it's also time that European grandpas start to listen others outside themself.

Staggeringly good First World War movie that is told on an epic scale. There were sequences where I did just find myself thinking "How the hell did they film that?" The plot centres on a desperate mission by two young men to deliver a message behind enemy lines that will prevent a massacre of a thousand other British soldiers. It is a tense, nerve jangling story of heroism and tragedy. There is no flinching from the brutal and terrible nature of trench warfare and there are some really graphic and disturbing scenes. However, Sam Mendes handles the subject matter beautifully and though horrific, the violence is never gratuitous. Some great performances from a solid cast make this a truly memorable cinema experience and 1917 has rightly won a clutch of awards at the BAFTAs and Oscars.

1917 is what I would call a perfect movie. 

1917 is an emotional ride that you take with the characters every step of the way, literally, the entire film is meant to look like one take, and they pulled that off fantastically, even watching the behind the scenes just blows your mind. 

In addition to it being shot in what is meant to look like one take, it is also a gorgeous film effects wise, each effect CG or not was absolutely gorgeous and true eye candy. 

The acting is another highlight of 1917, each actor played their role to a tea, it helped make the one take style of shooting work even further to emerge you in the world. 

The sound design was incredible, each gunshot sounding like a heavy boom and each explosion feeling like it rocked the Earth with it's sounds, but still not to quiet or unbearably loud.

The story was incredible, a war story with major basis in reality it makes you feel the emotions that the characters are feeling, again in part to the acting, it also helps you see the entire story unfold in ONE UNBROKEN TAKE. 

In a concluding sense, I give 1917 a 10/10, anyone who enjoys films owes it to themselves too see 1917 as not only a gorgeously written and acted film, but also as a unique experience in the modern film industry.

From start to finish, I was on the edge of my seat. This movie didn't have the feel good, everything's going to be okay vibe at all, which only added to the realism. I can confidently say it was the most cinematic, beautiful, and interesting movie I've seen in the past year.

The village sequence alone is worth the price of admission, but the entire movie is jaw dropping. 

I couldn't take my eyes off of it.

I'm not really one of those guys who gets super into war stuff, with one exception: World War I.  Another thing about me, I adore long takes in movies.  So 1917, a WWI movie designed to look like it was shot all in one-take, how was I not going to love this thing?  It's a very simple story, basically two-guys have to get a message to a place otherwise a lot of people will die.  Simple, but effective.  Interestingly as well, we really don't know a lot about either of these guys either.  Funny thing though, it wasn't until we learned a tiny bit about one of them in the final shots that I even realized this.  We still become attached to them in their journey.  Perhaps because they're all we have, and we're stuck with them, just as they're stuck with each other.  That's not to say there isn't character, there is, but it's just told in a unique way, a way that feels genuine to the wartime setting.  It's an unusual form of narrative, and it surprisingly works.  On top of that, godamn is this film gorgeous!  Every frame is just littered with beauty.  Horrible imagery often, but glorious to look it.  Takes your breath away in horror and awe all at once.  One of the best war films I've ever seen.

Both intimate & immense, '1917' is the first major film in recent memory to take on the theater of World War 1 and it is pure cinema. The technical achievements here are unmistakable; strongly bolstered by Roger Deakins' amazing (No surprise there) cinematography and a virtually seamless blend of production values to put you right in the trenches with the characters. Not to mention Thomas Newman's score is pretty darn great, it is very understated but rousing in the right moments of escalation. Like 'Dunkirk', this war flick is not character-driven in the traditional sense but unlike the former, it does a better job developing the lead(s) enough to be emotionally engaged with them - 8.5/10 (A-)

1917 (2019) stands amongst the greatest of war films, as it manages to dive into a content-heavy genre and create something completely unique. The main attraction of 1917 (2019) that many talk about is how it is filmed to look like one big long take, and while that is extremely impressive, it creates an up close and personal feel about it as you're dealing with the characters in real time and experiencing things along with them. Not to mention it never cuts away to a different persons point of view, so you know as much as these characters we follow.

There isn't much character development provided, however it isn't necessary as everything feels so real, and any sort of time developing them would have felt unnatural. Despite knowing little about the characters, following them into uncharted territory was extremely suspenseful and tension packed.

The story is simple, but the execution is flawless, capturing all kinds of emotions while never straying from the main plot. Despite it being a war film, it doesn't contain that much action, which is rare however not disappointing. 1917 (2019) tells a very personal story in World War I and manages to pull off every thing it goes for thanks to its truly fantastic cinematography.

At the end of the film when he is running on the top of the trenches trying to get the officer and running, you are just sat there in your seat, the scene makes your heart feel like you are there running with him. You are filled with many kinds of emotions, relief, sadness for what he has been through and what the soldiers will go through if he fails. It makes you feel like you are the soldier and the film just has that kind of poetry that you rarely get in most films.

1917 is a masterpiece in film-making; essential viewing for history buffs and cinephile's alike. The film not only aims to move its audience with a rather simple yet moving plot, but aims to give viewers a unique visual and auditory experience of the trenches and shelled cities of The Great War which are rarely presented in this fashion in movies past. Its use of clever cinematography, detailed set pieces, and brilliant soundtrack creates an eerie and tense aura for most of the film that is sure to keep moviegoers at the edge of their seats. Complex and intricate dialogue are not the focus of this film. We as an audience are denied flashy battle scenes found in countless war movies. Rather, the focus is solely on conveying raw emotion and tension felt by the two main characters as they set out on a seemingly impossible mission to deliver a message that will save sixteen hundred comrades from walking into a trap. 1917 is a film that stands out amidst other similar works, and is a film with relevant and important subject matter. It is a work of art that pays homage to the struggles endured by all who fought in The War to End All Wars; a subject that is almost all but forgotten in today's society. 1917 reminds viewers to never forget the sacrifices made by those who came before us, and will continue to serve this purpose from this day until our last ones.

Impressionante. O trabalho e dedicação do Sam Mendes aqui é notável. Todo o filme estava friamente conectado. A direção faz com que a cinematografia tenha um controle total de como tudo ocorre, como se fossemos um hospedeiro e/ou todo cenário fosse uma esteira, e falando nisso, que cenografia absurda - que contribui e muito para a atmosfera. E aqui vem uma curiosidade: como foi possível planos tão longos? É como se o cenário não acabasse mais.

O roteiro tem seus méritos. Sabe bem como familiarizar o publico com historias ou alívios cômicos - bem no inicio do filme; também consegue nos fazer ficar vidrado num gênero que já se tornou maçante há um tempo - quando não aproveitado da maneira correta; e traz justamente a possibilidade de fazer um filme com pouquíssimos cortes, se assemelhando a um plano sequencia por completo. E por ultimo, devo apenas mencionar o plano sequencia que ocorre próximo ao final do filme, que é simplesmente maestral e emocionante. Ver isso num Imax faz toda a diferença!

For me a great movie with some surprising post-Brexit features: The Brits are again alone in Europe and all Huns (Germans) are bloody snaky bastards.

But the real precious thing about the movie: It puts your daily peace-life problems heavily into proportion:
Didn't die today? Didn't lost a friend today? Didn't fail to prevent mass killings today? Didn't crawl over dead decaying bodies today? Must be a great day!
It's humbling the viewer in content and also regarding technology: The meaning lies in low tech. The only physical photograph of a loved one instead of a thousand digital ones. The only long cut instead of racing for super fast cuts. Quality and little human moments against quantity and the rush for big stuff and effects.
The backlash against digital over burden and infinite choice relativism has begun? Will we see more, slow, low tech, humble movies?

Easily the best war movie of the year and possibly the decade. 

The "one take" concept, while also a technical marvel, made a spectacle of the passage of time and distance in a way only a filmmaker with a clear vision and mastery of pacing could accomplish effectively. The plot felt purposeful, the stakes felt high, the actors felt talented beyond what their experience would suggest, and the climax had hearts pounding audibly throughout the theater. 

A small complaint is the film was a bit over-scored. The thunderous and booming soundtrack clashed with the gritty and visceral imagery. A tense but altogether quieter score would perhaps have had more of an impact but even the tracks used were not distracting enough to break immersion.   

1917 is a movie that has earned its place among the year's best pictures and should be remembered as nothing less than a brilliantly made ode to the brutality of the first World War.

There's no denying that 1917 is a technical triumph. Give it all the technical awards. It earns them all. But that's all it achieves. The plot follows two British soldiers (George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman) in constant unbroken motion as they embark on an impossible mission beyond German lines to deliver a life-saving message on foot. It makes the promise that you're going to be feeling everything the characters feel all the way to the end. The results are mixed. In its flashy insistence to immerse you in the horror of WWI, aiming to capture the immediacy of a war zone in constant tension, 1917 loses sight of all the other things that cinema can do to capture the hearts of those watching it.

The film opens with its heroes waking from an improvised slumber in a bed of flowers. Blake (Dean-Charles Chapmen), baby-faced and big-mouthed, nominates his friend Schofield (George MacKay) to tag along on what he thinks is a routine delivery job. There are whispers of the Germans retreating and the British going home to roast dinners. This is a false dawn, shattered without a trace of humour by General Erinmore (Colin Firth) who drags the boys into his tent, delivers a thirty-second mission from hell and sends them on their way with the most unconvincing ‘good-luck'. This is all happening in one smooth, anxiety-inducing take, which is clearly divided into two, and made up of at least a dozen more, creatively smoothed into the fabric of the film by careful editing. A keen eye will spot them, such as when bodies fill the screen and the soldiers are briefly lost. This is by no means a slight of the film. It is not illegal to have more than one shot in your entire film, and making it feel like one breathless experience is an achievement on its own. In this regard, 1917 rightfully should be commended. It is a visual powerhouse. The problem is that the film is completely shackled by its impressive camerawork.

The opening really is terrific as the camera slowly stalks Blake and Schofield weaving through the impeccably designed trenches, festering with ghost-eyed soldiers hunkering down for brief solitude, writing letters, sleeping against each other with only rats for company.  A ticking drumbeat adds to the tension, Blake and Schofield exchanging glances, Blake anxiously pacing ahead, Schofield losing track of him in the swarm of bodies. Blake has a personal attachment to the mission with his brother part of the company that's due to assault German troops in the morning, 1,600 of them unknowingly heading into a brutal trap. It's a great start and it is unfortunate that these early scenes don't build to something better.

What is most disappointing about 1917 is that, for all its technical achievement and incredible recreation of no-man's land (astoundingly shot by Roger Deakins), it simply doesn't do enough to make you care about its characters. War is terrifying, and the landscape created by Mendes and Deakins here is convincing in depicting that terror, but only on a visual level. There's no significant attempt to explore the characters in depth, or really, anything else. The film is only concerned with getting from point A to B and literally showing the audience every step the characters took to get there. There's nothing wrong with that initially because the film always looks astonishing and for a while you do feel like it could be your hand plunging into the cavity of a rotting corpse. This is the immediacy that Mendes wanted his entire film to be. And it works for half-hour. After that, the bare-bones script becomes more pronounced than the head of a decaying horse, and each meticulously crafted scene starts to resemble strict events in an on-the-rails first-person shooting game. This artificial nature is made worse when you consider all the two-minute star cameos placed throughout.

For all its good work, there's no getting around that every frame of this film has been designed like an exhibit you pass through, barely letting you breathe before you're thrust forward to the next puddle of corpses. You're immersed in everything and feel nothing — even when bullets crack like thunder. Any tense encounter is preceded by the ticking drumbeat that accompanies Schofield all the way on his journey. Rather than have explosions burst from nowhere, there's always an expectation that something is about to happen because the music only kicks it when it does. It's counter-productive in the film's attempts to create a sense of total immersion. Schofield is never in real danger because the film necessitates that he keeps moving forward.

1917 adds up to a film that looks harrowing without ever feeling it. Locking the narrative directly onto the distressed face of George Mackay, who is very good and should go onto better things, the film requires you to feel invested in his character in order to succeed. If you are, that's great, it's as thrilling as Mendes intended. If you're not, you're immediately distanced from the film because there's nothing else to connect with.

Its proud insistence on pretending to be one shot is both the film's biggest strength and weakness. It creates intimacy at the same time it unfailingly distracts because the script has no choice but to serve the one-shot gimmick, and there was never a moment that I wasn't aware of this.

A visual achievement in filmmaking, that sacrifices plot and character development for gimmicky film and special effects.

Roger Deakins is once again in top form, while Thomas Newman's score for the most part is magnificant.

For the most part, the first half is gripping and believable, the second part however, descends into melodramatic cliches, and checks off the standard list of war film requirements.

In my review for "Dunkirk", the last narrative war flick I attended that is not a (certain) documentary, I had opened with explaining our general complicated relationship with the genre due to the gruesome nature and how a filmmaker make it a challenge to authenticate the storytelling process without any glamour except for the used techniques.

Since then, I find myself wanting to see a war film released consecutively each year like it has become a special theatrical tradition for that kind of narrative built up by compelling direction varied by different, award-winning filmmakers taking the challenging helm. So far, only three spiked in the mainstream radar, probably overshadowing hidden gems by their own debris, from Christopher Nolan's masterful visionary mask to Peter Jackson's innovative remastering. Sam Mendes arrives as a one-man third wave with what could be the genre's best technical marvel in "1917".

Straight forward and simplistic is better said than done as seen, heard and felt, all synergistically haunted by the war-ridden grounds, whereas two young British soldiers, Schofield and Blake, are given a mission to cross enemy territory to call off an attack that is instead marching into a trap. Hundreds of soldiers' lives are at stake, with Blake's brother among them, and the brave pair must race against time as the first World War heightens.

Each of the three war films, including "They Shall Not Grow Old", are great in their own significance defined by the aforementioned compelling direction each have as their defined technical marvel, and "1917" is the top experience. In terms of war horrors that are usually violently painted, the splatter was kept to a minimum, the casualties seemingly however went the farthest in presenting with just dry gore but still disturbingly graphic. Aside from the red taints on the battlegrounds, the elaborate settings required across the soldiers' mission made the production design amazing to the point of being immersive within the grounds while the taut cinematography, by Mendes' cinematographic collaborator Roger Deakins, is ultimately well-maneuvered to enable great editing to mask the total apparatus as one continuous shot.

The resulted vision of the finest craftsmanship that makes this war classic gritty and especially transportive is more a technical revelatory than just descriptively a marvel. It provokes a question on what the best formatted flow when telling a story. Being immersed completely is another way feeling emotionally trapped as we can actually empathize the tense emotions going through the onscreen soldiers' veins as they carefully trek across the battlegrounds behind enemy line. The "shot" never gets disrupted with a cut that would threateningly break the mental experience, and the editing to make it appear is very carefully placed like going through a minefield of ruining flaws. If the film was done in any other way with cuts, it would be a different experience, a different story, and total acceptance to watch it downsized.

When people watch films on any screen to the tiniest of their addictive mobile devices to their televisions to the big silver screen, they are downsizing the experience's initial value. "1917" is definitely one of those films that are best seen on the big screen otherwise the story is practically an equivalent to a veteran telling you a story in person. There is a required dimension for this kind of film and the freestyling comfort zone that a home provides, with accessible lighting, cannot guarantee the exact effect a theatrical experience provides. At the theater when you are not at home, the screen overshadows you, encasing you in darkness with the only light being the only window to the world via the screen. Sounds like having no choice but to survive in a war, or safely riding along the rough, bullet shells covered, blood-stained, dug-up terrain, guided by an excellent cast and their fantastic, well-driven performances.

Sam Mendes' "1917" is the best war film of the decade that has solidified my vote for Best Picture; and the only way to see it best is on the big screen while seeing it downsized means you have seen it and want to admire its filmmaking quality over and over again – not the topic or that would glamorizes the war that invited involuntary sacrifices. (A)

1917 was a masterpiece of cinema. I've seen a lot of war movies over the years, but never one so cleverly directed. As two young men are sent behind enemy lines to deliver an important, time sensitive message; you're right their with them, the camera working like a third man on the trek. The tension is intense, as you feel a sense of unease woven into every second of screen time. You never feel safe because the characters never feel safe.

The film does a great job capturing the reality of something like World War I. Our protagonists are not the best their squad has to offer. They're not specialists at anything. They're not hardened combat veterans. They don't have super powers. They're just two kids trying to stay alive against the odds. You genuinely don't know if they'll succeed or not, because ultimately, they're expendable and their lives don't really matter in the grand scheme of things. It could've been any random set of teenagers and when you realize that over the course of the film, the true horror of it all starts to set in. 

Sam Mendes avoids the wide shots you usually get in a war film, preferring to keep everything close in what appears to be one, continuous shot. You see what the boys see, which means you don't get to see the German soldier slightly offscreen plotting an attack ahead of time. You don't see the sniper in the window. Danger is everywhere, even in the quiet moments, and one bad move or staying in one place too long can get you killed. It's less about the scope of conflict and more about the effect it can have on the individual level. You can't help but put yourself in their shoes.

I sang the praises of Dunkirk when it came out, but this blows that film out of the water (no pun intended). It truly needs to be experienced on the big screen for maximum effect. It's so simple, but leaves such a big impact. What feels like hell to us is just another day on the front to them. 1917 has a staunch anti-war message, but it doesn't come from anything that's said. Just the feelings of pain, anguish, hopelessness, terror, loss, and grief conveyed by watching one of the most destructive and pointless conflicts in world history unfold as it happened. There is no glory to be had. There is no victory. Everything has a cost and the price usually isn't worth it. Showing the reality of war is all the anti-war propaganda you will ever need.

This is, in nearly every way, just a far inferior knock-off of "Saving Private Ryan". Worse plot, worse acting (who are these guys?), worse dialog, worse special effects. Over and over again, there were opportunities for an interesting turn to be injected into the movie, and they were passed on. For example, the initial discussion that set up the entire plot of the movie was extremely brief, and the potentially momentous bookend meeting at the end was not much longer and mostly devoid of any drama. The battle scenes were not particularly interesting. And whose fresh milk was in that bucket? I guess nobody cares. Finally, prior to watching the movie, I did not know about the fact that it is basically one long continuous shot. I think this has produced a lot of fascination around the movie... but not being aware of it as I watched, I realize now that I was subconsciously annoyed by it. It's kind of mentally exhausting, and places limits on the director's ability to do story-telling. In other words, there are very good reasons why Hollywood developed all kind of film-making conventions and shots - they make for better movies! Who makes videos that are just one long shot? Oh yeah, you or me, right before we post it on Youtube.

There are movies which are good, there are movies which great and then there are movies which are unforgettable. The latter are rare gems, which only come about when a strong story fuses with spectacular acting and exquisite cinematography. This is the case with 1917. The highlight of the movie is Roger Deakins cinematography which consists of the much admired one-shot take as well as stunning images of war horrors. 
Lets first address the one-shot take. It has been attempted several times in the past with mixed results, however this time (ignoring the waterfall scene) it works on multiple levels. Firstly, the camera moves similarly to a human, which feels familiar to the audience, making them part of the perilous journey. Secondly, cutscenes usually tend to divide the plot as well as give the viewer a break to catch their breath and collect their thoughts, similarly to blinking their eyes after staring too long. Here they are absent, which keeps the audience on their toes, unwilling to give them even a short break. Finally, although there obviously were cut-scenes throughout filming, the camera takes were 8-10 minutes long, thus the actors actually had to act throughout a longer period than normal. This includes physically demanding scenes, which could not feel more authentic, as the actors actually had to run for several minutes, making their fatigue incredibly plausible. 
Roger Deakins has a gift for making movie scenes resemble art. This is incredibly effective when depicting horror war scenes, as the viewer is confused whether he should admire them or be in shock. The burning town of Écoust is such an example- I could not help myself but marvel at the beauty of the burning church or the shadow-play during Schofield`s run. 
Concerning the actors, I myself became completely immersed in their story, they felt authentic and I was not troubled by the lack of backstory or character development. I concur with the tactic of having two relatively unknown actors, both of which perform superbly on the big stage, making me optimistic as to the future generation of actors. I could not however suppress a satisfactory smile whenever a cameo of an elite British actor occurred. These were sprinkled throughout the plot, grounding and entire story.
Finally there is the question of the score. I consider Thomas Newman to be up there with James Newton Howard, Patrick Doyle or James Horner. His score was prolific as well as emotional, however was in some parts perhaps too disturbing, attempting to magnify emotions which were already present in heaps.
In conclusion, 1917 is a technological marvel, something I have never witnessed on a big screen with a thrilling story, superb performances and an adequate score. It is rare for me to leave the cinema stunned by such a hyped movie, the only other case was Villenue`s Arrival.

Know this- even I know that my review matters a little when I am writing my review after, well, the Oscar results have been declared. But yeah, I think it might be a little too overrated. Well, that's not to say that '1917' directed by Samuel Mendes is a film that falls short of its ambition: strictly not! The film has palpable war scenes: with the most visual effects and eccentric action of the camera, the film becomes an unbecomingly immersive example of a true war film. If you need to look beyond the genuine depiction, there are beautiful emotional highs. Mendes' craft is excellent- he drives the film as it's invisible hero. 
But the storyline is simplistic, and the movie contributes in further simplifying these. 
That downbeats the film- and believe- it does, a LOT! But watch '1917' because it's scale and passion is what makes it a frequently organic film. Just don't go in for a deep plot.

On December 25th, the WWI film 1917 came to theaters with an exceptional opening and will likely go down as one of the best movies of the entire year due to not only a great story and incredible acting but some of the most interesting cinematography of any movie in recent memory. 

One of the largest draws to this movie was the news that it was filmed in a "single shot." This news is not technically true as the movie has dozens of shots but due to the thorough editing, the film appears to play continuously as if filmed in a single take. This allows for a smooth flow of action and plot. 

This film has a plot designed perfectly for this type of cinematography as it follows a journey by two friends tasked to save a group of soldiers that are following faulty information. The two friends, one of which has a brother in the endangered group, trek across no man's land and then enemy territory in an effort to rescue the company of soldiers.

This films cinematography, that focuses on following the main characters, is only possible with great acting by these main characters. George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman lead the movie and create likeable and deep characters. George MacKay's character, Lance Corporal Schofield, is one of the most impressive displays of acting talent during this film. MacKay effectively shows the deep brotherhood soldiers share when in similar situations and the lengths they'll go to in order to help one another.

The Oscar-nominated score for this film was created by Thomas Newman and brings to life many of the otherwise silent scenes in the movie. The score brings together classic war music and slower classical music to create uniquely slow but triumphic tones through the movie. Newman aimed to avoid writing music about the tone of the movie and aimed to instead bring life to the movie. Newman successfully accentuated the single take idea of the film by blending moods and created music that doesn't get tired as the film proceeds.

Overall, 1917 is a great film that has earned its six academy awards with a good balance of acting, directing, and musical skills.
