Absolutely incredible - I've seen it 3 times in cinemas and each time I find myself even more in awe of, blown away by, and in love with this film. It's thrilling, tense, gentle, satisfying, and deeply beautiful. As a huge fan of the war genre, this is unlike any other film I've ever seen - it finds its true strength in its unexciting, human moments rather than in the mindless chaos of firefights, while still managing to have some of the most exhilarating and edge-of-your-seat segments I've ever seen. Schofield is a brilliant and unconventional choice for the lead character, and his empathy and softness have made him one of my favourite characters of all time and an exceptionally rare example of how quiet tenderness truly can carry a war film better than loud banter and hyper-masculine bluster so often does. Krysty Wilson-Cairns is a genius and George Mackay said so much more in Schofield's silences than most actors could hope to in the grandest monologue. 

I also absolutely loved the ending - it was so brilliantly, purposefully anti-climactic and perfectly captured this feeling of helplessness, meaningless, and tragedy: Schofield had achieved his task, but next week a different order would come down and the men would still die, and he'd lost his best friend, ultimately, for nothing. If that doesn't encapsulate the pointlessness and futility of war, I don't know what does. A masterpiece. I'd watch a sequel/prequel about him in a heartbeat.

There are not many films about World War I. The most well-known ones are anti-war dramas: All Quiet on the Western Front (1930), Grand Illusion (1938), Paths of Glory (1957), Gallipoli (1981). On the surface 1917 is a well-done, thrilling action-war movie. It is also such an immersive and intense experience that without making any overt political statement it is firmly an antiwar film. It may be a good, thrilling movie but it is never exciting in the way an adventure movie is exciting. Even in the quiet moments 1917 makes you want to be as far away from this war as possible and hope another one like it never happens.

The plot is simple and very straightforward. Two young British soldiers are selected to deliver a message to a distant regiment calling off an attack the next morning. If the attack goes forward 1,600 soldiers, including the brother of one of the messengers, will charge into a trap. The encounters Corporals Blake and Schofield (Dean-Charles Chapman and Georgy MacKay) have as they make their journey across enemy territory are what you might expect from a story about soldiers on a mission: attacks from the enemy, crossing paths with another group of soldiers, finding shelter that is actually dangerous, even stumbling across a villager trying to care for a child. 1917 isn't a total onslaught to the senses for two hours though. There are respites here and there that allow us to get to know Blake and Schofield. There are some surprising cameos by well-known British actors along the way too (or unsurprising if you've seen the trailer or the cast list on IMDb). Fortunately, none of these cameos take you out of the movie (Andrew Scott and Mark Strong could slip comfortably into just about any movie).

Director Sam Mendes employs long takes and expert, precise cinematography by Roger Deakins and stealthy editing by Lee Smith to make the film look and feel as though it exists in one long unbroken shot. This gimmick works well for the movie when it is not distracting. In its successful moments the one-shot effect is largely responsible for the film's frantic, immersive effect. The climatic sequence of Schofield running like mad across the top of a trench as a battle begins to find the colonel to call off the attack makes excellent use of the one shot effect; it had me gripping the armrests of my seat. Also, the nighttime sequence in a bombed-out village where flairs illuminate the night with a bright, eerie white light and a fire rages in the distance is surreal and terrifying. Other scenes, however, like when a group of soldiers (and the camera) climb into the back of a truck, then get out to push the truck, then climb back in again feel like they are straining to keep the shot unbroken. Though I think there's nothing in 1917 that couldn't have been achieved with conventional editing, I understand why Mendes chose to present his film as a single unbroken shot. It puts us right there with the two soldiers and we are as unsure as they are of what will happen next.      

There are two consequences of using the one-shot/single-take gimmick in a war film. 1) Whether intentional or not, the one-shot effect, which keeps the camera right behind, or in front of, or over the shoulder of the characters, along with the nature of the story makes the film feel like a video game at certain times. This is not really a fault against the film. It is more likely due to video games being influenced by movies and then filtering back into the culture, but the comparison comes to mind nonetheless. 2) I think all of the focus and talk surrounding the one-shot effect actually diverts attention away from the harrowing experience of the characters in the film. 1917 has already won several awards and praise as a technical achievement (which it certainly is). I just hope people can get past the film's style to fully appreciate and experience the events on screen.

1917 only tangentially touches on the larger scale of the war. One character makes a background comment on the unimpressive patch of land they've been fighting the Germans over for years. Mendes chose not to focus on the politics of the war but instead tell the story of the enlisted men that fought in the trenches and in open fields. This movie is based in part on the experiences of Lance Corporal Alfred Mendes, Sam Mendes's grandfather, to whom the film is dedicated. Mends co-wrote the screenplay, his only writing credit. For all the unrelenting action in 1917, the final shot makes this an emotional and affecting movie.

While much has been said regarding 1917's achievements behind the camera, from its "one scene" structure to its astounding cinematography, I was pleased to find its technical feats in full service of its story. Director Sam Mendes' decision to limit the camera to "zero" cuts effectively forces audiences to remain with the films two young protagonists, no matter how bleak their journey becomes. 1917 is ultimately a triumph of cinematic storytelling; a sobering meditation on a generational loss of innocence and the true cost of war.

1917. It truly is more of an experience than anything and a testiment to the power that cinema has to create a vicarious experience with the viewer. Catch it in theaters because your home setup can't capture this type of immersion. This film felt like more of a technical achievement than an achievement in story, however. It is meant to be shown as one seamless cut (you can tell when the 'cuts' happen) so that you as the viewer feel like you are walking with these characters through hell every step of the way. It didn't hit high enough emotional soars for me like with other Oscar contenders this year, but I still really enjoyed the ride this movie takes you on. The soundtrack is also stellar and it's my new jam when I need to do work or study. Don't miss this movie in theaters because it is the best way to experience this WWI thriller. And it's Roger Deakins. You can't go wrong with his cinematography.

This film is remarkable for many reasons. The single-shot format is impressively executed, diligently mapped out so as to convince you that you're really there in a war zone, although there were apparently 50-ish cuts, much less impressive than Victoria, a truly single-shot German film that was actually nailed on the third try. I felt an emotional connection to the main characters, though I agree with ScreenRant that this element could have been strengthened by more character development. Better development would have made for more for the actors to latch on to as well, as many moments between them felt flat and unrehearsed. But the exhilarating pace of the movie, mixed with a genuine depiction of the horrors of war, the beauty of the human spirit, and some razzle dazzle cinematography (I bet 5 films a year use flares now, though not the JJ kind), all combine to make a thrilling film.

Fantastic Oscar winning type film..   Never seen a movie made this way that was one long story in what appears to be a single take...

This movie has a lot going for it. The most obvious of these was the cinematography. My husband and I talked about the fluidity of the scenes. Your eyes are fed so much visual information that you felt like you were making the run for the "Front," alongside the soldier. This was especially noticeable as he darted in, out, and through the various obstacles. The acting was quite good too, though not in the sense of notable lines. In fact, there was relatively little dialogue in this movie, yet it was extremely cathartic. Lastly, it was bookend by two fantastic actors, Colin Firth and Benedict Cumberbatch, who took important roles which, allowed the young actors with less name appeal to tell the story.

1917 was amazing! I think it depicted a very accurate picture of what war zones were truly like during WWI. Not to mention the set design was some of the most detailed I have ever seen. The directing and editing were perfect. Everything scene blended together seamlessly almost making it seem like the entire movie was done in one solid shot. I also really like that the acting was not consistent with the “every soldier is a hard ass” trope because I do not think that is what most soldiers during WWI were like at all. I think this choice of action provided viewers with a more human view of soldiers (seeing as that is what they are) because most soldiers were simply trying to do what was right and survive. Overall, this was one of the most perfect movies I have seen in my entire life.

Expertly directed and viscerally thrilling, 1917 is one of the best films of the year and one of my favorite war movies ever. Director Sam Mendes brings you right into the trenches of WWI, focusing on two British soldiers who are tasked with getting through occupied territory to warn another British company that the attack they are planning is a trap. There is a scene in a river that is particularly effective, as one of the protagonists experiences just about every emotion you could imagine: panic, desperation, fear, calm, horror, and, finally, relief. The audience goes right along for the ride. It's a wonderful film.
Kept you in the edge of your seat.

Beautifully shot movie; no wonder the cinematography is nominated for an Oscar. In fact, this movie is nominated for numerous Oscars. Out of all the war movies I have seen, 1917 has one of the most real depictions of gunfights, trauma, and just the atrocities of war. It tells a tale that ends in two different ways and makes us question if the journey we endured was truly worth all the trouble. Then we realize the lives saved and a simple "Thank You" mean so much at the end. We are a part of this journey with our main characters, we are able to feel the stress of war and the danger that can come from anywhere at any time. This is heightened by the amazing score in this movie. Adding so much to every scene that it is a part of. Truly a movie I won't soon forget.

It's interesting that 1917 is not just a Dreamworks production, but an Amblin one too. Much more than Dunkirk, 1917 feels like a compliment to Saving Private Ryan, and, if you'll pardon the obvious connection, a brother film to it. While Spielberg houses Saving Private Ryan in a groundbreaking, bombastic and terrifying shell to shock a reminder to the world of the sacrifices made in recent history to afford us our freedom and complacency, 1917 is a love letter to those who never gave up, and enlisted a purity of spirit to see their missions to their end. And like Saving Private Ryan, Sam Mendes does this with no less bravura and potency.

In many ways, despite the comparisons, 1917 is the antithesis of Dunkirk, a film that is more of an exercise than a cinematic experience, one that strains the limits of its medium in a different way, a finely tuned watch turned out and rearranged in front of you, and with a sadistic and pervading intent to accost and unbalance you immediately and not let go until the final moments.

1917, however, goes out of its way to show you the linearity and simplicity of its thrust; the trenches, such as they were designed to be, are the perfect proof of concept to get the audience on board and lulled to this new version of cinema presentation with the long takes. The film takes the time to show you the world through environmental storytelling (not the first time in this review I'll reference video games!) and whereas Gravity put its bland characters and dialogue front and centre, 1917 carefully uses the extra characters and dialogue as a subconscious layer or normality, to draw you in to a hypnotic trance as Deakins' camerawork and lighting slowly pulls out of the faces of the leads their grief or exhaustion, wracked with unimaginable thoughts we are blessed never to have to think. 

And as such, and due to its vibrant camera work and unstuffy photography, it doesn't feel twee or old at all. The approach of ensuring 1917 didn't feel rote or samey and instead feel exceptionally present and modern and human also allows it to be relatable and less of an archive document and more resonant to now. 

Many of Deakins' shots are incredible. In fact almost all of them are, not content with stitching multiple long takes together, Mendes/Deakins et al have crafted a million moving paintings. And the long takes are a thing of beauty; a few conveniently placed rocks or cuts to black in the cloth of someone's back notwithstanding, this is the absolute best I've seen this kind of technology and approach being used. It's a far cry from the awkward shoehorning of some of Birdman's obvious cuts and even pips Cuaron's Children of Men for most impactful use of long takes. 

This is most felt in moments of real loss. The camera, lingering there as we know it will, injected into me a deep sadness at the normality of death, the general lack of significance or theatricality. The acting then benefits greatly from these long takes, the characters feeling like they are ebbing and flowing physically and emotionally towards and away from us as if we're running to keep up with a busy friend, afraid we'll lose them. As they draw away they seem to emotionally retreat into themselves, and when we're gifted a close up, it's such a palpable and tacit moment that it eclipses theatre (the medium compared to 1917 most in early interviews) by proving us with the heartbreaking simplicity of looking into another‘s face. Mark Strong acts up a treat in the small part he's in and he's an enigmatic and welcome role and one that proves he can still act beyond generic villains with unconvincing American accents. 

1917 owes a great debt to video games; the walking simulator, the first person shooter and the stealth game. Certain moments feeling like they are ripped directly from video games; the tense barren walk listening for gunfire or footsteps, twitch finger on the trigger ready for when that enemy rounds the corner in Call of Duty, will you shoot or flee? Or those moments of respite and story in Metro, between the gunfire and struggle, as you wander through an enclave of survivors, or silently taking down an enemy as you spin the camera around to see if his mate can see you in his cone of vision. All these moments are fresh and immediate in a way that's missing from something like Dunkirk. However, I don't think that's the only reason for this, I think that using much more of a recognised first person perspective approach mirrors the diaries and letters and journals chronicling World War I and so 1917 manages to be authentic my borrowing from a very modern medium and arches backwards by reaching forwards.

I'm intrigued why, besides in order to advance the timeline, that Mendes chose to put that single obvious cut in the film. And I'm not sure I liked or needed the subtitles, it pulled me right out of the experience and reminded me I was watching a film and it served little purpose, especially because the French was designed to be simple and he didn't really understand it anyway. I'm reminded of Polanski and his one regret with Chinatown when he wished he'd put the image on a camera lens upside down as it would have been in real life but for studio pressure he relented and put it the incorrect way for clarity. I wonder if Mendes would look back on this the same way.

But that notwithstanding the film is close to flawless. And despite being half an hour longer than Dunkirk, it doesn't feel it and I wouldn't have taken anything out. Interestingly it must have been tight and bold screenplay to allow for almost no wiggle room and little retiming. I guess that's Mendes' theatre experience kicking in. The film is full of little moments but they are the most meaningful parts. In some slim ways I thought Tarkovsky may be proud of it, and I had partial and welcome Stalker and Andrei Rublev flashbacks.

The film is essentially about you and this soldier. And how much you really connect with him is a testament to how earned and fist-pumping the more (brief) saccharine moments are. There's a close up towards the end of the film and I felt as if I could read the characters mind and I was completely urging him to make the decision I knew he would make anyway. That's powerful stuff and a feeling I never really get in cinema very much anymore.

Those moments are swept up, bolstered, underscored or otherwise lifted by Thomas Newman's incredible score. Newman, not a stranger to iconic, recognisable and listen-to-able scores manages to do the impossible (for him) and creates a powerful score that doesn't immediately sound like his work. It's a score that tells all that's missing in a scene without the film having to resort to exposition. It's not an an obvious score until it wants to be. And it's a world away from Zimmer's now predictable cacophony even though it sometimes scantily resembles it in places.  

There was a moment in the film, a very deliberate moment of drama and arch-power when I realised what an aural and visual treat this movie was. It was like being on the stage of an opera; it was grandiose and energetic and flamboyant and iconic and at the centre was this small figure running through what for many could have been their afterlife. This "afterlife" moment felt like adrenaline itself; not shock, just awe; danger, fragility, beauty and purity. I have never wanted a moment in a movie, without realising it, more. It was cinematic bliss. Good job 1917. My day started and I was at work. But by the end of it, I was exactly where I wanted to be.

Sinceramente? Achei só bonzinho. É inegável que a realização está excelente e realmente nos transporta para o espaço e momento em que a história ocorre, cumprindo o ambicioso propósito de mostrar uma ação contínua ao logo de grande parte do filme. Gostei da interpretação do protagonista, também. Acho que esteve competente e transmitiu uma certa empatia, apesar do aparente carácter frio do personagem. No entanto, sinto que faltou alguma coisa num filme desta extensão. Não posso dizer que tenha sido entediante, porque não foi, prendeu-me o suficiente ao longo dos seus 115 minutos, no entanto a história não me cativou por aí além. Tudo o que me cativou veio essencialmente da componente técnica da conceção do filme e que me deixava continuamente curioso para ver como iriam apresentar a ação em seguida (a história por si só não me deixava minimamente interessado em saber o que ia acontecer depois).

Vou dar 6,8 / 10 - Gostei da premissa a que o filme se propôs e o filme desenvolveu-a bem tecnicamente falando, mas esperava "sentir" um pouco mais com este filme e acabei por ficar com a sensação de que estava não a ver um filme dramático/histórico, mas uma espécie de documentário execionalmente executado.

Full voice conversations about drivel while traversing enemy territory, assuming a high comfort level in the enemys barracks cave, etc.  Had they secured the enemy combatants weapon after helping him from the burning wreckage likely would have saved two lives. Perhaps military training at the turn of the last century was lacking? Perhaps research for the movie was lacking?

1917 is a thriller about two soldiers who are given a message that they must deliver before 1,600 men get ambushed and killed. We follow these men on their odyssey in what appears to be one continuous shot but was actually edited to look like such. Either or way it's a technical achievement and the cinematography by Roger Deakins is incredible. There are shots form this film I will never forget. This film had me gripped from start to finish and it is the best film Sam Mendes has made since American Beauty from 1999. This is going to win a lot of awards and accolades and the awards and accolades are well deserved.

Mendes presents us with an extraordinary, visionary depiction of a specific time in our history which was defined by an incredible darkness & societal stress. All of the appropriate & unfortunate feelings & concepts transcend the screen & saturate the viewers psyche throughout the immersive, non-stop experience. The director does an amazing job of providing the viewer with a sense of excruciatingly precise timing during the journey. Each & every moment, decision & interaction carries its own weight which contributes to the culminating, climactic flourish in the films final scenes. The tension, anxiety & suspense of this masterpiece literally permeate the entire atmosphere of the theater from beginning to end. Finally, the experience gains a last bit of relevance to resonate with the audience as the credits prepare to roll.. the director's paternal grandfather was directly involved in the historical happenings. Well done, Sam Mendes. Thank you for sharing your vision.

This movie has most definitely reached expectations with its cinematography if not, maybe it has even exceeded it. The shots were mind numbing almost all throughout. Well, sometimes. The point is,  the one shot feels like a fucking gimmick and it just might've turned out better if this movie was made the traditional way so the scenes that drag out too long don't drag at all. The movie didn't quite succeed in creating great characters. Although George Mackay and Dean-Charles Chapman performed very well with the roles they were given, I still found myself lacking a hint of rapport with their characters. This movie, as I watched it, did feel like it was being carried a bit by the cinematography-- not to say that the whole oneshot was a gimmick, as there was definitely a lot of artistic integrity behind it. The movie is certainly a memorable experience, and one of the good war films I've seen in a while; but for me, it does not fall into becoming one of the classics.

I found 1917 to be a mostly effective war movie, uniquely shot and well written and acted. The best thing about it for me was the extraordinary amount  of mis-en-scene happening in the background of every shot. At least one of our two main characters are center frame for most of the movie as the camera follows them through a grimy, bloody, war torn country, and the detail really makes the movie. Whether they are wading through mud with bodies impacted into it, traveling through the crowded trenches of the front lines filled with soldiers, or darting through a demolished city at night with flares occasionally lighting up the sky and the German army in hot pursuit, the detail in the settings and the costumes really pulls you into the film.

The same can be said of the camera work and the one take style employed by the director, although here is where the film seemed a bit uneven to me. It was undoubtedly ambitious for director Sam Mendes to commit to the one take style, and for the most part, it was captivating watching the action unfold I real time. There were some quite astonishing sequences, including the apparent live crash landing of a German plane into a barn where the main characters had been standing moments ago. There were also parts where the fanciness of the camerawork was distracting. I found myself wondering how they could have set up the camera to float continuously over a pond or pirouette through the narrow hallways of a German bunker, which, while cool, takes away somewhat from the somberness of the subject matter. Finally, there were a couple of panning shots where the digitization wasnt quite right and leads to some graininess that bumped me from the movie for a time.

Still, even the flaws are worth going to see the film, its an engrossing cinematic experience. I imagine a second viewing might make it better now that the novelty of the film making has fully sunk in, I might have to seek it out again in the future.

1917 is possibly the best war film of the last decade. It is a visual masterpiece. The single shot style is masterfully executed, the sets and costume design are gorgeous, soundtrack is beautiful and the acting superb. The film is filled with historical errors, from the overall plot to smaller things like post war German helmets being worn. But most of these flaws can be brought back to the needs of the style of the film, such as having heavy artillery only about 100 metres behind the front line, a necessary flaw in a single shot film, unless they wanted to make it go for ten hours as the characters travel back kms to the guns. This is simply one of the few films where the historical errors can be ignored in order to enjoy the experience of the drama. Overall this is an absolute must see film.

This movie about loyalty, bravery, and perseverance beyond measure kept me on the edge of my seat.  It was brilliant.  The fact that it was filmed in virtually one take is mind-boggling.  How did they do it?  It made me feel like I was part of the movie, not just watching it.  I was a bit worried about the level of violence that would be in it because I have a hard time with "Saving Private Ryan - type" movies but although there were a lot of dead bodies and animals as well as battles and death (it IS a war movie), the actual portrayal of violence was left to the imagination for the most part.  There also were very few curse words and no sex.  All of this proves that an amazing movie can be made without graphically exposing the viewer violence, sex, and language.  It was a superior movie that I highly recommend.

Not since All Quiet on the Western Front has there been a greater World War I movie than 1917. The film's famous one shot is absolutely brilliant, seemingly unedited and delivering the best angles at any given time. The production design is spectacular, the score is suitably intense, the acting is so strong and underappreciated, the direction is amazing, and some of the imagery here, especially the fire scene, felt truly artistic. But the movie is so much more than just this unprecedented technical achievement. It is a film about brotherhood and friendship, it's downright heartbreaking in some scenes and its most impressive achievement is how it was conceptualized as an immersive adventure film and an exciting video game. The ending is emotional, the night sequence is incredibly suspenseful and the abandoned barracks scene is unforgettable in its entirety. Consequently, Sam Mendes here directed his magnum opus and one grand war picture for the ages.

Wonderful, beautiful display of filmmaking prowess, with the sole weakness of little to no characterization. (Spoilers ahead) I found it difficult to connect to characters when they were portrayed from the beginning as one dimensional, particularly in the case of the jaded, recalcitrant protagonist who ends up taking the movie to its conclusion. The audience is given very little sense of who he is as a person before he becomes the one we're supposed to be rooting for. This made it difficult for me to cheer for him outside of "do it for your deceased comrade who I felt more empathetic to!" However, it has been said before and I will gladly say it again: in terms of cinematography, this movie is a masterpiece. I had heard that it was a lumiére-style movie and thus from the beginning I was on the edge of my seat trying to find all the hidden cuts, and ready to criticize the camerawork within an inch of its life. However, not only was the editing seamless, but the camerawork, the set, the tasteful film score, and pretty much every aspect of the film simply absorbed you into it and by the half hour mark I had mostly forgotten my quest to find mistakes in favor of gripping the seat in front of me as I watched the story unfold with baited breath. Of course, the outcome was rather obvious from the beginning, but how would it be achieved? What obstacles would present themselves? These were the questions that unraveled before us in incredibly satisfying fashion, with delightful pacing and excellent cinematography. I appreciated, also, that blood and gore was utilised sparingly, only insofar as was needed to show the horror of the characters' experience and the nature of the war they were fighting. During one scene in particular, where the character paused to look with muted shock upon the face of a dead man, I fully expected the camera to pan to show his face to the audience, and was pleasantly surprised when this wasn't the case. The director was sensitive enough to understand that we only needed to see the protagonist's reaction to know what kind of scene he was looking at. Knowing what elements of shock were and weren't necessary paid off largely with this war film. 4/5 stars!

Let's start out with this. It is a visual masterpiece. You can almost see the hard work that the actors, set crew, and camera operators had to go through.
I think that this movie is rather unique in the war movie genre because, other than other war movies (Saving Private Ryan, for example), this movie relies on the deafening silence that happens between these scenes of cold-blooded battles to get the emotions of the audience flowing, whereas other war films rely on the brutal battles that are fought. There isn't too much dialogue in the second act of the movie and the film relies on how the characters are reacting to these problems that they are faced with and their emotions that convey the true weight of these events, at hand.
Another aspect of this movie that I find rather pleasing is the ability to capture the claustrophobic horrors in the trenches, to the vastly open fields of this grand traverse that moves us from scene to scene. Another good thing that comes to mind is this movie's ability to build up suspense in every set piece if there will be a grand event or not.
Of course, I love the one-shot look of the movie and, they are right, it does, sort of,  immerse you into this bleak-desolate world that was German-occupied France in 1917.
Overall, exceptional WW1 movie. We all deserve to learn about the brave men on the front lines and beyond.

A fantastic, gripping and absorbing masterpiece, 1917 finds Sam Mendes and everyone involved on the top of their games. The single shot feel of the film could easily be thought of as a gimmick but Mendes uses it to its full potential giving the audience a real feel of the dizzying, sickening nature of war, especially experienced by people so young. The cinematography itself is amazing as we trudge through beautiful and harrowing wastelands urging the protagonists to make it out alive. You will not think about anything outside of the film whilst watching, it truly is an incredibly impressive piece of work.

One of the most overrated movies in existence, Sam Mendes horribly pretentious personal-vanity project sports astounding merits in cinematography and absolutely positively NOTHING ELSE. 

Where to begin in terms of the film's flaws?  From the preposterous storyline, the well-groomed soldiers (which conveys anything but the horrid conditions of trench warfare), the nationalistic propaganda which reinforces the tired "barbaric German" stereotype, the abundance of overused war-movie clichés (which includes an obligatory encounter with a French peasant woman and her newborn baby), and the turgid and simplistic screenplay (which easily qualifies as one of the worst of the century), 1917 reflects the sheer epitome of style-over-substance.

Furthermore, the film's narcissistic self-importance oozes through each and every frame, further reflected by the title, the all-too-direct implication of which loudly proclaims, "Sure, there are other war movies out there. But this one is the true embodiment of the First World War!"

People call this film "The Birdman of WWI" and to be fair that is a justified assessment. This entire film is filmed like it is one camera shot and it is AWESOME! think one of the most impressive thing apart from the one looking shot is the AMAZING CINEMATOGRAPHY. This shouldn't be no surprising since it is the legend himself Roger Deakins (Blade Runner 2049 Cinematographer). Every scene feels like a painting and it is absolutely stunning. There is a scene at night where the lighting was done in such a creative way that heighten the tension of the scene. On that note there must also be praise for the score by Thomas Newman who somehow manages to make a score that somehow manages toe elevate every scene and help tell the story. There is also some amazing sound design that manages to make the War actually scary with moments that give horror movie jump scares a run for its money. Additionally, the props and set design should also get praise for creating such large,realistic but elaborate sets to accommodate for a more natural one shot scene. Everything in this film just feels like a technical achievement. We haven't even touched on the acting or story yet but just for the way this was filmed is already engaging enough. Nevertheless, the two main actors George MacKay as Lance Corporal William "Will" Schofield and Dean-Charles Chapma as Lance Corporal Thomas "Tom" Blake manages to do a phenomenal job in showing the horror of war and giving authentic,believable characters. The story, while relatively simple, is engaging enough to keep you invested in the objective of the main characters. They must send a message to allies stop them running into a trap. It's simple but works well for the aim of one shot as now it makes the audience a part of the journey.

There isn't much negative to this movie but I guess if I have to be quite nitpicky it is the fact that halfway through the movie there is a obvious cut. So this movie is actually really a two shot film. The cut was necessary to make the situation more desperate and allow for a unique change in scenery even though it was a bit of a jarring cut. Another sort of nitpick is that we don't really get much info on the main characters. We get their names and we know what their mission is but their backstory is just given in tidbits. It goes in a Dunkirk route in which we care about these characters because of the situation they are in rather than the fact that we are invested in the characters. It can be argued that the tidbits more than gives you enough info about the characters but it's really up to the audience in the end. Personally, I don't find it too much of a fault but can see how others could consider it so.

Honestly my negatives are just nitpicks. This movie is amazing and it is definitely worth watching right now.

The only word I can possibly use for 1917 is Phenomenal. Full disclosure: I am not a fan of war movies for the most part. For the most part, war movies have all the emotional components of movies (death, suffering, explosions, survival, grief, etc.) in overwhelming amounts. While there were these components in 1917, it did not distract from the story. It did so well keeping a strong focus on the plight of the two main characters. Remarkably, might I add. This film also highlighted a key characteristic of the soldiers who fought in WWI - their age. There was no doubt that the men in the trenches and on the battlefronts were considerably young. All in all, this is a must see.

The acting is fine but nothing outstanding. The plot is very simple, and there isn't much action but a lot of the film is full of suspense. The set, costumes, and practical effects were all great but some of the CGI (such as when the main character jumps into water) could have been better. The main character should have died if the German soldiers didn't have Stormtrooper aim - he was running in straight lines half the time and instead of the German's stopping to shoot, they were running after him... Spectacular! It was riveting, tense, and the most singularly visceral war movie I may have ever seen. It was a cinematographic tour de force. What could have been a gimmick of single-take shot, instead provided incredible verisimilitude and for the first time I could begin to imagine what trench warfare might have been like in WWI. The score by Thomas Newman was propulsive and as much or greater part of the film all around, but FWIW, my pulse was still racing thirty minutes later in the lift on the way up to our apartment. I highly recommend seeing this in the theatre, even if war movies aren't your thing.

1917 is one of the best war movies of the past decade. The most notable aspect of 1917 is Roger Deakins' masterful cinematography. The film is comprised of long cuts seamlessly stitched together to create the appearance of being one continuous take. It feels as though the journey is unfolding in real time. The camera is immersed in the action, as if from the perspective of a third soldier, which makes it even more visceral and real.

I never write reviews on movies or anything else for that matter, regardless of if it was good or bad. However, after watching 1917, I felt compelled to in some small fashion pay my thanks to the men and women who created this incredible film. The acting, cinematography, directing, writing and composing where all superb, and I want to thank everyone involved for the hard work and dedication that went into producing such a moving piece of art. 
You're sucked into the adventure right off the bat and all the one-shot scenes allows the viewer to step into the shoes of the characters -- you're restricted to only their world, showing how devastating, gruesome, and emotional war can be. 
I sincerely hope to see more masterpieces such as 1917.

I don’t want to oversell this movie, but I’m not entirely sure that would even be possible. 1917 grabbed my attention from the very first scene! The director chose to follow the actors with one camera and one continuous shot...it felt like the entire movie was one enormous theatrical play. Without changing cameras or camera angles, they had to be very creative with where they would take their breaks. Some of the scenes felt like 20 minutes or more, without stopping. That aspect alone, made it feel like you were in the trenches with the cast. It was perfectly timed like a dance that had been rehearsed a million times, yet also had an improvised feel, due to the fact that they just kept moving. I feel like any mistakes that happened during the filming, which there had to be at least a few, were covered by these very well prepared actors and it only helped make it appear more authentic. They depicted World War I with such detail, they really gave the audience an very comprehensive education. It was a great story and it was extremely tense. There were surprises around every corner. Again, from start to finish, this movie was an amazing attention grabber. 1917 is an epic film, in the truest sense of the word and a definite must see! If you’re tired of CGI and you like character driven movies with a good story and great acting, you won’t be disappointed with 1917.

My only complaint is incredibly minor and is due to only to a few distracting support cameos, from the first one which had me wondering if Colin Firth's uniform is too tight or if he has gained weight, to the final distraction of Cucumberpatch. Even his final line when he swears it is almost humorous and thus difficult to see him as the frustrated colonel he is playing.

This is a hypnotic film which had me on the edge of my seat for the entire length of it. The story unfolds in a single scene, in real time, among the ruins of a WWI battle field in Europe. Two soldiers must convey a message to another unit cut off from communication, warning them of danger should they launch a planned attack. I think the film works so well because of the way that it strips everything down to the simplest elements of storytelling. You can't wait to see what happens next and there are no gimmicks or feints. Of course, that could be seen as a gimmick itself.

🌺 And my personal favourite candidate for Best Picture, as I had predicted!! In 1917, during World War I, two British soldiers are assigned to race against time and deliver a message that will stop 1,600 men, from walking straight into a deadly trap. An intense war movie like any other that takes its audience 100 years back into the horror that men experienced in that terrible affair. This immersive, unnerving and nightmarish story was only possible due to the ambitious technical achievements in cinematography, production design and directing by Roger Deakins, Dennis Gassner and Sam Mendes, respectively.The daunting score of Thomas Newman deserves some praise as well as the main leads who convinced us of the courage and tenacity of the main characters. It keeps you on the edge of your seat, fearing for the safety of the soldiers and reminding us all the time that war is the worst thing that can happen to humanity, a bloody spectacle with no purpose other than causing trauma or death.

1917 was a gripping movie, with a huge cast but only two main characters that were followed throughout the movie. The movie is about the constant heroism and perseverance of the two men tasked with delivering a message to a distant military unit. The message was to inform the leader of the unit of the orders of the military higher-ups to cancel an attack against the Bosch (Germans) because it was a set up as an ambush which could result in the death/injury of 1600 men. This is not a spoiler because similar comments appear in reviews. The dialogue gave me a bit of trouble understanding the British accent of the men, but all in all it was a well played movie about the hell the WWI doughboys went through. Somewhat graphic war scenes, but the overarching emotion for me was the heroism of the two men to continue onward at all cost. 

The plot included character development, visuals of the trenches and the terrible mud impeding progress, sights of no man's land, the horror of the maimed and dead and a constant following by the camera of the two men as they struggled to complete the mission. It felt like we were there. 

1917 is a movie worth seeing to try to understand how much suffering war can bring to the opposing combatants.

The Sam Mendes' 1917 has been winning rave reviews from both critics and audiences for it's dazzling technical expertise and ultra-graphic depictions of the horrors of the First World War. When it comes to showing combat from the point of view of the front-line soldier, it does indeed capture the experience of mud, blood and sudden death as convincingly as any war movie since Saving Private Ryan, from which this film is clearly derived. But for a movie that is touted as being as realistic as all get-out, the details and premise of 1917 manage to utterly ignore the simplest realities of modern warfare  and basic common sense. 
The story is about two British lance corporals who are given what we are to understand is a very dangerous, probably fatal mission: to carry orders to a Colonel, ordering the latter to call off his regiment's attack  on the Germans, because the High Command has learned that the German position is too strong to be taken, and the attack will be a massacre (also, and purely by coincidence, the brother of one of the couriers is serving in the doomed regiment.) The Germans have withdrawn to new positions, and the Colonel believes this indicates that they are ready to break if attacked, so he has advanced into the zone the Germans have evacuated, and is now isolated from the remainder of the British Army. This attack is planned for dawn the following day, but the orders cannot given by field telephone, because the Germans have cut the telephone wires. They will only need to travel  nine miles, through an area that the Germans have evacuated, but one of the corporals is sure they will need to start right away, although they must have more than 12 hours to complete the mission. 
 There are so many things wrong with this that it is difficult to know where to start. First of all, if the Germans have indeed pulled out, why does everyone, from the general down, act as if the 2 corporals are on a suicide mission? Why did the Germans cut the telephone wire after they abandoned their old lines, and for that matter how, if their soldiers were gone? Why can't the British just repair the broken telephone line? Surely that would be faster and easier than sending couriers, who will probably be killed and thus fail to deliver the orders. Since the general knows exactly where and when the regiment will be attacking, we must assume he received this information from the Colonel.  So, if the Colonel (a waste of the talented Benedict Cumberbatch) is attacking without authorization, (more on this momentarily), as is implied, why wasn't he ordered to cancel his attack when he told the general about it in the first place? 
The filmmakers clearly believe that consistency is for petty minds, and they cannot be bothered with anything so trivial.  Again, even though almost the first thing we are told is that the enemy has pulled out, the couriers somehow keep finding Germans to shoot at them.  At one point, one of the corporals encounters a British truck convoy headed toward his destination. So why couldn't the general send the messengers in a car, or give them to a motorcycle courier? It is hard to imagine a reason, and the writers do not even try. 
But these are just a few of the minor holes in the contrived script. Even more serious is the way the screenwriters and director (the latter bears most of the blame, since he approved this brainless script,) blithely display their complete ignorance of the scale and operations of armies in the Twentieth Century in general, and the First world War in particular, in the film's premise. 
The British  regiment in question, we are told, consists of 2 battalions of 1600 men each. We supposed  to believe that the Colonel thinks he can defeat a German army which had  somewhat more than  4 million men. Unless the Colonel was actively psychotic, he would understand that his regiment  could not accomplish by itself, even if I could break through the German lines (which it could not.)
This bring us to another sore point: the chain of command. Colonel was (and is) not a particularly high rank in an army of millions, and he is not any sort of free agent. At a minimum,  over him would be the Brigadier General commanding his brigade, a Major General in charge of the division, a Field Army commander, (a Lieutenant General or higher) and the Commander in Chief (or Chief of the General Staff,) a full General or Field Marshal  Without authorization from above, no Colonel still in possession of even a handful of his marbles would think about attacking the Germans with his lone regiment, and if he was crazy enough to try it, he would be relieved of command and committed to an asylum.
Finally, even the details, which we are told are so very realistic, are falsified for cinematic effect. The climactic battle sequence (which was supposed to happen at dawn, but clearly is starting much later) as shown completely loses touch with reality. The Germans start shelling the British trenches the moment the attack starts, as if they had the schedule.  The hero runs across the deadly bombardment, with soldiers dropping everywhere around him, while he, quite unbelievably, remains untouched. We supposed to be watching a Company attack, roughly 100 men (attacking a Company at a time is even more ludicrous than idea of the one-regiment offensive,) but we see hundreds of extras leaping up out of the trenches to be slaughtered, a  battalion, at least. This of course, is because a company size attack would look puny and unimpressive, so forget about consistency.  And although we witness what appears to be the destruction of the entire attacking force, it seems that when they return (and seems to happens in the blink an eye, after the Colonel reads the order,) there are a fair number of wounded men  being brought back, but most of them seem to be unhurt. Yet, we saw them drop like flies when they went over the top just a few minutes before.
While 1917  is acclaimed for showing the truth about World War One, all it truly shows is how little respect director Sam Mendes has for the facts, and how easy it is for a fraud like this film to pass itself off as history.

This can't even be classified as a movie or film- it's an experience. I saw it in theatres after only seeing a few short trailers and hearing lots of hype, and wow! You don't even need to see it in IMAX, yet I'm sure it's even more immersive, if that's possible. 
This movie is a technical wonder, and it pulls it off perfectly. Roger Deakins and Sam Mendes' hard work paid off here. I think I was most impressed with Écoust at night, the lighting was done only by flares, yet I could still see what was happening in the movie (unlike a certain show that starts with G and ends with ame of Thrones). The one-shot felt smooth, immersive, and the script never seems to drag, another shoutout to Mendes and Krysty Wilson-Cairns. 
The acting was also phenomenal too. George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman are outstanding. Blake and Schofield are both the heart of the film, and I was very impressed with Schofield's character development, and George MacKay's performance. Also nice to see Andrew Scott, Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, and Richard Madden in the mix. 
Please see this movie in any way shape or form. No matter if you're in the theater or on the couch, you'll be amazed.

The sheer amount of time I sat, grabbing at my bag of cookies, eyes straying across the screen in hopes to recollect the brimming emotions I felt from this immaculate piece, was, to say the least, welcomed. 

I was prepared before going in. As it is rated-R, I expected the violence and the F-bombs. While I don't swear myself and am against it, this sat with me fine as in the place, time and situation, it makes perfect sense for the realism you feel. The violence wasn't nearly as bad as I was expecting and I was pleasantly surprised they didn't need tons of it for added shock value. 
There is a certain kind of beauty in silence. I explain this to others often, but a movie doesn't need narration. Someone doesn't need to always be talking. This movie made you absorb the atmosphere of quiet. It forced you to linger on mere emotions, expressions and desperation. And, if not silence, the eerie booms and bangs penetrates your being and serves as a reminder of the husk of war. The amount of unsurety that spills into a bountiful amount of determination that is seen through the film is breathtaking. 

Any thoughts that coax the urge to look back fade a way and all there is left is to press forward. 

And, besides the story, the cinematography was staggering. I've never felt both horrified and enthralled like this at once. Everything I watched was a disaster, but I was sure that I was watching shooting stars fly by and manipulate the shadows around the main soldier. As if making wishes on bullets and bombs was the resort one should take. 
This movie, is, without a doubt, something to behold and envelope. Your emotions will go from the slightest of laughs, to the largest of anger and fear, to just wallow in sorrow of events that occurred.

For instance the main character goes thru holy hell most of the movie including almost drowning in a raging river and at the end pulls out  a still readable letter to a commanding general and an unscathed photo of his wife and kids.

I can't hardly put into words how fantastic this movie was.  From the non-stop filming with seemingly no breaks, to the surreal landscape, and how you fall for the character.  Our theater was no-seats-left packed on a Tuesday and not a single person said a word throughout. It was amazing.

WWI happened a hundred years ago and doesn't get the constant attention that WWII does in the movies. 1917 brings the trench warfare of WWI to life in a way that I have never seen before. A  drama based on factual events and set in a time period that has receded from memory.. The interaction of the characters and the wartime scenery enhance the captivating story. Very well done it offers a look into the irrationality of war while infusing the human element of those who are caught up in the events of war. 1917 pays homage to those soldiers who were part of this era of history and who didnt sacrifice their humanity to the madness of war..

1917 is brilliant, we're right with the characters in their mission to cross over into enemy territory to deliver a message that could potentially save 1,600 of their fellow men, including Blake's own brother. Sam Mendes' choice to make this film one continuous shot brings you into the story of our two main characters, Lance Corporal Blake and Lance Corporal Schofield. You root for them, you worry about their safety, and you care about them. This film relies heavily on the performances of George Mackay and Dean-Charles Chapman. They both give fantastic performances. What else is there to say about the cinematography of Roger Deakins just watch Blade Runner 2049 for which he won an Oscar and should be awarded for his work in this film as well. Shout out to Thomas Newman's beautiful score. I can't get enough of it

The moment they gets the order and comes out of the tent and Thomas Newman's score comes (ting ding tding tding)my god😦😨😱🥶, heart just starts pumping like lamborghini's engine , it never takes a rest until the baby scene comes(just one scene in the movie which a little bit sense of relaxation) and then again untill the movie ends, you never rests, the night chase scene is really beautiful , the whole movie cinematography(Roger Deakins's) (gives you chill down the spine 🤯😨😱🥶),Newman's score exhilarating, you just becomes the third person like you are with them, It's Beauty is unexplainable, (just take every award and give it to 1917 (except for the Best actor - it's Joaquin Phoenix's no matter what).

I thought it underwhelming.  For me the biggest letdown was the portrayal of the Germans. They were caricatures, throwing up on a drunken binge or savaging the kindness of a rescuer. The so called cinematic breakthrough of camera following our hero through the horrors of war was not sufficient to cover up a childish storyline and the suspension of disbelief required to imagine a roaring torrent in flat Flanders or a meeting with a troop in the middle of No Man's Land that didn't  lend its support to the mission.

The story was told in a very realistic way and brought you in emotionally as well. You were rooting for the two guys to make their delivery and fighting with them through all the obstacles in their way. You were right there with them, to the point where before leaving the theater, you checked your shoes for mud. Extraodinary!

I found the movie engaging and interesting, but I did find myself being distracted by the idea the the movie was filmed as one continuous scene.  Too often I found myself wondering how the film had been shot and what was VFX and losing concentration on the story.  Assuming many of the scenes were shot real time, I thought the acting and direction were amazing because the shots were so, long, complex and well choreographed they could only be accomplished by people with an uncanny ability to concentrate.  They stayed focused on the story, hit their marks over complicated sequences that ran for many minutes without losing contact with their characters.

But the main guy, when left to his own devices, was boring and very uncharasmatic.

"1917" is a gritty, reverent coming-of-age film in combat boots. It rivets with the explosive and intimate loss of innocence that only war inflicts on men. The tension is not between life and death, but between choice and consequence.   "1917" pays tribute to those caught in the kind of war I hope Western Civilization will never see, again.

I found myself a bit disappointed with this movie. It's visually stunning to be sure, and the continuous shot draws you in. After awhile though you forget you're watching a continuous shot though, and you're just left with writing and plot. That's where this movie lost me. The main character should have (well WOULD have) died no less than four times in this movie based on the events that took place. Somehow though, he comes out relatively unscathed. Even when they make you think he was shot, apparently it just grazed his ear and he fell down the steps and was knocked unconscious. Near the end, he walks into a group of soldiers, his own in fairness, but not a single soldier was on lookout. He just walks up and sits next to them up against a tree. I mean wtf? the biggest issue with this movie is that time after time it sacrifices believe-ability for a great visual shot. When in truth, the main character is an idiot and never would have completed his mission. Yet too much Mendes chooses the great shot over a believable scene. Lastly, German soldiers make Storekeepers look like sharp shooters.

Not since Rope, the use of cinematography and choreography create a visual experience the likes of which I have never seen on the bigscreen! Thank you Sam & Alfred Mendes for this immersive experience of story telling!

Moving. This one word describes the essence of 1917. With real heart at its core. The camera is continuously moving, appearing to be shot in just one sweep. Mesmerising. This constant movement paints the personal story of 1917, a couple of un-miraculous blokes navigating World War 1 France. Superb acting moves the audience, making simple scenes hit like artillery shells. The way the tension is ratcheted up with our protagonsists urgently darting through the trenches to the front line and finally across No Man's Land had me physically on edge. Dread filled me, waiting for something awful to happen, a similar sentiment to those lives being depicted. Yet, this was tempered with moments of light banter, dark humour shared between blokes trying to get through this terrible experience. This movie moved me to sobbing tears, an experience last felt during the wonderful Dunkirk. The futility of war was highlighted so beautifully, as was the glimmers of hope and kindness. Strangers sharing rations, drinks or even hope. I urge you to move yourself to a cinema, sit down and be swept away by Sam Mendes' stirring tribute to his grandfather.

The story is not as compelling as the movie as a whole. In other words, a lot of the point is the way it was filmed to appear as nearly just one single scene. While that was nearly perfectly achieved, it does not allow for a great a story or tension as was achieved for Dunkirk.

If you haven't seen the movie 1917, go check it out! From very intentional casting choices that tell a story of military hierarchy without saying a word, to the cinematography that was beautiful and heartbreaking at the same time, and the score that provided both tension and release when needed this stunning love letter from director Sam Mendes to his grandfather is well worth watching. (Sidenote, it's a great, albeit unintentional, companion movie to Peter Jackson's They Shall Not Grow Old.)
The amount of attention to detail and the story blow my mind. They don't take away from the story with gore typically found in war movies.

Don't listen to the jaded critics- this is a major achievement, one of the most stunning war stories I've seen on film. You'll be swept up by the end. The critics sneer because it doesn't go all non-linear, post-colonial, and deconstructionist in every 3rd scene. Meanwhile, Mendes has done one of the best treatments of war you'll ever see. There are a few weaknesses: much dialogue is prosaic and plain; the musical score is too foregrounded; there are some credibility issues in the plot. Never mind all that, this linear film will stun you dead. The visual design, esp. color, is classic Japanese expressionism.

It was suppose to authentic. In the beginning our survivor cuts his hand and accidentally plunges it into a festering corpse. He would have been racked with fever by sunset. Then he is burred in an explosion covered with large concrete chunks. A little water in the eyes and he is fine no concision ,no hearing loss. Late he is shot, something blocks the bullet but he falls bashes his head and is knocked out. Later he survives drowning and finishes up sprinting like Jess Owens.  This is the avengers effect, he is human and cannot do the things he is shown doing.  If you are doing a piece like this you need to stick to reality.

In the drama and peril of the allied trenches and the fields of France, arises a story of triumph and tragedy. 1917 sheds light on the reality of WW1. The picture shows the brutal reality, there was no glory not was it a grand adventure.  The truth is it was a slow, grinding melee of blood and mud. This movie is a must see to gain insight into the war that defined the modern age.

During almost the whole movie you are glued to the main characters who struggle on over the battlefield. So close, that after twenty minutes it begins to irritate. You get the view of a toddler that gets dragged along, showing gruesome details that the main characters (try to) ignore, while you have to depend on the main characters to spot the greater danger that is always around you. When a sniper fires at you, the hero knows where the shot came from and is going to deal with it. So I felt the movie doesn't take you completely serious. 
Besides, despite the fact that many people will not have seen "Paths of Glory", I don't feel it is right to take the most powerful visuals/scenes/narratives and adept them for this movie. I feel 'Paths of Glory' by Stanley Kubrick is despite its age, still superior to this one.

Lo straordinario talento tecnico del regista Mendes e del leggendario direttore della fotografia Roger Deakins è senza dubbio l'elemento che risalta di più, assolutamente indiscutibile sotto ogni punto di vista. Il risultato ottenuto da questa incredibile collaborazione è un film che sbaraglia completamente qualsiasi forma di concorrenza, alza ancora una volta l'asticella, abbatte con decisione ogni limite registico raggiunto finora entrando a pieno merito in un nuovo futuro per la filmografia moderna. Ciò che sono riusciti a creare non è solo un miracolo cinematografico e un achievement da ritrovare in ogni libro di cinema, ma è anche un film che funziona anche sotto l'aspetto narrativo. Perfetta, ben bilanciata ed espressa alla perfezione una sceneggiatura essenziale e dannatamente cruda e realistica, che porta in luce le terribili realtà della prima guerra mondiale da una prospettiva mai vista prima d'ora. La comunione di questi due enormi aspetti crea un capolavoro senza tempo che si prende a mani basse il titolo di film dell'anno.

This is beyond doubt a cinematic masterpiece. I don't think I have ever seen such a blend of spectacular camera work, acting and score (with the possible exception of Villenue's Arrival). Perhaps the most intriguing fact is that the movie is secretly a horror movie rather than a war drama. The plot is unpredictable and keeps the audience guessing as to where the next treachery will occur. The constant tension is interrupted by scenes such as the burning village of Écoust, which can only be described as art. No less impressive is the stellar supporting cast (Firth, Cumberbath, Strong), who only have a few seconds to make their mark, but fill up these moments to the brink. Finally, there comes the question of the score. Although some viewers may find the score too vivid, disturbing their visual experience, I consider it a strength, as it ends up willing the characters through their treacherous journey. Overall, the movie succeeds technically as well as emotionally, without falling into the predictable kitsch of war movies.

Two young British soldiers are charged with delivering an important message during WWI, and we follow their harrowing journey to complete their orders. It's intense, not Uncut Gems intense, but still pretty intense. There's some great cinematography, especially the one-shot/take thing they do. It does a good job endearing you to these characters, and showing you the horrors of war and how cruel and uncaring it can be without being too fantastical. The pacing keeps you engaged, though there is a bit of respite that makes you scream "you don't have time for this". It's an excellently made film, but maybe I'm burnt out on war movies. So I liked it and appreciate it but didn't really enjoy it.

Another aspect that deserves to be mentioned is the photography of this film, which is wonderful, the scenes are constantly showing the open and wonderful environment. The sound work is very well done. 1917 deserved the 10 Oscar nominations, it is an impeccable work of direction, acting, cinematography, sound, editing and soundtrack. 1917 is a film that deserves to be seen by everyone. We will never know what they went through this film pays tribute to them all. The skill of the actors, and all the film makers that created this work of art poured their hearts and souls into it. It could not have felt more real. This was World War I. Not for ANY children of anything below someone in the 16 yr old range because it is appropriately VERY grotesque and violent. "Sam Mendes, Roger Deakins, and Lee Smith. Director, director of photography, editor. Three key filmmaking roles in the creation of one of the best WWI movies of all-time. Edited to look like one continuous shot, 1917 is a mind-blowing technical achievement, elevated by Deakins' always jaw-dropping cinematography, Thomas Newman emotionally powerful score, Mendes impeccable directing, and Smith's seamless editing. George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman deliver outstanding (physical) performances, but it's the astonishing filmmaking that steals the spotlight. Production design, costume design, sound, you name it. Everything is absolutely perfect. It's meant to be seen at the biggest screen near you since this is an incredibly immersive experience that you won't get at home. It's going straight into my Top10: Best Movies of 2019, and I hope you'll love it as much as I do."

Once you get over 1917's one single gimmick, you realize it's not that great of a war movie.

1917 is a one-shot film based during WWI. The plot is rather simple: deliver a letter across enemy lines or else thousands will die. It's straightforward and the action moves quickly.

One area that I appreciate about this film is the respect it pays to WWI. Special attention is given to the hell-like conditions that the soldiers had to face. 1917 does an excellent job showing how the Great War turned normal men into savages. It also did a great job showing the life-and-death conditions that people faced.

But, there were times I felt disconnected from the film. Is it from the dizzying speed the camera moves around? Is it the lack of character development and cheesy dialogue? Is it from the rather cliche plot? I felt no real connection to the characters until close to the end. Shame that this movie was missing that special something.

1917 is a good movie to watch. Yet, I wouldn't call it too memorable. With a bit more polishing, this could have been a much stronger movie.

As a member of the United States Marines I found this movie to have a lot of flaws that I could not look past. Some of these scenes were absolutely ridiculous. I can't fathom how two people sent on such an urgent mission would not only be walking so close side by side but talking like they're going to the mall on a Saturday afternoon. Also the main character lost his rifle along the way and I couldn't help but laugh when I saw him ditch his rifle. I could probably point out another 10 or so flaws along the way with this movie but see no point in it. I've conducted joint operations and training exercises alongside Her Majesty's own the Royal British Marines. Even during World War I British troops were better trained than this. In my personal opinion the director could have had a military consultant come in to make sure that movie was represented in an authentic light or at least near authentic. In my personal opinion I would not recommend this movie to anyone who has ever served in the armed forces. Even the coast guard knows better. I just don't understand how two people can be out in the open strolling laxadaisicle  shooting the shit. All in all this movie was shit and had onslaught of plot holes that left me with more questions than I had antisapated. I understand that this movie might have been based on a true story and some of the things could have happened but it could have been portrayed and or executed in a better manner. I would not even rent this movie from Redbox.

They did their homework on this movie. The WW 1 battlefield they created was very much like the real thing they captured the significant differences between German and British field construction perfectly. The German troop dispositions left behind as the Germans executed their planned retreat to the very formidable Hindenburg Line were authentic, complete with the planned destruction of anything the Brits might find of use, and the occasional sniper. Many of the German troops left to destroy warehouse supplies that could not be evacuated from the heavily shelled town in the movie were drunk, which inevitably happens when troops are directed to destroy items that they can use for their own purposes, such as French wine,etc. The scenes from this part of the movie were quite authentic, complete with so many Germans shooting at the hero....and missing. It's hard to hit anything when you are 9/10 in the bag. 
The story line moved along and kept pulling you in until you felt like you were there. Even with all this, one must remember: the full horror of what the British endured in Flanders will never be successfully captured in a moving picture, but this one comes close.

When Schofield ends up in the river and its daylight you feel all hope is lost and we've genuinely lost but the he finds the 2nd patalien and stops the attack when Schofield meats blakes brother it is a very emotional moment especially love how the final scene matches the first.
Duty and Glory in WW II

The cinematography was exceptional well done The military wardrobe and equipment was fantastic. The cow and bucket of fresh milk had me with ok where is this going. As the story unfolded it started to go downhill. If a burning airplane was coming at you why would you try to out run it? Commonsense would be to run to the left and right of it. Thats when things started to fall apart That German pilot was the enemy he probably was bombing and strafing the trenches they just got out of and would have been shot on the spot or watched very closely. They were on a mission to save thousands of there comrades in arms no time for prisoners, mission first. Then the German Soldier started shooting from the tower he should Have avoided taken it out and slipped by and accomplished the mission. What soldier who has a weapon and is running down a hallway being shot at would not return fire. Then he ducks into a door and there a young woman in there with a baby that’s not hers that needs milk and he just happens to have a canteen full. BS. Then he runs off with out his rifle and helmet. Got to where he was to deliver the message not to send the men into battle and it was to late the first wave went over hundreds were killed and wounded and he saves the rest. He screwed up. If the script writer would have consulted with a decent military advisor it could of been a good movie.

Great scenery etc............ the rest is pretty boring, tedious and predictable. The characters are "colourless" for want of a better word so to be honest, not really that bothered if they get killed or not.  The plot is the sort of thing school kids could write with all your usual stereotyped characters......and of course we get the young lady with the obligatory baby thrown in...   I suffered through to the very end but I was counting down the minutes I had to suffer.  To be honest.... I think I'd have preferred 2 hours in the trenches to 2 hours of watching this!!

Production qualities almost compensates for the huge gaps of logic that are offered as the 'story line'.  Such as: Why would only 2 men be sent out for such an important mission?  Logic says send out 30 pairs of 2 hoping one would get through.  This is more like an Indiana Jones adventure film than a realistic war chronicle.  Weak plot but visually captivating.

1917, I'm going to go out on a limb and say subtlety and warfare don't really go hand and hand. Had it's moments but didn't really work. It could have been because I was expecting a WW1 version of Saving Private Ryan given the trailer looked like a fireworks display. The marketing team played us well with an old fashioned bait and switch. If you were wondering how someone made a movie based around a flying plastic bag and made it art and then two decades later tried the same thing with a spinning plane out of control; you can say he's evolved quite a bit as a filmmaker. I would recommend seeing 1917 based on your expectations being different than mine. Do not expect it to be a military spectacle like SPR, Thin Red Line, Apocalypse Now, Blackhawk Down, etc. Nor should you expect it to have the same sentimentality as his earlier works. You should expect it to be an introspective look at what it's like sneaking behind enemy lines with rats jumping at you left, right, and centre. Did I mention there are a lot of rats in this movie? 

For those gamers out there who have experienced the adrenaline rush of the very visceral Battlefield 1, I must tell you, you will find moments of ecstacy here and there but for the most part you may find yourself checking your phone while the protagonist tends to some random baby. He does attach his bayonet at one point however, now whether or not he actually uses it I will not say. There are also horses in the film, but whether or not he rides them and decapitates people with a sword, I will also not say. 

I will say this, the movie is a bit pretentious and a bit self-serving in that it's based on a story told by the director's grandfather that more than likely was grossly exaggerated for the sake of making it more enthralling and dramatic than it actually was. If you are curious as I was to see the movie, go check it out. I question how deserving the film is of all the accolades it has received so far, but that's material for another discussion. I'm giving this film one bayonet out of four. Not so much for the lack of bayonets, but the lack of: storyline, character development and scope; it's focus on wowing us with sometimes superfluous long takes; a lack of screen time for actors with last names similar to Cucumber and Cabbagepatch; lack of any of the Jonas Brothers; lack of any mention of Canadian involvement, and a lack of any overall suspense.

It's gets one bayonet for having some excellent art direction, costuming, and special effects but my goodness son save your canvas for painting us a picture of the dangerous state of America, something socially relevant, something with more substance, something meaningful, something poetic, something more deserving. War is cruel, war is random, war is brutal. It's not a series of scripted events that sees the character narrowly escape from each time. This is not Indiana Jones, but it felt like it. Next time at least have the decency to put Harrison Ford in the movie.

Beautifully shot, cleverly made and with a real poignancy, 1917 is a fantastic piece of work.

I saw "1917" at a matine in Barrhaven yesterday. Tuesday. (Apparently the schools are on strike so the cinema has matines all week.)

The movie takes place during the aftermath of the German "March retreat" of 1917. In March 1917 the Germans abandonned the Somme and retired to the formidable "Hindenburg Line". Colin Firth's character does not name the line but refers to its strength. 

In fact the action doesnt take place on the Somme but a few kilometers South of Arras on the Artois front. (On the extreme left flank of the Somme Front.) 

The story is entirely fictional and unlikely to have happened as depicted.

I am not an expert on fortifications so i can't comment on the accuracy of the construction of the trenches. (I understand the famous historian Andy Robertshaw was a consultant so i assume the details are correct.) However I doubt the "no man's land" in this area as depicted was as devestated as was shown. But movies about WW1 always show devestated areas with shellholes...bodies and dead horses wether its true or not. To my understanding there was no serious fighting in this area since 1914 and there certainly wern't any derelict tanks on this part of the front at this time or ever. (I'm an expert on british tank operations in WW1.)

Beyond "no mans land" there in fact were green fields and lots of vandalism as shown in the movie. The germans cut down trees along the roads and cut down orchards and poisonned wells. Buildings were destroyed and booby traps left behind.

However there was no canal at Ecoust (the village depicted in the film) and certainly no raging river. That's all fabrication. I might be accused of being picky but there was also no fountain in Ecoust. There are surviving photos of the ruins at Ecoust but none were used in the reconstruction.

I doubt there was ever something as foolish as an unsupported two-battalion attack on the Hindenburg Line near Ecoust on April 6 1917. The larger multi-division Battle of Bullecourt was fought a few days later nearby as part of the greater "Battle of Arras 1917" where tanks were used, to disastrous results.

So. What did i think of the film?  It's a good movie but considering the number of Great War historians that could have been available to help the producers, the movie falls short of depicting the actual history.
