Storyline has more holes than a sieve. Two soldiers are sent across no-man's land to save 1600 soldiers. I suppose the thought of dropping a message from a bi-plane to the Dorset's never occurred to the high-command? On their way they search through abandoned farm buildings but, sitting in the middle of a field, is a bucket filled with fresh milk, supposedly taken from the solitary cow standing nearby probably by one of the Enterprise's crew before he was beamed up. Having rescued a shot-down German pilot who, in gratitude, stabs one of the soldiers to death, the remaining soldier is then surrounded by hundreds of soldiers who have mysteriously and silently appeared at the farm in trucks. Beam me down Scotty came to mind.  Dropped off close to his destination, the soldier is shot during  a gunfight with a German sniper but his injuries mysteriously heal leaving him without a mark. After being chased by more Germans, he hides in a derelict basement only to find a French girl and an obviously well fed baby who the girl explains needs milk. I neglected to  mention that he is suddenly fluent in French and she in English as he produces his water bottle which he conveniently filled with milk from the aforementioned bucket he'd found in the middle of the field. Forging on to his destination, he encounters numerous Germans but evades them all, ending up in river rapids and going over a Niagara sized waterfall during which he looses all his gear but finally arrives at his goal to produce the driest, cleanest and most pristine piece of paper with orders to stop the attack.  The orders must have been written with a yet to be invented indelible marker having survived all of the above. If this film wins an Oscar then I'll eat my hat.

I have read several books on the subject, served in a combat environment, so I tend to be very critical of these things.  With that in mind, I have to say that this movie is as close to a masterpiece as it comes.  Imagine if Saving Private Ryan had a less heavy-handed "object-lesson" story and you get something like 1917.  The Hollywood tropes are largely non-present, the twists are unexpected, the diaogue is pleasantly minimal and the visuals... The depiction of the hellscape that was France in latter WWI is simply terrifying, as it should be.  The final scene really hit me - it solidified the movie, for me, as pretty bloody great.  So I recommend it.   Further reading: "A World Undone"  by GJ Meyer.

First off, the technical ability displayed in this film is just straight-up astonishing. Of course the whole "one-take" concept isn't actually just one take for the entire movie, but by God do they convince you that it is. Following these characters in real time and only seeing what they see immerses you far more than any other technique that any war film has used in recent years, and that's saying something.

Beyond that, the acting and the script are just as fantastic. Dean Charles-Chapman and George MacKay's characters are likable and realistic and the audience will be on the edge of their seat worrying about their fates the entire film. The rest of the cast are great in their roles as well, but the best character has to be the setting itself. WWI with its chaos and destruction is so grippingly portrayed that one could be forgiven if they thought that this entire film were created in 1917 with modern technology.

All in all, this is the best film that I have personally seen not just in 2019 but in the last 3 or 4 years. It's that good.

1917, the new movie directed Sam Mendez, is a cinematic masterpiece and nothing less. The directing's perfect, the acting's perfect, the sound design is perfect, the cinematography is perfect, the script is, well the script is perfectly fine. It's intense, it's emotional, it's stunning, it's horrific, it's a much-watch for everyone who exists. As you may or may not know, the whole movie is shot to feel like one take and it all serves to make you feel like you're really down in the trenches with them. Everything is almost always in motion so the plot also always has forward momentum. There's really not a single dull moment in this movie. It's a treat to watch from beginning to end.
A lot of reviews I've read so far have praised the technical ingenuity of this film and I won't go into that because they've all said it better than I could. Suffice to say, check out all of the behind the scenes stuff you can find because it's almost as interesting as the movie. But one thing I really haven't heard a lot about is the sheer brutalness of it all. The protagonists will be crawling through no-man's land and you'll see the corpses buried in the mud with ghastly holes in their bodies and an entire ecosystem feeding off of them. This movie is not for the squeamish. That's not to say they shouldn't watch it. In an industry all to preoccupied now with cramming fan-service and nostalgia down your throat or beating you over the head with a message or both (not that either are particularly bad things, I personally just feel like they're over-played) It's nice to see a film that just lets the story speak for itself. It doesn't need Captain America wielding Mjolnir and it doesn't need to scream at you war is bad, it just has to exist and it says everything it needs to and it keeps you engaged the whole way through.
Speaking of it's anti-war message, that kinda leads to my one nitpick about the film. At one point, about halfway through, a character gives the protagonist a warning about his message that just kinda turns out to be nothing to worry about. That little scene felt like it was a remnant of a draft that was more explicit about it's message and it just was never cut. Other than that the message works really well. The whole central conflict almost feels pointless (that's not a knock against the movie, that's a knock against WWI), and it really shows just how meaningless the war really was. There was one scene where the protagonists do a good deed and I quietly thought to myself, "Oh, here's the scene that shows how great the British are" but no! The protagonists get punished for trying to be good people! And that's the movie, it's both nihilistic and optimistic in some crazy way. It's literally shot so it looks like the protagonist got back to where he started! And yet, it also feels like some good came out of this. It feels like the protagonists helped people that otherwise would not have been helped and that even through the craziness of war there are still god people. It's almost a shame that the technical aspects are so great because it means that not enough people are talking about the fantastic way it handles its themes.
The other aspect of the movie that is not talked enough about is the cleverness of how it resolves tension. It's hard to get into specifics without giving spoilers, but basically the movie has its protagonist go through one stressful scenario that makes you worry about one thing, for example at one point early one they go through what they think is an abandoned German trench and the audience is on the edge of their seat waiting for the German army to pop up, only for the tension to be resolved in a completely unexpected way. It's never clear until the very end if the protagonists are going to succeed on their goal because the movie throws so many wrenches, some little, some big, into what would otherwise be a very straight-forward plot into a riveting ride where you're never sure what's going to happen next.
The acting is also great. Dean-Charles Chapman and George MacKay were relative unknowns going into this but they are astounding in this. Their relative anonymity really makes them feel like actual soldiers and you're not thinking of them as the actors, you're thinking of them as young men in over their heads. In addition, the celebrity pop-ins, including the likes of: Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Andrew Scott, Mark Strong and Richard Madden are all excellent. Most likely they were not getting paid a lot to do this and you can really tell watching them that they all really want to act in this movie. Nobody is holding anything back and nobody looks like their phoning it in. But HOLY SHIT Richard Madden! It's one thing to not phone a performance in and it's another thing entirely to own the movie with like two minutes of screen time. He probably was on set for like, half a day max, and he kills it. Like, whatever it is, he absolutely slaughtered it. He goes from excited and happy to absolutely devastated in just a couple seconds and he absolutely nails it. That one short scene has really cemented Richard Madden as a great actor and one that I excitedly anticipate following his career in the future.
But back to 1917. 1917 is a fantastic movie and definitely deserves the Best Picture nomination and would deserve to win it too if it can manage that. I walked out of that movie, my head spinning and my brain not working quite right. No other media has ever had that affect on me. So yeah, I mentioned before that this movie is not for the squeamish, but the squeamish should still watch it anyway. 1917 is not just a movie, it's an experience, and it's one that as many people should feel as possible. 1917 is a masterpiece.

P.S. This movie also has one of the most triumphant climaxes ever. Like, I found it more effective than Endgame's massive CGI battle. Because it's not about fictional superhero's punching things. It's about actual human beings pushing themselves to the limit and pervading against all odds.

Through 1917, Mendes makes an eloquent portrayal of why film making is a beautiful art form which is under appreciated. Whilst 1917 lacked narrative and solidification as a story, having no where to go nor conveying an ultimatum, the film was not about narrative. It was not about storytelling. Instead, 1917 wanted to challenge the limits of film making - pushing it from an experience in the cinema into an modern art gallery performance. From a gorgeous colour scheme, outstanding lighting and shots which just capture the epitome of beauty - 1917 must be one of the most beautiful films I've ever witnessed. It contained the realism of war through sublime composition and created a personal feel with the main character as he battled the hardships of war. And whilst we still don't really know who the character is by the end of the film due to the lack of context and establishment of his characterisation, we feel content for him as the sun beams down on his face, creating deep broad shadows which signify hope for the future. In terms of production, it is truly a beautiful film and worthy of its box office acclaim

Sam Mendes' "1917" is a breathtaking, immersive and gripping war film that captures the trenches of World War I with authenticity. With his latest feature, writer/director Sam Mendes has crafted a stunning portrait of World War I. Working alongside acclaimed cinematographer Roger Deakins, Mendes draws viewers deep into the trenches of the war. From a technical standpoint, "1917" is an incredibly impressive film. Roger Deakins' one-shot technique is a risky approach, but it works tremendously well. Deakins' cinematography is as always gorgeous, immersing viewers in the setting of World War I. It is hard to not admire the excellent performances from the cast. George MacKay delivers a dazzling debut performance as Corporal Schofield. With riveting expressions, he captures the fear, terror and determination of a soldier on a life-threatening mission. It's a star-making performance that deserves to be recognized come awards season. Although "1917" is a technical triumph, ultimately it is not a film without flaws. Its story is slightly formulaic, and lacks strong character development of the best films in the genre. It is hard to be emotionally invested in the story when you barely know the characters. Nevertheless, fans of war films will definitely enjoy "1917" and so will movie-goers seeking exhilarating entertainment. At a time when war films are a rarity in Hollywood, its a timely reminder that the stories of war deserve to be seen and told.

A lot has been said about continuous-cut film editing in 1917. From my point of view it merely looked like a video game, where the action is always in front of you. Compounding that video game feeling were the improbable situations and decisions that our heroes were presented with and distracted by:

Instead of going over the German trenches—my choice if I were on a vital mission with little time to complete it—the two "players" improbably decide to go through and under the trenches. Of course, this leads to new, unnecessary adventures and challenges, otherwise needless and counterintuitive for a couple of guys on a vital mission and little time to complete it.

For example, they get distracted (did they forget to take their Ritalin?) by having fun bouncing on a German infantry mattress. Don't they have a vital mission to complete and just a few hours to do it?

And then the explosion within the German tunnel. Under non-video game circumstances, the air inside the tunnel would have been so clouded and full of dusty crud they would have never been able to see to get out. Or breathe. Game over.

No matter that one of them was buried under a pile of rocks that should have killed him outright. (It's just that dust in my eyes!) Anyone else, if not already dead, would have had bruises and cuts covering their face and body for the rest of the movie.

And a concussion. Experiencing a blast like that at close range would have ended the game right then and there from brain injuries—apparently not convenient, however, to plot lines.

Okay, I'm being harsh. But anyone else on a vital mission with just a few hours to complete it would have gone way around that farmhouse, not through it. Here our two heroes lose vital time unnecessarily undergoing a search and kill mission inside a deserted farmhouse that they should have left behind long ago.

And why is it that English soldiers are always wanting to show compassion to the enemy while the Germans are only interested in killing them? This is war propaganda stuff. Didn't we get over that long ago?

But wait! The one surviving soldier has just a few hours to get his vital message to those 1500 troops who are going to die, and what is he doing? Playing with a baby! (A starving baby in a burned-out cellar hole, dressed like it is going to a Christening.)

Okay, I'll give you the beautiful woman in that cellar hole. This is where beautiful woman like to hang out, of course. And we all know that the first thing any normal, healthy English soldier on a vital mission thinks about is sex.

I said video game plot. You are given choices: hidden doors to go through, abandoned houses to enter, beautiful women, yeah, we know the software. Apparently 1917 was made by and for people who grew up playing video games and still see the world that way. A military drone operator must feel the same way.

1917 is a modern cinematic triumph. I hadn't heard (living under a rock, apparently) about the genius long take cinematography that makes it seem like the film is one long shot, but I quickly figured it out and is so effective. Not just effective visually, and absolutely it is, but to the story.  These young men are on a mission to deliver a message that will save 1600 lives. They are undeniably heroic, but when you find yourself thinking about this film days later you will think that every one of those men they hurried past in those trenches would've tried to do the same. The film is essentially one day bookended by reflection under a tree on what really matters in life. And you know as a viewer that 6 April 1917 is only a little over halfway through the Great War. The Germans aren't on the run. The tides aren't turning anytime soon. Those men have another nearly two years of grinding along the dirty, infectious, festering, cramped, exhausted, starving, terrified, lonely, monotonous, brutal uncertain edge of life and death. It's hard for a modern privileged person today to even fathom that. That's why this movie is great. It opens your eyes to what your grandfather's father (etc.) lived. I think I got so much out of 1917 because I loved They Shall Not Grow Old, Peter Jackson's excellent WWI documentary. I can't forget the acting either, because besides the great cameos, George MacKay and Dean Charles-Chapman are both wonderful and should have received more accolades for  performances beyond their years. Sam Mendes is a master of nuance and 1917 will certainly be considered one of his greatest accomplishments. His grandfather would be proud, not only for the film, but for keeping those young men's deeds and sacrifices on our minds.

Written by Sam Mendes and Krysty Wilson-Cairns, and directed by Mendes, unless you've been living under a rock, you'll know that 1917 has been done in such a way as to give the impression that it all takes place in two shots (the marketing material says one, but it's two – there's a time-jump where no attempt is made to hide the transition). In reality, there are a lot more than two shots, but the edits have been digitally 'hidden', much like Birdman (2014) or Utøya 22. Juli (2018). And although I have some issues with it, I think Mendes has made an exceptional film, one in which form and content are tightly matched, with the style effectively delivering the story in a thematically justified manner.

April 6, 1917; the Western Front. German forces have fallen back, and a pursuing British colonel believes that if he attacks now, he can turn the tide of the war. However, he's unaware that the Germans have fallen back to the heavily fortified Hindenburg Line and are lying in wait. With communication lines cut, two British Lance Corporals, Will Schofield (George MacKay) and Tom Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) are assigned to physically carry an order calling off the following morning's attack. If they fail, 1,600 soldiers will be slaughtered.

So, the film's big selling point is its aesthetic design. The use of the single-shot format is such a noticeable type of form that whenever it's used, it automatically places pressure on the content, which must justify why the film is shot this way, or the form becomes gimmicky. Think of Rope (1948) which was edited to look like one shot, or Victoria (2015), which was legitimately one shot. Very little in either film justifies the stylistic design. Compare this with one-shot films such as Russkij Kovcheg (2002) or the aforementioned Utøya 22. Juli, both of which tie form to content. And I think Mendes and cinematographer Roger Deakins achieve like synergy.

Is the one-shot effect distracting? At first, yes, it is a little, especially if you're trying to spot where editor Lee Smith has hidden the transitions. But after sussing two edits in the first twenty minutes, I stopped looking, because I was just pulling myself out of the film unnecessarily. In essence, once you go with the aesthetic on its own terms, you forget about trying to spot the edits, instead letting the cinematography do exactly what it's supposed to do – immerse you.

The opening scene is a superb introduction to the technique. The film starts with a shot of a daffodil field, before pulling back and revealing Schofield and Blake taking a break. They rouse themselves and begin walking, first past more resting soldiers, then the mess, then down a ramp into the trenches. We see the tactile transition from Edenic to hellish because we're moving in real-time through the milieu; we see the boundary between peace and war because the characters walk along that boundary. You shoot this sequence conventionally, and you undercut that.

Along slightly more conventional lines, one has to commend Deakins's work during the nighttime scenes in Écoust-Saint-Mein. As we pass through the ruined town, the only light is from flares creating very hard shadows in constant motion. The whole thing is almost otherworldly, and as the light traverses the sky, it's as if the ground itself is in motion. You won't find a better study in how to compose a sequence using light and shadow.

Thematically, by its very nature, 1917 is far more focused on the micro than the macro – you might learn something about life on the front, but you'll learn nothing about the politics behind the conflict. Partly because of this, it avoids, for the most part, the kind of cartoonish jingoism that make films like Saving Private Ryan (1998) so obnoxious. Indeed, the protagonists' nationality is largely anonymous, which is not something you can usually say of a war film. On the other hand, you shouldn't expect too much psychological insight. The Thin Red Line (1998) it most definitely isn't.

The story is unquestionably paper-thin, but that's by design. One criticism I did have, however, is how well-groomed Scholfield and Blake are. One only need watch They Shall Not Grow Old (2018) to see how unrealistic this is. Indeed, they look like they've just stepped out of the makeup trailer most of the time, and it's glaring enough to pull you out of things on occasion.

All things considered though, I thoroughly enjoyed 1917. The single-shot strategy worked well, and even if the film is weak from a character/storyline/theme perspective, it didn't really matter when form and content are this well matched. It could have been an empty technical exercise, but Mendes hasn't allowed that to happen. The Great War was hell on Earth. 1917 doesn't make us feel what that hell was like. Because no art form can do that. But it's a very fine approximation.

This movie is more about the the characters than the actual war. As such, there's not nearly as much fighting as one might expect. Don't misunderstand- there is definitely fighting, explosions, and way related things, but the focus is on the journey. These two soldiers must deliver a message and they must pass through the enemy to get to their fellow troops. The first gunshot of the film made me literally jump, I physically left my seat for a second because I jumped so high. It caught me off guard because I was so focused on the story and characters. I highly recommend this movie. I will say it's not for everyone. There were times when it seemed to move a bit slowly, but the action always returned. There were scenes that may cause sensitive people to freak out a little- dead and mutilated bodies, etc. Lessons to be learned: loyalty, dedication, friendship, brotherhood, perseverance, courage, creative thinking. Probably more, but that's all I can think of at the moment. I watched the movie 10 hours ago, just now have the time and energy to write all this. If you fall asleep easily to movies with slower moving stories, you may want to wait until this one is on something other than the big screen, but it's definitely worth seeing on the big screen if you're into this kind of movie. I hope this helps someone make an informed decision. Have an awesome day!?! 🤗🤗🤗
Great movie!!! Shot perfectly!!!

1917: On a technical level, a storytelling level, a commintary of war, on a humanity level thats packed with a cinematic look and biting suspence, 1917 is a masterpiece. A film that is truly a cinematic experience thats nearly perfect that also has a little more on it’s mind than the ususal fare from the genre and arguably the best war film of the century.

As the soldiers moved slowly through the rugged countryside, on full alert for sniper fire and bombs, I too was in the state of hyper alertness.  We get to see almost firsthand how war is hell, but I think being there conveys the point even more forcefully.  The acting was super and so was the photography.

Such a well-captured film, the cinematography was impeccable! Not only is this a war film that takes place during WWl, but it is also an incredible story about friendship and brotherhood and what we as human beings are willing to do for the ones we love.

It literally covers too much ground in the time available. Trenches. No mans' land. Abandoned farm. Fire-ravaged town. River rapids. SLOW DOWN! The one-take technique may be good PR, but it does not make this a better film.

Dialogue is surprisingly wooden (e.g. 'I'm looking for the Devonshires'. 'We ARE the Devonshires!' Groan.)

This movie is simply stunning. The question must be posed though: is it really a movie? Or a cinematic experience. Shot with almost faultless camerawork which aids the beautiful cinematography. Every single second of the thriller is perfectly played by the two leads in a very believable and emotionally raw performance. Every single second of the 2 hour runtime is dripping in anticipation, always keeping the watcher - who is arguably the 3rd main character - involved and engaged. Whether you liked the film or not, you must admit that the historic importance and technical achievements must be honoured.

On a technical level it's a stunning achievement to behold, impeccably shot and paced, propelled perpetually forward by the universality of a soldier's survival instinct, though the simplicity of the well-trodden narrative belies the hellish political machinery that gave (no just) cause to the Great War, undermining the specificity of the conflict—though perhaps all wars are the same war—in a way that is itself somewhat dehumanizing in its humanistic approach to ground-level storytelling about an everyman warrior.

If you're into really historical war films this one definitely isn't for you. The main plot of the movie would never have actually happened in World War I. They had runners whose specific job was to run messages to troops in areas that couldn't be reached by phone or vehicle. The charge in the attack at the end of the movie wouldn't have happened the way it did at all, there would've been a barrage of artillery and machine gun fire before the men charged across the field, those were just basic tactics in the first World War. However, if you just like a fun movie, this one is gold. The way it's shot is incredibly immersive and it's intense throughout. Good movie, just not good historical movie.

Its Oscar bait. They give no backstory on the main characters and its just the two of them for the majority of the movie. I didnt feel invested in either of them. The camera work also made me dizzy at times too, so that was no enjoyable.
The movie looked amazing, very pleasing to the eye sensors. Story line could have been written better and many things that happened didnt have to happen while that couldve happened did not.

He's just delightful and gives such tender humanity to this film that's all about the bombastic filmmaking technique. A must-see on the big screen indeed!

Reading or listening to "how it was" is one thing, watching a possible scenario is quite different. I recommend this film to a younger generation in hopes a wave of gratefulness to those that fought arises. Life and death portrayed well side by side. The lighting was perfect, griminess believable I felt sad, anger, caught my breath, dismayed and stressed as if I was the one doing the delivering!

A perfect example of an amazing film with a sub par ending. It's not that I didn't how the plot or characters ended up, but rather the lack of importance or gravitas to the ending. That was most likely by design, but for me it just didn't work. Everything else about the film was truly magnificent. I can't recommend it enough. The term thrill ride is thrown around a lot in reviews but this movie really was a ride. You get on at the beginning and are propelled along the way on the edge of your seat. The lulls are like much needed breathers. It's visually stunning. There's a night sequence, which I won't spoil, that truly made my jaw drop. This is superior film making, there's no doubt about it. Mendes is in top form. He has cemented his place among the greatest film makers of all time with this film. For all the inevitable comparisons to "Saving Private Ryan" I have to say I think the two are perfect companions to each other. For how well SPR conveyed WW2 this film does WW1. See it. See it in the theater, and if you miss it there see it at home. It's a must see film.
while it was a great story & acting was good, it was sooooo slow & drawn out.  2 hrs of movie delivering a message.

The technique of the "long take" is like a shredding guitar solo. As technically impressive as it is, it should only work to serve the entire larger goal. Mostly, 1917 succeeded, seamlessly & un-distractingly placing us within the mud-covered boots of young men forced into war. At others, I was too focused on it, constantly trying to pinpoint where the "edit-cheats" were hiding. Ultimately, it's a war movie more about adrenalin & inspiration that brains or ethics…not bad, I just think I'm more interest in the latter.

An amazing film. I was impressed both with the story and with the technical aspects of the filmmaking. There is a lot to ponder in this film, most notably how the main characters respond to duty in hellish wartime conditions. What does it mean to be human in a world like this?

Definitely a movie to see.

89% favorable is generous in my view.  The film's story is not unlike Frodo and Sam's, a pair of sodiers  given a task with low probability of success.  The story is then the trip through hazardous lands with monitors showing up periodically.  The trip in this movie has little to do with its title, it could be anywhere, anytime.  But the key problem I had with the movie is the inane actions of its hero's.  The task is to deliver a ring (sorry, an order) to a major on the other side of Mordor (sorry, no man's land) and they have but 12 hours to do so.  They come across a farm, which inexplicably they decide they have to explore.  Any reasonable person would go around this farm, not to it.  I came out of the movie questioning if it was a war movie.  The movie is good, not great.  Sit back, enjoy the acting and invoke your suspension of disbelief, and you'll be okay, just don't expect to come away with any insight into 1917.

It truly is a feat of film making that will be replicated, and that is kind of sad because it is going to be really hard to make a film like this again.

No winners...tremendous loss and sadness...As wars have progressed...we have become more skilled at killing.

The cinematography is fantastic, like no other movie I have ever seen.  At first, while the main characters are traveling through the trenches, with the camera following them, I didn't think I'd be able to watch the whole movie like that.  But, as soon as they broke over the trenches and ventured off on their journey, it became apparently clear what this camera technique was going to do for the audience.  I felt the feelings of the characters completely.  I was with them on the journey.  The storyline was a little too familiar (Saving Private Ryanish), and ended abruptly (expecting a letter to the mother of the soldier or more closure to the purpose of the journey).  But overall, just when you didn't think a new idea could be created in movie making.....1917 comes along.  Well worth the money to see it on the big screen.

I thought this was a good war movie but not in the same class as some Great War movies and not meriting the awards attention it is getting.  It seemed very derivative, with many themes and plot lines out of other movies, notably Saving Private Ryan, which was much, much better.  The cliche's and stereotypes were non-stop and they loved showing the men wallowing in fetid water littered with dead bodies, though these could have easily been avoided by the hero's.  Yes, the cinamatography is really impressive.

Sam Mendez and crew should win awards for cinematography. The technical achievement of a single continuous shot  (or maybe just 3, AT THE MOST) with no cuts (or possibly just 2 - the underwater scene and the blackout scene) combined with the quality of the sets and locations, set design and lighting.... OMG incredible. What if just one actor flubbed a line or became distracted and began to giggle? An entire day of shooting would be down the drain. Amazing.

Innovative, Impressive, and Immersive. The cinematography is this film's highlight, and the movie fully takes advantage of the medium. Production quality is phenomenal. Acting is superb, with incredible amounts of talent on display. Editing and production are stellar. The narrative is solid, taking risks where necessary and playing it safe otherwise. Character development is lacking in some areas. The one-take style drew me into the film to the point where I was shaking and jumping in my seat in reaction to on-screen events. The soundtrack is pretty good, but in some areas could be improved. An incredible film that deserves the praise it gets.

1917 - A BEST PICTURE?
1917 - A Best Picture?

by armen pandola

Do you like war movies?  What are your favorites?

If you like war movies and Saving Private Ryan or The Paths of Glory or even The Longest Day are among your favorites, then you will like !917, directed and co-written by Sam Mendes.  If you don't, chances are, 1917 will not make  a believer of you in spite of the fact that it is an odds-on favorite to win the Oscar for Best Picture.

Mendes won an Oscar for his first feature film, American Beauty, which no one watches any longer because it starred Kevin Spacey and because his character, a middle-aged man on the brink of a breakdown, has sexual fantasies about his teenage daughter's friend. 

Since then, Mendes has directed a couple of good movies (Road to Perdition and Revolutionary Road), a couple of so-so movies (Jarhead and Away We Go) and a couple of Bond movies (Spectre and Skyfall).  He comes from the theatre and continues to direct for the stage. 1917 is his first co-writing credit.

So, what does 1917 bring to the 'war movie' table that wasn't there already? 

Peter Jackson's They Shall Not Grow Old  has all of the horror of World War I,  Stanley Kubrick's Paths of Glory has all of its despicable commanders, All Quiet on the Western Front (1931) has the folly of its 'patriots' and Gallipoli (1981) has the tragedy of senseless slaughter. What else is there to say or show?

Mendes brings us a war movie that follows two soldiers for one day, keeping his camera on only these two and what they see and experience. Shot in segments several minutes long, the movie is stitched together seamlessly - or seemingly so. From its opening to its closing, the camera stays focused on the two protagonists. What does this add to the movie?

'Tracking shots' are shots that go on for a minute or more without the action stopping in order to set-up a new shot. Alfred Hitchcock shot one of his least successful movies, Rope, the story of two rich kids who kill someone for the fun of it, in a few very long takes. Orson Welles starts off Touch of Evil with a three and a half minute tracking shot that ends in an explosion. Paths of Glory has a shorter (91 seconds) tracking shot of a general walking through the trenches. Scorsese's Goodfellas has a three minute tracking shot of Henry Hill and Karen walking through the kitchen of the Copacabana to front row seats. If you have noticed such scenes, then you are probably a film buff. 

What do tracking shots add to a movie? In the movies I have mentioned, long tracking shots have furthered the story. For example, in Goodfellas, the long tracking shot shows us how Henry, a small-time mobster, has special privileges because of his insider status, privileges that impress his date, Karen.

What has filming 1917 like one long sequence added to its message?  It has focused our attention on two soldiers and two soldiers alone. This is a view of war from the bottom up. The stench and mud and rats are brought to the fore as two young corporals, Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Schofield (George MacKay), undertake a mission to save sixteen hundred fellow soldiers from a senseless slaughter.  Sadly, Mendes decides to add to the mix a few 'special appearances' from famous actors a la The Longest Day (1962). The movie stops dead for brief appearances by Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch and Mark Strong, taking us out of the gory frontlines and into the world of make-believe. 

There is not much depth in 1917.  Two soldiers are given what seems to be a suicide mission which one of them is eager to undertake because he has a personal motive - his brother is one of the soldiers who may be saved. Along the way, we are told small bits and pieces of their lives. They are not especially memorable, and the self-imposed technical limitations make it impossible for us to have a fully rounded portrait of them. In the end, they are just two soldiers, much like millions of others who were fighting on both sides - and dying. And that is 1917's virtue and its limitation. Given its narrow scope, 1917 can only appeal to our most sentimental feelings.

The best war movie that I have ever seen has not been in circulation in years - there are some pirated versions available on Amazon. The Victors is a 1963 British-American WWII movie written, produced and directed by Carl Foreman, starring George Peppard, George Hamilton, Melina Mercouri, Jeanne Moreau, Elke Sommer and Eli Wallach - yes, an odd cast, but an excellent one. The movie dares to be an anti-war movie in an era when such feelings were suppressed. WWII was the 'good war,' yet there was no sentimentality in The Victors - in fact, it showed the execution by firing squad of a GI deserter (a scene inspired by the real-life 1945 execution of Pvt. Eddie Slovik). 

 In The Victors, war didn't make the men 'better' or more 'giving' or 'caring.' War did to the young men it trapped exactly what violence does to young men - it makes them worse, not better. There is a scene in which a new member of the squad finds a dog and starts to take care of it. When the squad pulls out of its camp, the sergeant tells the young soldier that no dogs are allowed on the trucks. As the young recruit sadly sits in the truck with his fellow soldiers, one hardened veteran tells the recruit to call the dog, so the recruit whistles to the dog, thinking they will hide it on the truck. Instead, the veteran shots it. That's what war does to young men, at least those who survive.  The Victors won no awards for presenting war as it is - and The Victors has been forgotten. A great loss.

1917 is a magnificent achievement in regards to the technical aspects of film making. Sam Mendez directs an incredibly well shot movie filled with scenes that I will not soon forget. One scene in particular which took place in a French town at night was one of the most visually striking scenes of the year.  Roger Deakins continues to cement his legacy as one of the best cinematographers in film making with 1917, which is one of his greatest achievements. The only aspect of the movie that I feel holds it back somewhat is its lack of character development. The movie asks you to feel for characters which really do not receive much development throughout the film. That being said, I think the movie is still excellent and is well deserving of the praise it has received.

1917 is a one of a kind film. Going in, I was expecting to compare it to my favorite war films such as "Saving Private Ryan" and "The Thin Red Line", but 1917 had so many unique qualities of its own. What stood out to me was the "one-shot-esque" take, the haunting score, the creative lighting choices, the intense pacing and plot, and most importantly was the unique was the film provoked the audience's emotions. The acting from George McKay was stellar, where Dean-Charles Chapman's performance was great yet a bit forced. All in all though, my expectations for 1917 were rather high, but this film absolutely blew me away!

This is a review of the movie 1917. I gave it a D rating both for premise, historical accuracy, and dialogue. I compare it to Private Ryan which was a mostly ‘A" movie with only some illogical parts.

The premise is that it has been 3 years of trench warfare and for some reason in April 1917 the Germans in some sector have pulled back to a defensive line in the rear. A British battalion, without orders and for some reason, is chasing the withdrawing Germans thinking they have them on the run.

1.	The scene opens with our two heroes walking through a trench. Their uniforms are clean, trench is very clean, wood is clean as are the sandbags. Reality was that after 3 years of trench warfare the trenches were filled with one to two feet of mud and water. Trench foot was a real problem. There was nothing clean.

	So the movie begins like a 1950's Western and continues in this same vein.

2.	The two heroes are given an assignment to travel several miles across no-mans land to give a message to this wayward battalion that they are running into a trap. Now its not actually a trap but rather another defensive line, but the movie keeps calling it a trap. 

	We don't know why two routine no account soldiers are given this duty rather than say actual couriers or intelligence people. Further, no reason why a group of say 10 soldiers aren't sent out at different spots to make sure the message gets through that the battalion is not to attack.

We are told that the British can't communicate with the battalion because the wires have been cut. What wires? This is supposed to be a fast action pursuit of a withdrawing enemy yet they have time to lay wire across enemy lines? Even so, after 3 years of war the British know how to fix cut wires. Further, the regular thing was to drop dispatches by planes and we see planes flying in this movie. So they would have dropped dispatches in reality.

So the premise is extremely nonsensical.

3.	So the heroes jump out of the trench and start across no-mans land. We are told that two days before the Germans had killed a bunch of folks but now the way is all clear. The heroes jog across the bad land standing up for the most part. No crawling is allowed in this movie. No German snipers around I suppose. 

	They pass a dead horse. If the clean trench wasn't bad, this is absurd. If you look at dead horses and mules on the battlefield as in Civil War pictures you notice that their stomachs are all bloated from the internal gas. Just like humans. And they have shrapnel wounds, bullet holes and cannons have shot off legs and such. But not this horse. He looks like he is sleeping. Just lying there all nice and clean.

	What is worse is that horses were never in no mans land. They were behind the lines. They might get killed by artillery but to put them in front is to say there was a cavalry charge. No cavalry charges in WW1. Wrong war.  

4.	Then one hero gets stabbed by barb wire. No gloves. So now he has tetanus.  He's going to die. We don't get antibiotics until around 1945. We used sulfur before that but not even that in WW1. He's going to die. He wraps a bandage around his wound.

	
5.	Then they pass a tank in a crater. The Mark 1 British tank was first used in the fall of 1916. They didn't have the Mark 2 and 3 until late April and summer of 1917. This tank appears to be a Mark 3 so it wasn't in use in April 1917. They also did not send tanks across craters. The tanks went about 8 miles an hour and constantly had mechanical problems. They did use them to cross barb wire and trenches but not craters.    

	BTW, Americans like Patton and my Great Uncle George used French tanks cause the US didn't make any.

6. Our heroes get to the German abandoned trench. They keep saying they are on a time constraint and must keep moving but they divert to explore some underground lair. Made no sense.

6.	They get to a bombed out farm house and what do you know, there's a cow? So after 3 years the Germans have not gotten around to eating this cow. Riiiight

	And there is a bucket of milk. Now this is old unpasturized bacteria filled milk bucket and our guy thinks it's just great and fills his canteen. Riiiiight

7.	Then we come to the German airplane scene. The plane is shot down. Most of the time in these sorts of crashes the pilots were dead. Maybe a few survived all unconscious and all broken up. But not in this movie.

	After our heroes pull the pilot out of the burning plane saving his life, the pilot is on the ground in the lap of one of our boys, who the German pilot then stabs in the stomach!!

	Our boy never sees the pilot pull the knife because he is too busy? Looking at his cell phone? So our guy is lying there stabbed and is now in the lap of his buddy. I thought I was watching a 50's Western with Audie Murphy. You have the usual dialogue,  "You'll tell Mom won't you?" Of course, I will. Am I dying? Of course, you are."

I wanted to add, " And tell my girlfriend Sally won't you? Yes, as soon as I screw her brains in cause you're not there cause you're dead." But no dialogue like that.

Now this same buddy has just wrapped his tetanus diseased hand in a bandage. But he never takes his friend's shirt off, pour water over the wound to clean it and then wrap another bandage around the entry. Because wouldn't you know but about a minute later another company of men show up and they have a medic. Or in real life they would've.

And stomach wounds can be fatal if they hit a vital part or not. Seward, who bought Alaska from the Russians, was assassinated on the same night as Lincoln by the same group of people. He was stabbed multiple times. BUT because he was so grossly FAT none of the wounds were fatal and he survived!

8.	So now we are down to one hero. He gets in a truck with the others. And in the truck is a Kurkha or a Sikh. Ridiculous. Colonial troops did not serve with regular British troops. They had their own unit officered by the white man. But in this movie, they show him with regular British troops. 

	In the war in Italy in WW2 the French used Algerian Colonials who had these really long knives. They routinely would go into an Italian village and rape all the women and kill the men. They did not serve with regular troops.  But they were on our side.

9.	Our hero gets off the truck and crosses a river. There is a German sniper in the window. If this is familiar it is because they stole the scene from Private Ryan. In that movie the sniper does not miss because he's a sniper. But in this copy the sniper is a terrible shot. He misses and continues to miss. Our hero shoots blindly at a window and by golly wounds the sniper.

	He then goes up the stairs after the sniper. Forget the mission, Forget the time constraint. Lets go up the stairs. The going up the stair scene is another Private Ryan copy. He opens the door and shoots the German just like the German did in Private Ryan.

By the way he is using an automatic Enfield, which did not exist nor does it today. The Taliban used these same Enfields against the Russians. They don't today cause they have lots of our weapons. The Enfield in WW1 was a single shot rifle with a lever for ejecting the shell and inserting the next cartridge. You could have a 5 or 10 shot magazine but you still had to pull the lever. Not in this movie. It shoots like an M1. 

	Then he finally makes it to some burned out village. No idea why it is burned out since it was in the rear lines of the Germans but no matter. The village is full of Germans. Don't know why since they had withdrawn but no matter. The Germans shoot at him. Point blank. And miss.

	But wait there's a woman. Every other person has evacuated but not this woman. And the Germans haven't raped her. They haven't raped her because they just can't seem to find her and they are too busy missing at point blank range.

In WW2 the American army left plenty of raped French woman behind. I am reminded of my Uncle's unit where they told me a story of coming upon a farm house and the husband charged the men American dollars to go upstairs and have a go with his wife.

And wait, she has a baby!! That's right, the whole town is gone except for her and this baby. And she needs milk. So he gives her his rancid milk. He doesn't know that women who have babies carry their own supply.   
	
The woman talks French and he speaks only English but somehow they understand each other perfectly! Seriously! I think they were reading the subtitles.

10.	He is then chased by Germans again who again miss at point blank range. Then stealing from Last of the Mohicans he jumps into a raging river and waterfall. It is the exact same scene from Last of the Mohicans.

11.	The river carries him exactly to the lost battalion he was trying to find. So our hero doesn't have to stumble around for a hundred miles trying to find them, the river brings him right to them. Such luck!

12.	He then runs through a trench to find the Command Post to tell the General, who we are told doesn't obey orders, to call off the attack.

Trench? What trench? Why is there a trench? I thought this battalion was chasing the Germans. Yet they had the time to dig a very clean trench with a very clean sandbagged and all Command Post. Must have taken weeks. Not in this movie.

13.	He reaches the General. The General says….wait for it…..he says ok, the attack is off. And the movie is over just like that.

	I think a "D" might be too generous.

1917 is by far the weakest of the Oscar nominated films.  The "movie" feels like a excruciatingly long Twilight Zone episode, the variety where displaced characters find themselves in surreal environments.  The soldiers meander aimlessly through mud laden bunkeresque passages, bumping into war weary soldiers who occasionally demand an apology.  The novelty is the movie is filmed as a "one shot," which only makes it feel gimmicky.   With little content and amateurish direction (think walking through corridors à la West Wing), the actors have nothing of substance to work with.  Although the Allies won WWI, Germany is having the last laugh thanks to this disastrous excuse of a film.

"1917" is a very well made and acted movie.  The cast does a very good job and the production design is first rate.  However, for the most part, "1917" is a carbon copy of Steven Spielberg's Academy Award winning World War 2 epic "Saving Private Ryan".  "1917" follows basically the same plot line.  On the Western Front the Germans have retreated.  The Commanders of the second Division of the Devonshire Regiment are under the impression that the Germans are weak and one decisive attack on them will force Germany into surrender.  However it is revealed that the Germans have retreated as part of a tactical strategy and are actually preparing a major counterattack and hope to lure the Allies in and overwhelming them.  Two British soldiers are ordered to go to the front line and deliver a message to the commanders of Devonshire to call off  the attack.   The two soldiers somewhat reluctantly go to carry out their orders and meet with dangerous obstacles.   Sound familiar?  That does not mean that "1917" is bad, it is just a bit disappointing and unoriginal.  In all fairness I was never bored and many sequences are well staged, but I while I was watching the movie, I felt I had seem it before.

Lets start with the good.  The most obvious is the telling of this story in one single view. No cuts or passing of time. Everything occurring real time. The number of extras involved, the battle sequences, its is choreographed so wonderfully that the movie offers something that no other movie provides.  A real perspective... as if you are on the journey with them.  It is wonderful way to view this story and one we don't see used often (like in Birdman). However, it does come at a cost in this story and that is a lack of any real emotional connection to the characters.  

The movie begins with two soldiers being told to see the Generals and from that point, they are off. How much do we really get to know about these characters?  Why should we care about them other than the importance that they be successful in the mission they have been tasked with?  

As they are trekking through No-Mans land, they are on the look out for enemy Germans. Not really an opportune time to have any real conversations of any real substance so we never really do get to know the characters.  The mission, and ONLY the mission seems to be real focus.

1917 is definitely fascinating to watch and certainly worthy of  a trip to the theater but it carries very little emotional impact on the viewer as compared to other war movies that have used more conventional methods of film making (Saving Private Ryan, Platoon, Band of Brothers).

I almost feel that the movie would have been better served allowing us to get to know these characters first before moving on to the one take perspective.  Give the audience something to connect them to these soldiers before they carry out their arduous, incredibly treacherous mission.  Yes the stakes are high, for them and for the success of the mission... but if we know our history, we already know how the story ends, so what is needed is the journey, which is not just the mission itself but what it means in terms of what the characters have to lose.  That all gets lost without SOME focus on the characters.

The point is this.. The movie is interesting because of its perspective, but beyond that, does it make you think? Does it make you feel?  If it doesn't, as war movies go, isn't that kind of the point?  To make you feel or think.. about something... anything?  

For me, this movie simply felt like a movie where I came in at the point where the film was starting the beginning of its build towards a climax but I had missed all the exposition prior to it.   So while there is tension and there is peril, there nothing to connect my interest in the characters other than the success of the mission.

So the movie deserves high marks for its direction (no easy feat to coordinate a one take perspective for 1hr 30 minutes). It worked well in Birdman.. but the difference is, in Birdman, we also got to KNOW the character and connect with him through the length of that movie.

Give the movie its props for cinematography, set pieces, visual effects, etc.. as well. Academy... nominate away.

But Best Picture? Based on that list of nominees, there are others that I believe to far more deserving.

I had my expectations up very high for this film and I also really like movies that portray true events.  The only problem with this movie is it was obviously not being truthful. It showed one ridiculously unlikely event after another and the believability was lost about ten minutes in -- and it got even more ridiculous from there.  The final deal breaker for me was the scene where the two leads pull an enemy soldier from a burning plane. Made no sense especially, right after the speech one of them had just given about being so intent on getting the message to his brother and the 1600 soldiers whom they needed to save. So suddenly his priority was saving a dangerous  enemy soldier, putting his own life in jeopardy. And what happened after that was something I've seen in dozens of movies. In fact a lot of stuff in this movie seemed ripped off from other movies.  Another really bad thing about this movie was the scoring, which was horrific and didn't fit the movie at all. At times it seemed like music for a cheap horror film and other times it seemed a throw back to some patriotic propaganda movie from the 60s.  The long shots with no edits seemed to go on and on...were pretentious and extremely boring.  I really didn't like this, nor did my husband, who had pretty much the same thoughts on it.

1917 was a really long movie, which spent hours on end building up the character played by George MacKay, as highly driven and motivated to saving the 1600 men. After his fellow soldier is killed, MacKay's motivation ramps up to the point he tries to lift a truck out of the mud basically by himself. Then the direction of the movie ceases and MacKay wanders around wasting precious time chatting up a french woman and playing coo-coo with her baby. Then he stops and listens to a soldier sing a lovely tune. What the hell is this wasted time by the most motivated character in the film. Then presto chango the motivated character pops back in and MacKay tries to save the first wave of half the 1600. Oh No, he wasted all the time and over the top go the first wave and they are mowed down like wheat. 800 men wasted, 800 families destroyed so the character could lean on a tree and listen to a singer. This direction mistake ruins an other wise fine movie and leaves the audience with its mouth wide open trying to connect the unconnect dots of the main actor. I must protest the nominations received and will laugh at any awards won for this jumbled piece.

1917 revolves around two young men tasked with crossing no-mans land to deliver a message. If they fail, thousands die.

The film portrays no glory of war. It holds back from being over the top dramatic. Instead, it sucks you in to the action. The whole timeline of the film is just a few hours of action, with just a handful of characters. You get an ever so tiny view into war, from an angle you would have experienced. No big overview. No information that the characters don't get. 

The whole film is designed to appear as a single shot, the camera following these brave young men the whole way. Every now and then, though some of the subtlest camera work I've seen, you're drawn to a horror of war that hardly seems to impact the battle scarred youngsters. 

The film hits home. The story would have been played out thousands and thousands of times, every day, for years. 

If anything, this film is a lesson in perspective. 

- Putting our current struggles into perspective

- Putting war into perspective. It's not Nation Vs. Nation, it's man vs. man. Individuals vs. individuals. A life vs. a life. 

- Putting people into perspective. There are two moments, in particular, when the duty towards others trumps the duty to one self. 

A great film. 100% would watch it again. Please go see it if you can.

1917 is certainly a technical achievement, and it's hard to comprehend how difficult it must have been to make. So many obstacles to negotiate, extras to co-ordinate and marks to hit, only a seasoned director like Sam Mendes could have pulled it off. It features a lot of big names, but much like The Thin Red Line many of them are only on screen for a few minutes, raising the question of why they needed such stars in the first place. The film is a solid piece of work, but aside from the one-shot style, there's nothing that distinguishes it from most other high-profile war films. Saving Private Ryan, Dunkirk, The Deer Hunter, Platoon, Apocalypse Now; all of these films were made with more conventional styles, yet all were more emotionally resonate, tense and impactful. Mendes has a crafted a film that is more to be admired than enjoyed. I get the impression that if it had been shot in an ordinary fashion it wouldn't have attracted the plaudits it has. But I'm not trying to take anything away from the production. I really liked how it was put together, giving us a sense of escalation, making the viewer a third character, showing how far the lead has to go to accomplish his mission, which is to deliver a message. Om the positive side, the costume design and trench depictions were excellent. 
Assessment: Not Academy Award material.

So we all know that war is ugly. War is gross. War is full of heart wrenching experiences and unfathomable grief. That is why war has been romanticized throughout the ages. It can capture your imagination and twist your emotions up in knot and get up in your face and grab your soul . We all root for the "hero", the "good guy" who is fighting the "enemy". We want him (or her) to "win" and settle in the end with a justified outcome. The outcome in a war story told for the big screen makes us feel good. The end result justifies the means, over and over again. At least in the movies. If a movie were to realistically depict all the consequences, and not just the justified ones of combat, the realism would make us sick. Not that movies haven't tried to portray realism, but they pick and choose what to describe in order to illicit a response from the viewer. 1917 is no exception. 
One thing I didn't know going into this movie is that there are no Americans present. You have to listen to the dialog with the British accents, which occasionally were lost on my ear not accustomed to Brit speak. We Americans are so used to seeing and hearing war stories with the Americans winning and holding the Stars and Stripes up high, that it was like "oh….okay, no Americans here" and it took awhile to sink in.  
The opening scene shows the trenches in France where British soldiers are hanging out waiting for their next move. We've all heard the expression "battling in the trenches" but we've never really experienced it, have we? There's hardly any color available for the eye to grab on to. Everything is bland and near monotone of brown and gray. Mud, dirt, and rocks and war torn men in same color battle gear are all that's there. A skinny trench of a hell hole existence for these men who are there either willingly or maybe not. I do have to say that one thing this movie does well is make you feel like you are there, so that afterwards you kind of have a small puny inkling of what it may have been like to actually have been present. That's exactly what this movie tries to do more than other war movies. The panoramic views of desolation and barrenness gives the viewer a sense of desperation and hollowness. It's as if everything that is good on this green earth has been stolen and forgotten. 
The two men who are chosen to go on a special mission at the beginning just seem like two random guys in the middle of the pack. We don't know anything about them. There is no back story about who they are or where they've been prior to latch onto . That is one thing I wish the movie had done. For when we get to intimately know a character first, we get more sucked in to the story. We can only imagine, because really at this point they just seem like "soldier No. 1 and soldier No. 2" dudes. That's not part of the story. The character development is made simultaneously as it moves full steam ahead. The plot is pretty simple: Two seemingly brave yet afraid men go on an outwardly impossible mission to save a huge number of other men from complete annihilation. If they complete their task, they will be heroes. It kind of makes you wonder though, if in real life if such a mission was thwarted by any number of possible situations, they would never be remembered as heroes, but just one of the many casualty numbers. Hmmm…… how many men died out in the battlefield trying their best to be brave but didn't get to complete their heroic task? They are all but forgotten by the world. But here, this is a movie, and of course the outcome has to be the good one or it was all for naught.  The movie's direct objective is to get you to like the ending so you can walk away with a justified sense of the war's purpose. The men don't know what they are about to encounter and they know it's extremely dangerous. One man, Blake, sets out with willful determination all gung ho style, because he was chosen for the fact that one of the men who will be saved, should they complete their mission, is his brother. "No time to waste let's go!" The other soldier in the duo was his combat friend next to him that Blake chose himself, before he knew what they were in for. Of course his choice proves to be providence. This guy (Schofield)  is anxious and fearful, he doesn't want to go at all and tries to think through the plan of action so as to improve the odds of survival. So here we have two opposing forces which sets itself up right away as the dominating pull. The fact that war is awful, terrifying, and revolting, yet brings up the courage and bravery inside a human soul that they didn't even know was there to defeat the enemy which stands in the way of going home to be at rest and safe. There, that is basically the whole plot. It's the details that get laid down that make up the bulk of the movie. Probably typical scenes described by former veterans, all jumbled into one inclusive narrative. This is probably one of the few quarrels I have with this movie. It puts too many typical WWI war  incidents all into one two hours long story.  I had wondered if this tale had any basis in any real life event, but come to find out no, but it "could have happened" is the footing. I mean, if we are watching something outlandish like The Avengers, we know it's all made up make believe science fiction, but when we watch something like this, while  in the back of our minds we think "this could have really happened", it automatically sets you up for a different reaction. The movie's set design all along the way is this film's forte. It's what captures your empathy. If there are any worthy Academy awards to be handed out, it should be for cinematography and set design. When my son saw this movie before I did his review was "you need to see it on a big screen". Yes, that is true. Otherwise you are missing out on the film's primary force. The film has a  sitting on the edge of your seat type of nervous tension as the men go about trying to get to their goal, which is to cross no man's land of enemy territory to get to the ranks of 1600 men's general  about to head into an enemy planned trap, to call off the attack before it's too late. We know they don't have much time to get there, and there will be a lot of possible snares. It's the "snares" that we are watching in real time, at least that is what the movie makers have you perceive. It was supposed to take about 6  hours as stated in the beginning of the mission, but we get to see it all unfold in about 2 hours. 
In the end it's like you just went on a wild thrill ride where you scream at every drop and tense your muscles at every whip turn, only to breathe a sigh of relief as it pulls into the exit gate. Isn't that the goal of the every screenwriter, director, set engineer, actor and actress ? Speaking of such, there's hardly any women in the character list. The one and only female turns out to be an abandoned French girl living in a basement of a blown out building, with nothing other than an orphaned baby that she doesn't even know that she's trying dutifully take care of. And of course, this young woman rises up above all the misery and shows the tender side of humanity that hasn't been lost yet, while she tries to communicate with a non French speaking soldier and give him wound care. We see the soldier respond with likewise compassion when he gives his milk he saved in his canteen for the baby's survival. Here we see translation subtitles for the French dialog.  (I love hearing French spoken since I tried to learn it with 5 years of French classes in school but I'm still not fluent, ….oops I digress)  Okay, that was cliché! I felt like the movie could've done without this part, but then there wouldn't have been any female roles to play at all! Of course the female represents all the opposite attributes of war. It's in fact the men's mothers and sisters they think of, and have pictures of that they hold dearly to their chests, when faced with these dreadful sufferings of war. 
There are a few other cliché's too, like the man angelically singing a folk song in the middle of the woods to the men waiting to go to battle on the next wave of the attack. The main character, Schofield, hears his voice way off in the distance and he follows it to end up in the ranks he wanted to find. Of course, he obtains his primary goal, by the hair of his chinny-chin-chin while we all hold our breath. Everyone in the cinema was silent, I suppose from all the breath holding and lack of oxygen. I stayed until all the credits rolled because I love to hear the score, and I try to read some of the roles, locations, and names whizzing by in rapid tempo. Did you ever bother to notice the score playing at the end of a movie? It's like a nightcap on day's end, or a silk cover of a book being closed. You should really try to stay to the absolute end of the reel's roll the next time you attend the cinema. I always felt that jumping up out of your seat and going back out in the hallway during the credit roll is like skipping the best encore song of a band at a concert so you can get a jump on the traffic! What the heck? Why make the effort and spend the money if you don't even bother to stay to the very end? Your missing out on a part of your experience. You're cutting the movie short and not giving due attention to the whole realm. Of course, if you hated the movie and you were squirming in your pants the whole time waiting to get out of there, the credit roll is your cue to depart, like a dog being let of its leash.
What I did notice in the credits was the numerous names listed for the set design creation. As I said, this is the film's forte. It does it's job of sucking you in and giving you thought provoking after effects. Yes, it is a well crafted movie for experience's sake, and I give it a 7/10 in the end, or with Rotten Tomatoes it's a 3.5 out of 5

War is a brutal and painful for all involved so it is generally a subject that I do like seeing represented on screen as it is either glamorized in a disgusting fashion or is seen in all it's horror and depresses me intensely. Fortunately this film is the second type of film as it does not share the pro-war sentiments of Patton (1970) or The Longest Day (1962) but unlike a classic like The Deer Hunter (1978) it never emotionally grabbed me. The film's primary selling point is the incredible cinematography of the legendary Roger Deakins who makes most of the film seem as though it was filmed in one shot and brings the lovely orange tint that denotes most of his work to the picture.

In April 1917 during World War II the British troops are settled in the Western Front in France and are planning to attack the Germans whom they believe are weak and will be easily overpowered. General Erinmore, Colin Firth, has received word that the Germans have in fact fooled the British and retreated for tactical purposes as they will easily be able to defeat the 1600 British soldiers who will be deployed. He enlists two young soldier, Lance Corporal William Schofield, George MacKay, and Lance Corporal Tom Blake, Dean-Charles Chapman, to inform the soldiers waiting to attack at the Hindenburg Line that they should call off the battle. The two young men struggle to make their way across no man's land and Blake dies in the process lying in his newfound friend's arms. Schofield keeps going but is momentarily diverted in Ecoust Saint-Mein where he is knocked out by the bullet of a German soldier and treated by a French woman who is caring for a child who is not her own. He abandons them and continues on his quest but just barely escapes being shot by several Germans who want to murder him.

Deakins is a master of his craft and that is on display here as he takes a gimmicky idea and makes it work with the film being enhanced by the sense that battle is non-stop and inescapable. Where we would usually cut away from men walking through fields, reminiscing about their fellow soldiers and the silly mistakes they once made this film allows the camera to remain on them. We get an understanding of the boredom that can come with being involved in a war as well as the fear and tension built up by being a few seconds away from death at all time. The boredom and monotony of having to walk over a terrain that seemingly never ends accompanied by one man who you probably do not know all that well is something that many soldiers probably experienced and these dull frustrations only serve to highlight the terror of later scenes of action. When we do reach the bombed out French town that Schofield takes refuge in for a few moments we see the flickering yellow light that will appear every few seconds to illuminate the targets of the German soldiers already settled there before being plunged back into darkness. I did find it funny that the film I was most reminded of while watching Schofield's daring escape from his enemies was The Fugitive (1993) but I have seen few films in which men jump off the top of a waterfall. He is deservedly picking up a lot of accolades for his work and he makes a film that I was otherwise unimpressed with remarkable in some ways.

Beyond the impressive visuals the film is not much to behold however as it's plot is unexceptional and the actors and the screenplay do little to make us care for the young men we follow over nearly two hours. They are fragile and face incredible danger no matter what they do but when we know so little about them it is difficult to see them as valuable people and not just nameless, faceless robotic soldiers. MacKay is a fine actor and gives a good performance in Captain Fantastic (2016) but he does not get enough to work with here to make Schofield a great heroic figure and Chapman is on screen for what feels like so little time that we barely get to know Blake. If the film had put more effort into making me care for these men I would have been emotionally moved and incensed at the fact that so many young men lost their lives because of a meaningless conflict as I should have been.

WWII is the war with sweeping narratives and tales of heroes. WWI is the war with anonymous boys defecating and dying in the mud. 1917 is both a powerful anti-war film and commentary on the history of war films. A seamless take from start to finish, 1917 doesn't have time to inspire us. It doesn't have time to give us real characters. Those who criticize the film for what it lacks story-telling wise fail to appreciate that these "film-making" sacrifices are deliberate -- and necessary in order to create a true-to-life world of war. The "celebrity" cameos -- brief and unexpected parody the war films that came before -- Tom Hanks and John Wayne.

And the world in 1917 is unto itself -- an inversion of Genesis, it is built backwards from death and devastation. Earth -- the mud of No Man's Land; Wind -- the gust of tumbling wood; Fire -- the explosive destruction of machines of war; Water -- ever the way to salvation.

1917 is a gospel of War -- and its visceral brilliance makes it one of the finest ever put to screen.

1917 is a cinematic masterpiece with scenes and sets that immerse audiences into WW1. The story is simple, tense and almost exhausting as the Corporal goes through his mission to get to fellow soldiers on the other side of enemy lines. The setting, cinematography and realistic grit make this movie well worth the watch. As far as the dialogue goes there isn't much, it's also hard to build a connection to any of the characters other than the two main ones. The rest of the cast are merely cameos or blips. There's been some comparison to Saving Private Ryan by some people and I can understand that. That was the first movie that came to mind when I watched as well. In my opinion Saving Private Ryan still reigns as one of the greatest ( if not the greatest) war time cinematic movie of all time. The graphics and details in both movies are amazing, however Saving Private Ryans battle scenes were much more intense and detailed. You can also have a better connection with more character's in SPR. As far as the stories go both are good with Saving Private Ryan having more memorable moments. 1917 definitely cracks the top 10 of great war movies.

1917 is a truly incredible movie that uses impressive cinematography, a convincing but some what predictable story, and (the best part of the film) incredible character development. The story is not the part of the movie director/writer/producer Sam Mendes wants you to focus on. The main focus of this movie is the character development. With incredible inciting incidents that push the characters to new and uncomfortable places, we see some of the finest character development of the year (2019). While the story is not the most incredible tale this generation it is convincing enough. You are told to deliver a message, it may very well save your brother’s life. You can’t use the phone, you must walk a piece of paper to its destination. It’s convincing because setting and time period allows no other way of communicating to the person the message is for. The shots in this film are incredible and show the bloody, deadly, and most importantly destructive nature of war. This is especially highlighted when we are placed into a whole town set on fire and our hero’s must navigate through it without being detected. While meeting the civilians that had gotten stuck between the fighting. In total this movie is for anyone that enjoys a good well put together story with both incredible shots and characters.

'1917' is a monumental cinematic achievement and the definition of "epic". This is certainly a theater-experience for the ages. The idea of a movie all being done in one shot, or at least 'looking' like it was all done in one shot is nothing necessarily new to cinema, and some may even perceive it as gimmicky, which to be honest was a concern of mine going in. Although to my pleasure it instead enhanced the movie experience to a level where I was near-hypnotized, something a war movie has never been able to do for me. Everything from the costume design to the set-pieces and acting were on point, as well as perfect casting and excellent obscure casting choices. Roger Deakins also continues to prove that he is the best movie cinematographer to have ever lived. The movie does an astounding job at involving the viewer, it truly sucks you into the film and its world, and will blow by as the fastest 2 hours you'll ever watch. There's nothing more that I can say, other than you MUST watch this film at some point.

5/5 Stars. This is the best movie that I have seen this year, and the best since another WW1 movie from last year--They Shall Not Grow Old. I wondered about the "single take" perspective and if it would come off as some kind of gimmick; it doesn't. Instead it holds the movie together so well that the absence of the traditional 3 act structure is only really noticed in hindsight. Character choices are in keeping with their personalities and objectives and the acting is strong throughout. There are really nice historical touches, like the hobnail boots and swarms of flies around the dead in no man's land. Because of the unique camerawork, this is a film that needs to be seen on the big screen to be appreciated.

The cinematic style of single shot is so unnerving, it is sure to be copied in future action thrillers. The film shows war as existential, disgusting and wasteful nonsense. It does this with characters who are so insignicant and stupid that attempting to see them as worthy of life just adds to the existential effect. As the U.S. taunts Iran, a film like this has relevance.
