"1917" It is a film, a film that transforms due to its applied technique, with a lint of script, the feature film directed by Sam Mendes conquers the viewer by its visual and technical direction, all simulated in a sequential plane and with a frightening sound mix, the claustrophobic and menacing film takes us on a journey that we will feel in our skin the linearity and terror of a war.

The script is simple and clear, two cables have the mission of taking a message from one point to another, until the success of your object is dubious, because the journey here is worth more than the conclusion, the two cables, lived by the actors George Mackay and Dean-Charles are doing very well, although the film doesn't leave much room for us to contemplate performances, George's few moments of terror and anguish are great.

In addition to a script that serves as an excuse to embark and enjoy a journey, the character developments are simple but profound, but the film puts itself at a pace where it is counterproductive to create depths, and when Sam Mendes does that, he is the only 5 minutes that we disconnected from the film.

The technique of the film is the one that most stands out, simulating a sequential plan of a war movie seems very bold, when "Birdman" did it 5 years ago we were delighted, here, this feeling is even more elevated, care of technique that Sam Mendes had here is something to think about, it is clear that the sequential plans are simulated, we perceive their cuts, however, the long planes conducted are diverse and bold, although many of them are with little action on screen, their conduct is magnificent, with several open plans and a constant contemplation of the disaster, with mutilated bodies, rats and dirt, the disgust and fear is passed on to the viewer who accompanies that narrative stuck in the chair, much because of this narrative conduction and other fundamental aspects too, his composition of scenery, his photography that in certain moments blurs in order to create tension and darkens in planes with strong lighting that turns scenes into horror films, and last, but not least, the sound, everything that surrounds this important component of war film is great, starting with its mixing and ending with its magnificent soundtrack, the composer Thomas Newman abuses classical music and its equalization sound, always with high and progressive tones, in order to lead the viewer to the climax, as an element of horror film.

"1917" is not a cinematic perfection, we have some errors of continuism (which are acceptable in a sequential plan), we also have a problem when the film uses special effects instead of practice, as such effects are very perceptible, even so "1917 "is a spectacular film, very similar to classics such as" Saving Private Ryan "and recent films like" dunkirk ", whose immersion capacity is the same.

Sam Mendes returns to be very prestigious 20 years after his classic "American Beauty" with an extremely technical film and who has everything, even in an extremely busy year to become the highlight of the Oscars and awards. NOTE 9/10

1917 shows a Director who's pushing the boundaries of what a movie can accomplish and it tells a story about a part of our history that doesn't get shown enough in film. It's a visceral and tightly written story about two men's journey two help out others, and that's something that everyone can connect to. Mendes does a great job of placing the viewer right into the action and that's how it separates itself from your average war epic. It didn't hit that upper echelon of movies in the genre that would have been rushing back to the theater to watch it again, but it's one of the best movies of the year for sure.

The visual of one continuous shot throughout the film is a technological achievement to be applauded however, it comes with a price: it never allowss us a reason to care about our main character(s). Trying to attach emotional resonance to characters who are constantly being followed by a GoPro-like camera experience didn't work. There were transitions that didn't make any sense at all which ultimately proved to me that Mendes was fine with sacrificing story for visuals. Richard Madden's two minute appearance at the end was the only compelling acting in the film. How has this film garnered an Oscar nomination?

I heard 1917 was going to be like a film where they film the entire movie in 1 take. Well actually they cut only once so they can change the time of day. Making a film like that can be very difficult and I would want to know how they did it all. Just because a movie has this style doesn't mean it deserves to be graded high. That's like if I did all my math homework for the year on one sheet of paper and got it all right. The movie wasn't that bad, but it is way too slow and takes its time to show off the sets. There were some intense scenes, but again, done too slowly. Also 2 jump scares that didn't need to be there. The music was very good and would probably get it for myself because it is by Thomas Newman who did Passengers; that's why it gets half a star more. If the movie wasn't slow going, then I would have enjoyed it more.

Superb cinematic achievement from Sam Mendes, that gets you into the head of a common soldier during World War I, depicting the heroism and horrors they faced.  The cast is uniformly excellent, much of the weight on the two leads, Dean-Charles Chapman & George MacKay, who perfectly capture the roles of normal soldiers tasked with a near impossible mission.  They get able support from the rest of the cast, many of whom are notable British actors, bringing needed gravitas in their roles.  Behind the camera, Sam Mendes quite possibly makes his best film to date, telling the story in real time and almost looking like one shot, as the two soldiers track across the war front, encountering numerous dangerous and figures along the way.  Its a cinematic achievement in its own right but also helps the story by bringing on the level of the soldiers.  Everything is from their perspective, keeping the tension at a razor edge, along with showing off the brilliant set design and art direction.  Simply put, one of the best war movies in years and probably the best film of 2019.

Considering the overall hype, I guess it was disappointing very predictable, zero character development, unknown actors.  On the plus side excellent cinematography that gives a realistic visceral perception of what trench warfare was actually like.

Tone, rhythm, atmosphere. These are some of the words and concepts that any movie has to take into account when it is executed, and 1917 does it perfectly. From the first 10 minutes you already have an idea of what is coming and the movie prepares you for that.
To avoid spoilers, the movie will take your breath away, it will keep you on the edge of the seat, you will be afraid. The fact that it makes the illusion of having been filmed entirely in one take is simply hypnotizing and makes you feel part of what is happening on screen. You are inside the war. I don't remember many movies about war conflicts that make you feel that way. And... Oh, boy. The score in this is MAGNIIIIFICENT. Beautiful and terrifying when it needs to be. Thunderous appplause for Thomas Newman. Should win the Óscar.

This and Dunkirk were two of the most over-hyped and under-powered films I have seen in the past two years.  In order for a film to hold its audience it has to establish characters that we might care about. No such effort here.  The two protagonists set off on what resembles an extended selfie.  There is no feeling of the claustrophobia experienced in the trenches and the rows of troops huddled along the trench walls served no dramatic purpose apart from hinting at the huge number of soldiers at the front.  I felt that once the director had decided to break the world record for fewest edit points in a movie then he could think of nothing else. The last 20 minutes of the film comprised of a trip in uniform down what appeared to be a cross between Niagara Falls and an Olympic white water canoe course, followed by an extraordinary dash along the top of the trenches during which he appeared to break several land speed records in a remarkably dry uniform.  Benedict Cumberbatch appeared for a few seconds to receive the letter from HQ, and then it was the turn of Richard Madden, fresh from his role as Elton John's manager, appearing as Blake's brother. As we had never properly met the late Blake apart from his quick death scene in a French farmhouse it was not possible to empathize with his brother apart from the usual sympathy one would always extend to people who have suffered loss.  As a war film this was a travesty.  R.C. Sheriff's "Journey's End", and the classic film "All Quiet on the Western Front" are fine examples of movies exploring stories set in WW1 action.  It would serve a far greater purpose if  now  all the box office receipts were given to organisations set up to care for soldiers who have gone through even worse battlefield experiences.

A good solid movie, but not a great one. 

First let's start with the good. This is a beautifully shot movie. I went into the theater expecting the "one track shot" to be distracting and annoying but I actually liked it. 

The authenticity of this movie is outstanding. It looks and feels like WW1. You can tell the team behind the movie did their homework. The scenery, the uniforms, the trenches. It's all top notch. 

Tons of really good moments of intensity and tension. This lasts throughout most of the movie. Actors did a respectable job. Some decent action sequences. 

Now for the bad. 

Not a big fan of the ending. Would've been a better ending for the messenger to go all that way to deliver the message and the commander sends the troops over the top to their deaths anyways. That would've been a very WW1 type of ending that literally personified the senselessness of the war.

There are hardly any battle sequences in the movie. When I go to see a WW1 movie, I'm expecting thousands of men running towards a trench while getting gunned down by enemy machine guns. There's very little of that here. Thus, I would classify it more as a drama, then a war film. 

What made Saving Private Ryan great was the gut wrenching battle scenes that show the true hell of war. To this day, I think of those battles scenes when I remember the movie. In 1917, there's none of that. If there had been at least 1 good battle scene for longer then a couple minutes, then I would label this more then just good. I would label it great. I just think the director missed a big opportunity to show some nasty WW1 combat.

This movie is pure gold. Th acting, directing, cinematography are all outstanding  and you feel like you're with corporal Schofield the whole time and experiencing what he is... I've seen all the other oscar nominees for best picture and this deserves to win.

Just got back from the movie theater. Thank you everyone, who helped me decided on which movie to see. 1917 the story of 2 British soldiers, during the WW1 are given an impossible mission . Beautifully done, The musical score was beautiful to listen to. The storyline was great.  The telling of these  2 young soldiers and their journey into enemy territory was tremendous. The cast of characters was perfect. The 2 young stars of this film, did a tremendous job. They held this movie together. My opinion George MacKay, who played Lance Corporal Schofield. Should haven’t gotten a nomination for acting. Well done! This is a beautiful, tremendous and wonderful piece of filmmaking. This deserves the Oscar nominations and right now it deserves best picture and best director. My rating is 9/10. Go see this movie. Again thank you all for helping me pick a movie. I will do it again, that was fun. 🙏🏻#1917movie #ww1 #sammendes

I loved this movie; war movies get better and better each year. The cinematography is really what sold it and it was a very immersive movie. It had a good blend of classic war movie tropes/cliches as well as new ideas and twists that weren't expected. The idea of giving a movie the illusion of a single take is such a new and interesting concept; it makes you feel more connected to the current scene and characters, and especially for historical war movies, it gives you a good sense of distance and physical/geographical perspective.

I may have misunderstood or missed points of the plot however I have the following observations/queries:-

Why would lowly lance corporals be entrusted with such an important task?  Surly it would be an officer with at least a section or more likely a platoon for protection. 

How did an infantry battalions find itself intact and able to mount a planned fresh attack so far in advance of the main battle area, amidst green rolling hills? - not feasible in 1917 - perhaps in late 1918. 

Why would the Germans abandon their trenches just to lure to destruction, or ambush in the film makers vernacular, a solitary infantry battalion? 

Why did the two lance corporals have to undertake a risky daylight crossing of No Man's Land and negotiate booby trapped subterranean enemy positions to get to a point which was easily accessible by road to an officer in a staff car and lorry born infantry? 

How did the solitary lance corporal locate the enemy sniper, shoot and wound  him at the canal crossing scene?  The sniper, who was a very poor marksman, was concealed above him behind a solid wall in a darkened room wearing a helmet. To have hit him he would have had to have put a bullet through his head which is generally fatal or at least incapacitating.  A man so wounded would not draw his trusty Luger and sit waiting for his assailant to pop by to finish him off.

Why would he enter the sniper's building, albeit very cautiously, when he didn't know if there were shed loads of enemy present?  Surly, in view of his vital mission, he would vacate the area as rapidly as possible using cover in the direction of the 2nd Devons not risk a gun fight with myriad enemies? 

This begs the question how did he navigate?  He was behind what had been the German frontline in unfamiliar territory. Earlier he had a map which was discarded because it was soaked in his comrades blood. Which begs the question what, in 1917, did lance corporals know of map reading?  I tend to think in most units such things were untrusted to officers. However once again I stand to be corrected. 

Having located the second wave of 2nd Devons, a scene of melodic & bucolic unlikeliness, he then enters an apparently British communication trench leading to an apparently British front line in the middle of the enemies old rear area.  Who dug this trench system so quickly?   What is happening either side of this isolated battalion?  Presumable, as they are so far in advance of the 18th Division's front line, they are flanked by Germans.  They're  not even in a salient linked either side to the British front line.   If that was the case then the attack cancellation message could have been passed along from units on their flanks. 

There's probably more I didn't notice but the above will do for now to register my discontent.

The only reason I saw this movie is because this movie won the golden globe for best drama so this movie is basically going to win the Oscar. And man this movie got me. I cared so much for the two main guys and I wanted them to make it so bad. And then the movie pulled the thing that I knew they were going to do but I didn’t know when they would. But hold on why the flip is the two main guys not nominated for an Oscar. I know they’re basically nobodies but still, their performances are some of the best I’ve seen this year. Oscars make no sense. The cinematography is also beautiful and also deserves the Oscar. I was legit on the edge of my seat watching this movie and man this movie already has an iconic scene. That running scene that’s in the trailers just a little bit but in the movie you’re rooting for him. It’s a full rocky moment right there. And also this movie feels like the most stressful video game in the world aka war so hopefully we don’t get into any wars in the future. Final thought and little criticism, when Sam mendes at the golden globes said this movie is shot in one take fake news it is. I can clearly tell when they took a break and I know it’s basically impossible to film an entire shot in one take but he tried and failed so stop promoting it then. But besides that this is a Great War movie that I never expected to be worth my time. I’ll maybe watch this movie again if it’s on ITunes for 4 bucks.

Rather than feeling like a gimmick, the ‘single shot' impression sucks you into the movie, making you feel as if you are trudging through the muddy trenches, gasping for air, and dodging bullets alongside Blake and Schofield. 
Having heard of this stratagem before the viewing, I was expecting my ADD brain to be distracted by trying to spot the odd furphy or sly transition - instead I was sucked straight into the story like a boot in foot deep crater mud. 
It is a stunning achievement by the filmmakers and cast. I don't think I have seen anything quite like it, I was deeply impressed. Deakins and Mendes could have made a cracking story with the usual cuts and transitions, but some men live for the fight...
I will be definitely going back for a second viewing.

1917 está dirigida por Sam Mendes y está protagonizada por George MacKay y Dean- Charles Chapman.

1917 nos cuenta la historia de Lance Schofield y su amigo Blake, quienes son encargados de llevar un mensaje al general Mackenzie para que detenga un ataque que tienen planeado.

Ok... ¿por donde empezar?, voy a empezar por la fotografía, hecha por Roger Deakins, es bastante impresionante en muchas escenas, pero en otras es básicamente seguir a los personajes, lo cual está bastante normal en una película de una sola toma, aún que en esas escenas donde solo siguen a los personajes la fotografía es buena. Otra cosa que ayuda mucho a la fotografía es el diseño de producción, el cual es bastante bueno también.

La Banda sonora, me gustó bastante, Thomas Newman que ha sido nominado muchísimas veces al Oscar hace un gran trabajo, antes de la temporada de premios parecía que se iba a llevar la estatuilla, peor las cosas cambiaron. Es épica, te conmueve, te emociona, aumenta la tensión en las escenas tensas, si gana la verdad es que no me molestaría para nada.

Las actuaciones, son buenas, en especial George MacKay, hace un gran trabajo, y también los demás actores, pero no tienen tanto tiempo en pantalla como George. Dos de los grandes nombres, Benedict Cumberbatch y Richard Madden no salen mucho en la pelicula, lo cual es un poco decepcionante. 

El guion está bien, no es el punto más fuerte de la película, pero funciona, los diálogos están bien, hay muy poca exposición, y los personajes están bien escritos.

La película no tiene muchas escenas de acción, si entran a verla esperando una película con muchísima acción y explosiones, probablemente terminen decepcionados. 

Otro punto negativo es que en lo personal en algunas partes sentí la película lenta.
Técnicamente es la mejor película del año.

En general es una gran película, con un guion que funciona, una gran fotografía y Banda sonora y buenas actuaciones y muy buena dirección por parte de Sam Mendes,

WWI was sold by the US-Britiish empires as "The War to End All Wars". And so millions sacrificed their lives/health. The lie was evident at the armistice when all parties rejected Wilson's plea for "open covent of peace, openly arrived at". Why secret deals? Because government fight wars for private gain, not public. 
The carnage was avoidable if a little common sense was used. It wasn't. Why? Generals don't fight with the men, don't die when they make incredibly stupid mistakes, over and over again, e.g., charging machine gun nests with the loss of hundreds or thousands at a time. All this could have been shown in the movie but it wasn't. This so-called anti-war movie was like war, a waste.

1917 is a jaw-dropping experience that puts you right into the trenches of WW1.

Two soldiers are tasked with an impossible suicide mission - traverse the dreaded No Mans Land and enemy territory to stop an attack that is heading into a carefully prepared trap.

The stakes are raised that much higher by the fact that one of the soldiers has an older brother officer who is leading part of the attack.

Along the way, they must face the absolute horrors of the WW1 battlefield, as well as carefully laid traps waiting for them and the enemy themselves who are still lurking about.

The movie is amped up further by the 'one continuous shot' perspective.  The camera goes on and on in sweeping arcs for minutes at a time, and you find yourself holding your breath as the tension builds!

The cinematography is EXCELLENT, easily the best of 2019.  This is a MUST SEE in the theatres, in the best screen you can find.

The acting is also top notch.  If I could quibble on one minor detail, the scale of the war is not captured by this mission, as the loss of 1600 men would not even be considered as anything worth bothering over, with battles routinely losing 50,000 men a day.
Mendes' single shot perspective was captivating.  The camera dragged you into the devastation of war from a soldier's perspective.
All people need go to see that great movie.

In the end, I left feeling...not bad...but not something I'm enthusiastically telling people to see.

Spoiler Alert!
Pros: The score and visuals are pretty good. I like the idea that two boys have to give a message to Tom's brother Joseph or else 1600 people would die. Tom's death is very sad and emotional and unexpected.  The visuals are pretty great and they have some amazing war aspects and the aspect of these guys may not come back from the war.  After Tom's death, I was very interested in the plot. There are many great scenes like when Will(The main character) meets a baby and tells her a story and gives her some milk and that is one of my favorite scenes in the movie. I like the scene where he was in this broken town and he was running for his life and even though I knew he was probably going to survive there were moments where I thought Will would die.  The movie gets really great in the third act. He has to give a message to Colonel Mackenzie to stop the attack and the way it was executed was handled very well. I like the scene where he is running away from the battle while everyone is about to fight the Germans.  I really like the Benedict Cumberbatch Cameo as Colonel Mackenzie and when the battle stops and Will meets Joseph is a great scene with great acting and emotion. The thing I like about this movie si that the story is what stands out to me and not the action.  

Cons: The first 30-40 minutes were boring because Tom and Will were just walking around. Sure there may have been good parts like the plan and the explosion and Tom saving Will but it isn't really much else and it was too long for them to be sneaking around. I also think that the time gaps could have been handled better because it felt a bit like a dream sequence.  I can also sometimes realize some choppy CGI because I could usually tell that they used it on a tree or a rock. 

I still think that this is a beautifully made film and I'm gonna give it an (A-)

Disappointing. A Sam Mendes family fireside tale hits the big screen and extends the last 10 minutes of Peter Weir's movie "Gallipoli" into 120.
If you like costume, scenery and first person camerawork which relentlessly follows 2 characters from point A to point B then this is probably the film for you. Although the film is 120 minutes long (so you know he's going to make it in the end) suspense and tension are kept alive as you wonder when is the little, mouthy fat one going to get it? Once his friend expires and the character is simply left to complete his mission then it may as well be a video game since there is no one left for us to care for. 
This movie feels more like an exercise in camera technique than a narrative film. There are some wonderful shots though such as watching characters go from close up to wide as they cross a waterlogged bombed out crater whilst the camera tracks them from the other side only to join them again on the other side. Or entering a bombed out town at night lit by fire and flares or running through dust filled lam lit corridors.
But the film is like watching an Xbox game unfold as the  character goes from level to level before they get to their missions final objective.
Nina Golds casting is excellent as she tries to fill the screen with enough actors and extras to cover the cameras movement. Costume and set are excellent. The only thing missing is narrative. The characters are so thinly drawn it is a lot like playing battle of Honour or call of duty on a console with the voice overs thrown in.
There are better films out there whose narrative is a lot more engaging than this film which had me looking at the exit a few times. I recommend instead Gallipoli, Attack, Remember the Spartans and A Bridge Too Far.
I realized why I didn't connect to this as much as Gallipoli. I think it's because with Gallipoli and bridge too far you spend 60 minutes getting to know the characters in different situations so that when the final battle or run occurs you really feel for them before they make their final stand. In 1917 the character  is already running  so you don't really get that in depth picture of them over all. you are learning about them as they run and for some reason it doesn't work here as well as "Naked Prey." In "1917" it is  the cinematography that takes centre stage and you're watching that first and then the character and for me that seems to distance me from the character and empathy with what is going on.

A massive technical achievement in film making. The entire film is shot in a way giving an illusion of a single take, and to mesmerising effect. This technique creates a real intimacy with the characters; and really makes you feel that the audience is the third soldier on this mission and fully immerses you in a WW1 torn France. It's a testament to how well the film is edited. The cinematography, set design, music, and sound design are all exceptional (all categories it has received Oscar nominations for - also a Best Film nomination). The film is beautifully paced - there are intentional drawn out quiet scenes in between the action beats which gives the film a great cadence and gives it necessary time to breathe. This is a must see on the big screen; and fully deserves its Best Film nomination.

Technically, I thought 1917 was an exceptional film. The cinematography, editing and special effects were first rate. However, the story line seem to plod along at times. For example, the scene where George MacKay's character is moving endlessly through the trenches trying to find the the colonel was like watching paint dry. I understand the reasoning behind the "one camera" filming technique, but at times it just simply served to significantly slow down the pace of the movie.  It was also distracting that I only able to understand about half the dialogue because of a combination of low sound quality and the the thick British accent spoken by most of the cast. Normally, I find war dramas very absorbing (Saving Private Ryan being one of my all time favorite films). But 1917 had me looking at my watch more than once during the last 30 minutes.

There are a ton of things that make this film great: immersive environments that show you the horrors of warfare, a promising & compelling story that keeps you invested as well as fantastic cinematography that makes the film feel powerful and jaw-dropping overall. While I was deeply moved by the quality of the film and the powerful soundtrack to go along with it, 1917 isn't as perfect as the trailer or the accolades would have you believe. There are several moments that feel underwhelming which take away from the raw power the film provides, there is far less action as well so this feels like more of a historical visual piece rather than the all-out action war films we are used to seeing.

1917 is an intense, wonderfully shot war movie that was written and directed by Sam Mendes. The movie is about two soldiers (Dean-Charles Chapman) and (George Mackay) must go deep behind enemy lines to deliver a message to save 1,600 soldiers. 1917 is an excellently shot film where the director tries to make the entire movie look like it was all in one take with no cuts. This was pulled off exceptionally well. The movie also does a great job at showing how deary war can be and it shows in this film. The settings of this film where also phenomenal and felt so perfect. My complaints for the film would be that there wasn't much connection to George Mackays character and I felt I knew nothing about him. The film is great! I definitely recommend it! Utilizing a simple linear narrative structure inspired by his grandfather's stories during WW1 in which two young soldiers are tasked with delivering a life-or-death message across no man's land crawling with enemy combatants and other unknown dangers, Sam Mendes delivers a breathtaking, intense and immersive cinematic experience that's rightfully Oscar-worthy. Wisely presenting the film as one seemingly continuous shot, it wretches up tension and put the audience right next to the central characters for 2 full hours to unforgettable and tremendous effect. This technical challenge aptly showcases the collaborative efforts of Mendes' directing and Roger Deakins' cinematography as their meticulously composed visuals discover beauty and poetry in devastation and desolation. Equally impressive is the way Mendes, in his first writing credit, finds depth and humanity in an often wordless script that follows their journey without falling into contrivances or repetition. If there are minor quibbles, there is one less than totally smooth transition from one tragic incident into the next episode of the narrative that will require a bit more suspension of disbelief. There are also times when the film moves a little close to sentimentality and emotional manipulation but it would seem churlish to criticize either the script or Thomas Newman's sweeping score when it was done so beautifully and brilliantly. Dean-Charles Chapman and George MacKay's performances are convincing and, at times, heartbreaking, and they prove they are worthy up-and-comers, whilst a litany of glorified cameos by Mendes's famous chums / more familiar British actors help guide the lesser known leads along with their starry presence. Perfectly orchestrated with military precision, Mendes's films stands proudly on its own as a taut and visceral thriller as well as an historical drama that honours the past and reminds us of the cruelty and pointlessness of war.

1917 is an intriguing film.  As many are aware, the film is shot in a seamless "single-take" shot. Of course, it's actually a number of long takes cleverly stitched together. This gimmick works very well.  The story is very basic. Two soldiers are tasked to cross a WW1 battlefield to warn military division of a trap.  That's it! The camera always follows them.  The single take approach puts you right there with them, as if you were a third soldier.  What makes it effective, is that the camera is always at their level.  It's quite the achievement considering how tumultuous the battlefield is.  And like war, the action flips between, action, nothing going on, or distant action.  The attention to detail is quite remarkable.  The cinematography is excellent. Definitely in my top 10 this year.

Sorry, I don't see what the fuss is about. Chapman and Mackay are great in their roles, Mackay deserving of a few awards although he wears that harrowed/haunted visage that he's famous for throughout (understandable here). The story is cobbled together, this year's crop of movies have a few "box-ticking" scripts ("Sorry we missed you" being a fine example, where a load of different people's stories are put together as a list and "hey, let's make a story out of that". Doesn't work for me. There's enough major/single/human story WW1 material that hasn't been addressed yet, you don't need to create a confection like this. Along with a number of less than convincing special effects and a half-baked "phoned-in" score from Thomas Newman that has to be one of his weakest yet and some distracting walk on parts from Mendes's famous mates that sadly come across as tired and timeworn stereotypes at us. The "whole movie is a single shot" conceit, is for industry insiders to giggle at. I noticed it for the first 10 minutes, thought it to be awards bait and stopped seeing it after that. It's OK this film, but after Peter Jackson's "They shall not grow old" it was perhaps a mistake to not wait a bit before putting this out. Maybe using that extra time to craft the story a bit more skillfully and to find bit part actors who are a bit less well known, there are plenty of good ones who need the work!

1917 (2019) This film did not show gas, too many tanks. We saw a abandoned tank but nothing more than that. This film showered the dangers barbed wire had to soldiers and the extremes of barbed wire. This film showed how Germans would kill Cows or destroy armaments and set booby traps. I never seen terrain alter so much in a film. I have never seen a World War I Film like this film. This was so unique in that you never saw but one clear cut. Dog food left in bags so rats would eat it and leave as a trap I just saw 1917. I have never seen a War film or a Great War aka World War I Film like 1917. It is so unique in how the terrain would alter so much within short distances. The trenches even in films like Sergeant York (1941), Young Indiana Jones chronicles (season 2), Fly Boys (2006), War Horse (2011), They Shall not Grow Old (2018), Wonder Woman (2017), just to name a few War films do not give the scariness and give you the feeling of distance, size and time to go between the lines like 1917 does. Sergeant York (1941) is probably the closest I have seen to this comparison of the trenches in 1917 and Young Indiana Jones season 2. This film provides a unique aspect of the Great War showing the amount of men, how the battlefield terrain could change so quickly. The soldiers life from one part to the next or from one moment to the next and how a soldiers state of mind and thinking could alter from one moment to the next. The dangers, music score, Sound effects, silence were used very well to guide the tensions and feelings of the film from one moment to the next. This film showed the different War technics and thinking each side had during this war and how many would not listen even when they received order to attack or surrender or even how superiors thought.

A technical marvel and a cinematic wonder...I departed the theater in awe, to say the least. Arguably the most impressive feat in the film is, yes, indeed, the entire film IS shot and edited to appear as one long, continuous, seamless take (well, except for one obvious cut mid-way through serving to represent the passage of several hours), and it is a fascinatingly convincing piece of work. I played a sort of game with myself during the movie to pick out all the parts where cuts could have been made before editor magic basically erased all traces of them (quite a fun game actually, and challenging.....I'm a nerd — I like this sort of stuff). Open to debate as being even more spectacular than the technical aspects is the actual content of the film — just...lavishly layered, riddled with sounds, images, emotions, situations, conversations, intensity, calmness, accenting the big things, little things, drawing literal and metaphorical lines between death, life, hope, perseverance...Many of these things are presented simultaneously throughout the film, cascading breathlessly into a tidal wave experience that is altogether just absolutely...consuming (it's hard to put accurately into words; just watch it). This is one of those movies that you can start watching at any point, and you're hooked instantly, unable to turn away until the end. Unforgettable. From what I've seen, there's no war film quite like it.....no film quite like it, period.

1917 (4 out of 5 stars). 1917 is one of a king epic war film which puts you right with the characters Will (George MacKay) and Tom (Dean-Charles Chapman) as they travel through the battlefield. Director Sam Mendes is trying to achieve something with his direction, long camera shot continuation, and a wonderful music score by Thomas Newman. The film does well in capturing the realism and raw tone of war. The silence in walking through a mineshaft. The enemy firing at you and hearing the bullet ricocheting. Or an enemy charging at you. The audience is put right next to these soldiers as they cross enemy territory. The plot follows Will and Tom as they are assigned by their captain to cross no mans land and to warn the other battalion that they are about to fall into a trap from their enemy. It is a race against time that they will have to walk a far distance in less than a day. While watching out and avoiding their enemy. Director Sam Mendes does well in capturing a still camera shot. Mendes does not over do it like other action film directors with adding a lot of unnecessary action or explosions. He does capture the realism and raw tone of the movie. I like that he is trying to break the ground barrier with a one long continuation shot with the camera. Sure, there may be a scene cut somewhere. The editors did a great job in keeping the camera shots and direction very coherent without breaking away from a scene. It is kind of distracting. It works great with the movie. The opening scene following Will and Tom from their captain being told their assignment. To walking through the trenches around the soldiers. The cinematography by Roger Deakins did a great job in following these characters. And capturing the production set with torn down villages. Or a gritty aftermath of the battlefield with corpses on barb wires. It is just impressive. Lee Smith editing was well done in keeping the one long shot focused. The music score by Thomas Newman was beautifully done and haunting in a way. George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman were also good with their characters. We learn a little about them as they talk about their history as they walk through no mans land. Plus there are other actors in here with a small appearance like Mark Strong, Andrew Scott, Colin Firth, Claire Duburcq, Richard Madden, and Benedict Cumberbatch. My one issue with the film which I dislike about it is the pacing. It is nice to see a one shot sequence with the cinematography following the characters without cutting scene to another. Basically, you're with the characters every foot step they make. Which is cool and all but it does get a little slow when they walking a long way in a field or come to a complete pause. Overall, 1917 is a good war film done by Sam Mendes and his sharp beautiful direction. With a good music composer, editor, cinematography, and cast. It is one film that is worth seeing on the big screen.

I’ve never felt so immersed while watching a film. Not only was I invested in the character’s journey, I felt as if I was there beside them: living, breathing, and walking every step of the way with them. This isn’t your typical war film in the sense that the film plays out more or less in real time. Sam Mendes tells a relatively simple but moving story here in the best way possible, with flawless execution. The event was ultimately inconsequential in terms of history, but in terms of story and humanity, 1917 makes you feel for these men in a way that makes you want them to succeed in their mission. It’s not a matter of numbers or victory, it’s a matter of saving somebody. Putting a face to the number, and in this case, that face is his brother, who is developed as a character before we even see him on screen. Roger Deakins brings the trenches to life with his outstanding cinematography as usual. However, the best part about the cinematography in this movie is that it doesn’t detract from the story, it improves upon it. The ‘all one take’ gimmick is not a gimmick here—it’s a creative choice that serves the story by never giving the audience a break, just like the soldiers. The intensive 4 months of rehearsal days really shows in the final product. The hard work put in by both the actors and camera crew is unparalleled. In short, 1917 succeeds in telling a tale of humanity in an otherwise gruesome world—and bringing the audience into that world in a seamless and hard-hitting way.

However, for the more quieter moments, it can become distracting. The cinematography from Roger Deakins is amazing as usual. The film is stunning to look at. The weakest part of the film for me is the script. The film doesn’t do enough to get you invested in the characters. You care about the situation, but not the people in it. Overall, this is still a good movie. I definitely liked it, just a lot less than most people.

Technically, this is one of the greatest things I've witnessed at the cinema. The camera continuously tracks the leads, refusing to relent, in a way that makes it appear as though the film is done in one shot. This has a impressive effect on the viewer: we feel like we're involved in the action, but paradoxically looking in on it at the same time. It's an immersive experience. Perhaps, however, this technical wizardry may leave some people finding the film too clinical.

The production design is superb, from the labyrinthine trenches to the hellish, desolate no man's land. It's not just visually impressive but acoustically, too, with top-class sound mixing and a brilliant versatile score. The two aspects combine to provide a incredibly visceral experience. 

Although it features surprisingly few actual battle sequences, the film maintains a quick pace and is frequently both tense and intense. But the quieter moments of the film are equally hard-hitting, such as a later scene which sees the soldiers resting before their planned attack, whilst one of them sings The Wayfaring Stranger. It's hauntingly beautiful.

'1917' is a masterpiece - epic, immersive, and poignant - and deserves to stand in the pantheon of greatest war films ever made.

"The Messenger's Travels"

	Sam Mendes crafts a spectacularly unique war film unlike any other that refuses to relish in its combat and violence, but instead, tells its audience an emotionally captivating story through its depiction of the gritty and raw nature of unforgiving war. Legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins works to capture every visceral frame of the film and works with Thomas Newman as he constructs a potent orchestral soundtrack that perfectly underscores every moment throughout the two hour runtime. Not a single performer on screen pulls any of their punches as everyone delivers Mendes' tight script with a pure focus that sells every scene. "1917" is an astonishing achievement in filmmaking on all fronts that will undoubtedly be recognized and studied for years to come.
	The story of "1917" is one of fiction that is derived from the real world stories of the world's Great War. We start by getting introduced to our central protagonists, Lance Corporal Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Lance Corporal Schofield (George MacKay) as they are handpicked by General Erinmore (Colin Firth) for a mission of the utmost importance. The mission requires that both soldiers make their way to the 2nd Battalion of the Devonshire Regiment and relay a message to call off the assault on the supposed "retreating" German forces within the next twenty-four hours; if they fail, the battalion will be slaughtered and thousands of men will be lost. With the stage set and stakes known, both men embark on an arduous trek across the invaded lands of northern France making their way through an assortment of environments across the span of a single day.
	"1917" is a film that features a good plot, but not a great one; if anything it comes across as thin.. However, Mendes and Krysty WIlson-Cairns' script does include several moments that seamlessly flow from one to the next and keep the momentum of the story moving forward, while most importantly, leaving long and somber sequences for the film and the audience to breathe giving room for reflection. One of the script's greatest strengths is its pointed dialogue that says so much with so little. The performers do an excellent job to enhance the script by delivering their lines in a way that evokes a natural sense of emotion that resonates deeply with the audience. From the very start, both Chapman and MacKay come across as genuinely being close friends. We instantly buy into their relationship because every exchange the two gentleman have serves to further build their on-screen chemistry. In one of the film's earliest set pieces, Chapman and MacKay brilliantly convey their companionship as one that could be classified as a younger brother/older brother dynamic where Chapman's inexperience in the field is starkly contrasted to that of MacKay's calm demeanor; every step of the way the two are challenged and we witness their different reactions to a multitude of circumstances that further display their individual intricacies. With that being said, MacKay pulls out a true stand out performance as Schofield within this film. MacKay delivers an absolutely transformative performance that will keep you enthralled from beginning to end; it is a true presentation of skill that should not be overlooked.
	You can not discuss "1917" without speaking on the pre-production and execution of this film. Mendes took up the insurmountable challenge to shoot the entire film with the illusion of one continuous single shot (Despite the fact that a keen eye can spot where some of the cuts occur). The significance of the mission is known to both the cast and audience, so crafting this film with a single shot in mind is brilliant because as the passage of time moves forward, we stay on the edge of our seats knowing that with the exclusion of obvious cuts, the film is forced to keep pushing onward. All hands were on deck as the production team sculpted miniature sets to test their lighting rigs and get a direct layout of what needed to be accomplished. A dedicated team of designers were painstakingly tasked with bringing every "1917" set to life; and it pays off. With the knowledge of what track the camera was to follow and dozens of rehearsals, "1917" pulled off what most would not dare to try. When the actors are moving throughout these diverse environmental sets, every segment of the frame is packed to establish a dirty, yet natural world that is as beautiful as it is immersive. Whether it is an object in the background or a character in the foreground, David Crossman, Jacqueline Durran, Dennis Gassner, Lee Sandales, and Robert Voysey come together to create a world that is accurate to the times and precisely encapsulates the depressing realities of the First World War. The technical aspects that help shape "1917" into the marvelous film it is, serve as a reminder of the lengths a focused group of immensely talented people will go to create the best piece of work they possibly can and it should not go unnoticed.
	"1917" is an enchantingly tense piece of art that straps you in and never lets go until the final cut to black. Mendes along with the entire cast and crew craft a truly immersive experience that paints the art of war as not one of bombastic explosions and blood, but one of fear, disarray and raw emotional weight that burdens every soldier on the battlefield. "1917" may not have the most engaging story to tell, but it does not need it; the way in which the film was made and shot is a triumph on its own that many can look to and see that an inspired group united to create a powerful work of art that will be talked about for going above and beyond its genre. "1917" is without a doubt, one of Sam Mendes' finest pieces of work.

Final Verdict: B-

The movie was about a young man getting a message to an Army Commander to stop an invasion- and thats exactly what it was and nothing more.

Lance Corporal Blake and Lance Corporal Schofield take on mission impossible when they are tasked with delivering a message to the 2nd Battalion of the Devonshire Regiment who believe they have the German army on the run when in fact aerial photography has revealed they are walking into a trap. So begins a race against time across enemy territory as the 2 friends rush to deliver the message to call off the attack, hopefully saving the lives of 1600 men, including Blake's brother. 
I thought 1917 was a superb achievement, it is beautifully filmed, well acted and has scenes of sweaty palm inducing tension.  There is one stand out scene that takes place at night time in a bombed out village still occupied by German soldiers.  The way this scene is filmed, the use of lighting and the music will stay with me for a long time, one of the most tense scenes ever committed to film.  Great story, superb film with a stand out performance from George Mackay. Would definitely watch again.

These two solders are approaching enemy lines and are walking and talking in a normal tone of voice like they are on a walk in the park.  I have seen 2000 pound bomb craters up close in Vietnam and the bomb craters in this film were unrealistically huge for this era.  An amateurish poorly told story with a very anti-war/military bent.  None of the solders who encountered these exhausted hungry messengers offered them anything or expressed concern.  Solders do not act like that, they would have immediately asked about what unit they were from, what their mission was and offered assistance.  Just a Hollywood propaganda film about a subject they know nothing about.  Not worth the price of admission

Saw 1917 & it's the Best Picture of the Year!, Absolutely Phenomenal movie, I've seen all the previous nominated movies and there is none better than 1917, visually stunning in everyway, cinematography excellent perfect Balance of drama & suspense, and the entire movie filmed in one shot 🤯, I remember seeing a Underrated film on Netflix called The OutLaw King which I liked a lot, in that film the opening scene is shot in one shot and it was the first of it's kind but that's only the opening scene, but whats incredible about 1917 it is filmed entirely in one shot, it is incredible, the best war films when you break it down that I have ever seen from depth of story telling to action has been Saving Private Ryan, Hacksaw Ridge and now 1917,what's crazy is that 1917 doesn't even really have a war battle scene, it's mostly suspense and intense scenes with a couple of shootouts yet it's still one of the greatest Cinematic war films of alltime, it's definitely the Best Picture of The Year or it darn right should be, 4/4⭐️s, A+, 9/10 for 1917 it Should receive best picture & Director Oscars forsure.

There's been a lot of "epic" or "blockbuster" war films. Films like Saving Private Ryan, Black Hawk Down, Platoon, Dunkirk, Pearl Harbor, etc. These films focused on heroics, grand scale battles, well known actors, and some even had great stories. Then comes 1917, which is a simple plot, yet a full immersive experience the likes I haven't felt in a while. 

1917 feels like you're part of the mission. You feel every sound, movement, and decisions made in the film. How is this achieved? The movie was shot to appear like it's one long take, with "no cuts." The camera follows our two protagonists from many angles, but there's "never" a cut in the action. You'll sometimes wonder just how the hell certain angles were achieved.  The camera follows the events happening from beginning to end, it is truly an amazing cinematic achievement.

The camera goes from 3rd person view to full 360 shots, to even shots where our characters haven't even seen what's up ahead. All with no edits, all one fluid motion. Obviously, there's some camera magic involved, but I don't care to know about it. All I know that audiences will literally feel like they are part of this mission. For this reason,  I recommend to splurge on premium formats like Dolby Cinema, RPX, IMAX, D-box, or 4DX. This movie should be experienced to it's full potential.

The main cast does a fantastic job with George MacKay and Dean Charles-Chapman leading the way with using every possible emotion available. You really do feel for these characters. All the tension, fear, anger, regret, happiness is felt along with them. 

I do have one warning: if you need there to be a lot of battle action going on in your war films, this is not the movie for you. This movie focuses on survival, stealth, and getting the mission completed at all costs. Do not expect huge battle scenes, but the tense action scenes are there to advance the story when need be.

This is truly an amazing work of art from director Sam Mendes (he won an Oscar for American Beauty 20 yrs ago) and award winning cinematographer Roger Deakins. I would put this film right next to Saving Private Ryan. It already won at the  Golden Globes, wouldn't be surprised if it wins an Oscar as well. Again go see this in a premium format to truly enjoy it.

FINAL REVIEW: 9.5 out of 10.

1917 was a good movie. While I didn't think it was the masterpiece that others believe it is, I still really enjoyed seeing it. I mean seriously, the cinematography. It was great! I loved the idea of a long, continuous shot through editing and creative liberty, and it made the movie feel much more unique. Also I really liked the big action set pieces, the production design, and the acting. all great things on those fronts. But this movie shows itself as weaker in its story and plot. While I think the script to the movie is good, there's nothing special to the main story of this movie. I'll be it, it does set up some cool ideas for scenes in the future, but I really feel like these scenes are mostly made special from the camera, and not really their ideas. I just feel like this movie was made more for the production than the actual plot, and I really think more thought should've been put into this aspect, and this movie would have a lot less stereotypes and be a much better movie overall. Still recommend it as a fun movie to watch, but it's not the best thing out there.

Award-winning director Sam Mendes based 1917's premise on his grandfather's story-- a family lore that centred on a messenger delivering an important message in the Great War, a war that was supposed to last a few weeks.  Paired with the inimitable cinematographer Roger Deakins, the pair cast the audience deep in immersion in a fluid single-take camerawork and created a very visually enthralling film-making masterpiece. 

Billed as such, the camera never ceased except for one noticeable cut in the third act and almost showed its seams but Roger Deakins' hand is firm and sure. This is nothing new in film-making; Alejandro González Iñárritu's Birdman is one of those films. Some feature extended long takes like the famous long take in Alfonso Cuarón's Children of Men or more recently The Revenant by Iñárritu again. 

The difference here is Deakins. 1917 quite literally is Best Cinematography at the bare minimum. The white-haired one brought home the Cinematography prize for his brilliant work in Blade Runner 2049. Sam Mendes looks set to win Oscar's Best Director as he had in the recent Golden Globe. 

The film's colour palette is reminiscent of colourized black-and-white World War 1 photographs and Deakins having his utter disdain for green-screens and CGI, showcased his technical ability and brilliance in every frame. Cynics may say it feels arcade-y given the exhaustive length of camerawork but the third-person effect thrust the viewer alongside the characters. I must admit I feel for George MacKay's character, Schofield, (almost criminal how he received no recognition for his stunning portrayal) how must exhausted he must be.

The film begins with lush greenery as soldiers rest in perhaps a homage to All Quiet on the Western Front opening chapter in Erich Maria Remarque's timeless war classic. Blake (played by Dean-Charles Chapman) with Schofield are tasked to be messengers, given that the radio lines are cut, to deliver a message out to stop an attack scheduled the following morning. A German retreat is in fact an organised trap for their pursuers and both messengers must reach the pursuing battalion and halt the attack. 

I must caution those who enjoy combat and over-the-top explosive sequences, 1917 is not an action-flick. It is something else. It is a depiction of what soldiers experience in war and heroes are never in flowing capes. Mendes never cease to show us what our earth was like through the soldier's eye-- beautiful lush landscape in a brief respite as soldiers rest, trepidation as they head through the trenches, fear in a burning, decimated town and adrenalin in the battlefield-- all of which in unending flowing sequence. Chapman and Mackay's delivery in their roles are worthy of mention, the latter delivered in spades. Even those in small roles played their part very well. 

The overall result is a film that encapsulates a harrowing experience, thrusting the viewer in the visceral hellscapes of war, imprinting a profound memory in those who are willing to partake in the sensories of historical man-made catastrophes. 1917 is an astonishing film which I had the opportunity to enjoy at the IMAX theatre. Go and see it.

I really enjoyed the storytelling in the movie with the one shot technique. It captured the hardship and emotion that the soldiers had to face just to deliver a message, especially knowing that it would save 1,000+ people. The start of the film felt like I was playing a Call of Duty Campaign, but it was a great way to introduce the tone of the film as the two men walk through the trenches and you see what all the extra soldiers are doing to keep themselves distracted. I thought that the score was really well put together with the pacing of the film and mixed really well to the storytelling of the film.

I disliked how the trailer showed the climax of the film, showing Schofields running out in the open as the first wave runs out and attacked. I also felt like some of the sound effects that were added to film was really poor. One example in particular was the sniper shots when Schofields was crossing the broken down bridge, it didn't sound menacing or endangering, it could have made the scene more suspenseful.

In the end, I recommend for everyone to watch this film, keeping in mind of the one shot technique. On piece of dialogue I really  took notice of was when Schofields was talking about trading his medal for a bottle of wine. It was a great insight to a soldiers mentality of a medal not really showing the hardships, trauma and sacfricies they faced to survive the WAR.

Plot is still the most important thing in a movie for me and this one has a lot of holes.

1917
2020
Director: Sam Mendes
Starring Dean Charles chapman, George makay, Colin Firth, Richard Madden.Bendadict Cumberbatch etc


1917 is based within the first world war. Where a battalion of 1,600 soldiers are sent to retreat the Germans but what they don't realise is that it's a trap and a massacre. So, it's down to Corporal Blake (Dean Charles chapman) and corporal Schofield (George makay) to stop this from happening but they will be met with multiple challenges along the way. Wow what a truly incredible movie that hit the mark on every level, visuals, acting and a compelling story lets talk more about this. 

First, the cinematography was stunning. This film really was firstly phenomenal to look at, and secondly really transported you into the world of the film, and it really made you feel a part of the time, with its scarily realistic set designs and scenery truly making you feel like you were in the battlefield with them. Leading to a truly phenomenal film just to look at and I was often sitting in awe of the film. The visual creativity as well was of the chart, making me truly respect the artistry of Sam Mendes with what he can create.

Next the film really made you connect with the two main characters and their performances were fantastic. Due to the film largely being focused on just two characters it gave you more time to truly connect and spend more time with them as there friendship developed throughout the film, so they actually made a good decision by having more secondary characters with only a couple of scenes and two key characters to connect and focus on. And the performance from both Dean Charles Chapman and George Makay were truly fantastic. Considering that I had never heard of either of these two actors before they surprised me at there acting abilities. They showed emotional complexity of what it would be like being a soldier in the war, in truly versatile performances, hitting all the right notes with both serious, impactful and emotional scenes.

Next the film did not hold back with showing the harsh reality of war with its gore and action sequences. In order for the film to leave the impact that it did, gory scenes showing the true horrors of war was needed, and it was most certainly shocking to watch. The film did a great job at getting under your skin with surprisingly very realistic looking bodies. A key scene that stands out to me would be when corporal Schofield, is swimming in a lake trying to get on the shore, but there is a large amount of bodies that he had to swim through in order to save himself, this scene truly left one of the biggest impact for me, and I am glad the director did not hold back with showing what war was really like, and especially glad that he didn't play it safe.
My only slight nit-pick that stopped the film from being truly perfect for me was that I felt that they could have been slightly more creative with the films character arcs and development. The film didn't show a lot of back story to the main characters, which I got as it was more about the developing friendship, however it would have been nice to have learned slightly more about them, but this is only a slight nit-pick. As well as the death of corporal  Blake I felt could have been saved for the final act, yes this gave corporal Scofield the motivation to find his brother, but perhaps another scenario for the film could have been where Blake reunites with his brother and then gets killed whilst the Germans were attacking, but once again I didn't have an issue with what they did but this could have been how this particular death could have been placed slightly differently.

Next, I thought the film managed to achieve an extremely tense tone and well executed jump scares. The film in a lot of places didn't have any soundtrack, which worked perfectly as I felt on the edge of  my seat throughout the whole film, and I also think fear of the unknown for the audience and for the characters on the screen also made the film very tense as well. And due to this lack of sound in places there was a surprising amount of well executed jumpscares. These were largely just explosions or gun shots, but they happened completely out of the blue which I was not expecting but it was a welcome surprise for me.

My next two positives would be the films surprising amount of emotional weight and its incredible final act. Wow this film was surprisingly emotional, just seeing the large body count throughout, truly made me realise whilst watching how pointless war is, and I think that's a good message to spread. And to have corporal Blake get killed was extremely heart-breaking, due to him not being able to see his brother and the connection he had formed with Scofield you could really tell how sad he was feeling which is another credit to there acting abilities.  And the long drawn out scene of his death really allowed the audience time for what just happened to sink in, therefore making it even more emotional to watch. The final act was truly one of the best things I have ever seen. Sam Mendes did an excellent job at misleading you into what was going to happen, he could of easily went the predictable root and just let the message be delivered, but no the soldiers were already on the battlefield when Scofield was attempting to deliver the message. They went all out with fantastic cinematography, surprising cameos and an impactful ending with Blakes brother which really worked as a show of respect for the character and to make you leave the film satisfied.

However, my final biggest positive would be how the film managed to look like one continuous take. Wow what a clever creative decision here. Yes, there was clearly a few cuts, but they were very well disguised and didn't affect the flow of the movie. Having one continuous take really gets you immersed in the film, and makes you feel like you are there with the characters truly leading to excellent experience whilst watching, as you connected with the characters more and it makes you feel like part of the movie.

Overall 1917 is a true cinematic masterpiece and deserving of all its awards buzz. With a fantastically acted and fantastically crafted immersive film that might be my favourite of the year.

1917-
​What is WAR? More importantly why was "The War To End All Wars", circa WWI, not true to this prophetic hope for an end to the savagery of war? 1917 will not answer any of these questions but it will provide an insight into the horrors and anguish of war - the irony and the agony - of war through the eyes and actions of a single man. War will be presented through a series of vignettes helping to define one man's determination, hope and fear that will be shared with his audience through examples that will touch your emotions and add visual clarity to the never seen sides of war. A young British soldier is asked to grab a comrade for a mission of unknown duration or intent. His commanding officer charges him with a mission to cross enemy lines to deliver a message to the commander of thousands of British troops who are about to charge into a battle that is now known to be a trap that will kill them all. Why was this young corporal chosen for this almost suicidal mission? Because his older brother is one of the young officers who will be leading the charge to almost sure destruction and death. What follows are the actions and experiences that drive this young soldier on a mission of love and duty. First to family and almost certainly to save the lives of the thousands of comrades in arms who will be slaughtered if he fails to deliver his orders to NOT advance. This is a powerful and emotional insight into war and into the unexpected challenges that fate offers as a road map to the completion of this or any mission. If you ever wondered what it took to be a HERO - you may be surprised how much simple survival acts as the principal motivating force in allowing one to perform without thought or concern for anything but simply staying alive. 
Rating: W - O - S = War's Other Side

1917 was...phenomenal.

This film is a stunning technical achievement seamlessly linking a series of long takes into a final product that appears to be almost entirely one continuous shot. If that weren't enough the film is shot by cinematography god Roger Deakins and therefore looks consistently amazing despite the limitations of having to maintain such long takes. I'll be very surprised if this film isn't at least nominated for Best Cinematography at the Oscars if not Best Picture.

The story is very simple but fits the long take approach perfectly, two British soldiers are tasked with delivering orders to stop a massacre of their forces. Much like Dunkirk, this is a race against time, and we see every heart-racing minute of the journey as the two soldiers LCpl's Schofield & Blake are brought to life thanks to great performances by George MacKay & Dean-Charles Chapman respectively.

The film's not perfect, there are a few minor issues I had with some plot contrivances and a Lee-Enfield that fires far more rounds than it should hold. The nature of the film also prevents significant character development, though I think we get enough to identify with the characters' regardless.

Overall, I found 1917 to be a beautiful depiction of the ugliness of war and a heart-wrenching examination of the incredible lengths men will go to for one another when the chips are down. See it in IMAX if you can.

Here goes-- Too Much Fiction. Too much comedy. With complete respect for the real fighters in the hell of World War I, this is to attack the fiction.  I'd call the surviving messenger Odysseus, but Odysseus never had it so bad. How many lives does a Hollywood character get in a war film?  Schofield didn't go five minutes into his Odyssey without cutting his bare hand on barbed wire. Most Generals would lend a pair of wire cutters when they send soldiers through No Man's Land.  Then he got buried under rocks in a trip wire explosion, but didn't bleed much. Later, I learned why the Germans lost the war-- they couldn't shoot a guy at close range after dozens of prime opportunities.  The plot called for milk, so he found a pail near a cow that the Germans donated to the Allies for the purpose of who knows. Schofield was hands down the noisiest swimmer in the war. Interesting, because British Boy Scouts were taught how to swim silently before then. He did or didn't crash into a huge rock, depending on what camera angle you choose. He did  or didn't get shot by a German, finally, but recovered quite bloodlessly and ran off. After falling down Yosemite Falls or something similar, he was out of breath, but recovered nicely, in time to listen to too many verses of Wayfaring Stranger before remembering to find the Colonel. Then he honed in on the Colonel's whereabouts like a homing pigeon. Too bad they didn't send a homing pigeon in the first place.

A lot of people are saying this movie is slow. I don't know what you expect, a transformers movie? Those are the type of people that rate this one star. Or the people that possess no WW1 knowledge.

"There wasn't enough action." - World War 1 was slow my guy. I don't know what kinda movies you've been watching that warp your perception of what takes place in battles, but clearly you think they last 10 minutes and that it consists of only hard action and is filled with cliche'd garbage that has been shown to us in recent war films.

"How did they dodge the bullets while being chased?" - Have you ever fired a bolt action rifle while running? Case closed.

"Why didn't they just send a biplane to drop pamphlets over the battlefield?" - First off, is this even feasible? Printing pamphlets is a huge waste of time and flying an unreliable biplane over an active battlefield is not reliable. Also phone lines have been damaged, if you weren't paying attention. Also no, they aren't using radios. Like mentioned in the beginning of the film, two men are significantly faster than the organization and mobilization of an entire battalion, and this is not even mentioning the fact that that would be a waste of resources considering that the trench featured in the start of the film is a reserve trench, meaning that these soldiers are waiting for battle.

"Characters weren't developed." - Although I agree they weren't as fleshed out as they could be, don't act like there wasn't any character development or backstory at all, because there is some.

"They just randomly found milk." - Okay fair point. Not enough to justify a significantly lower rating. 

"If they're in enemy territory that means they are surrounded or have the enemy surrounded." - Not how a trench system works. Also the main characters are making a journey from a reserve trench, past a German trench from which the enemies have fallen back, to a frontline trench, which likely would have been a repurposed German trench. WW1 battles consisted of constant pushing back and forth of the frontlines. Regardless, it is still possible to flank a trench, as trenches don't generally stretch across an entire country.

"Unrealistic plot." - So do you want an actual completely authentic plot? Because that would make for a horrible movie in the context of WW1.

"Schofield got shot." - Once again, pay attention. He is shot in the helmet and it ricochets (You can literally hear it). He then falls backwards injuring his head.

WWI stories are engaging in print, but they do not necessarily translate into movie visuals. Muddy, rat-infested trenches are monotonous and as frustrating as the stalemate war itself. However, 1917 is the greatest depiction of that horrific conflict that Ive ever seen. Ive found war movies from the 40s-80s interesting, but the heroics and bravado make the characters 2-dimensional and laughable, imo. Saving Private Ryan forever raised the bar, and that is hardly my opinion, alone. One may invest in a story through cleverness and sensationalism, but will they care enough to be viscerally jolted by the main character's experience? George McKays (Lance Corporal Schofield) eyes, expressions and responses alone sold and held me.
Since storytelling must evolve in any genre — Western, spy, war — to further that genre, what can be said that hasnt already been said? Answer: quirky but accurate details about the times, settings, values and vernacular details that arent essential to the story, yet immerse the viewer into the period. I look for that, and GREATLY respect it 1917 scores big in that way! Although Ive not researched this, revisionism was undetectable, and minimal political correctness pandering, which is rare anymore.
The highly intense, immersive nature of 1917 locked me in from beginning to end, and my only complaint is that it wasnt long enough (always a good sign). I place 1917 on the level of Saving Private Ryan, Fury, Hacksaw Ridge and Dunkirk.

I love seeing an honest-to-god WW1 film. Too often that entire conflict gets brushed over in favour of its flashier sequel. The single take gimmick is neat as well. It gets you real close to the two leads’ story and doesn’t let you leave. One of the better things about this decision is that we get a better idea of the geography of trenches; a whole complicated structure of command trenches in the rear connected through in and out trenches to the support and frontline trenches. And boy do they feel different. Then you have the tangled mess of No Man’s Land and you get taken to an actual German trench! Complete with large bunkrooms and artillery ranges. After this point the geography gets rather more shaky. To be in verdant green pastures you ought to be several miles beyond the front lines as constant artillery barrages would have left precious little else intact. And I can’t see how the soil in the second line of trenches makes any sense at all given the look of the first one.

Sam did not disappoint! A master of the visual, Mendes once again uses every inch of the screen to its fullest potential. The much spoken of "gimmick" aside, the film is brilliantly written. Never heavy-handed, the script is wonderfully efficient in its dialogue. It is a masterclass in show, don't tell. Back to the gimmick, it does not work if not for the performances from the two young actors. MacKay, especially, excels as a worthy Virgil in our trek through the hell of war. This is not a traditional war film. Like it's predecessor Jarhead, Mendes deconstructs war from the perspective of soldiers not to glorify or denounce war. Instead, it is a apathetic study of soldiers (humanity) in war. It is a must watch!!!

I seriously cannot understand the people who give this movie  4 and 5 stars. Not too be mean but I wonder how many movies they see each year. I was enthusiastic about seeing this film but very early on a got a sense of lazy effort by the director. By the end I couldn't wait for it to be over and leave.  How good can a movie be if you would never ever waist another 2 hours of your life watching it? I know many others give it very good marks but lets examine just a couple of the oddities of the movie. Very convenient to have a cow in the middle of the pasture and the milk bucket in the barn with fresh milk. Meanwhile the Germans have killed every other cow in the country, and by the way who milked the cow? Outside the barn one of the American soldiers was stabbed by the German and died. Why did the other American soldier need to move him 10 ft? And where the hell did all the soldiers come from that were pissing on the side of the house? Did they not hear or see the German plane crash into the barn and prevent their fellow soldier from being killed?
There wasn't enough time elapsed to even make that scene make sense.  Some how the allies have plenty of planes for "dogfights" but none of them can fly a message over to the front line? It's just a whole bunch of silliness and convenience when needed(french girl and baby needing milk in the ruins). The Germans are so incompetent that when it's pitch black out they cannot see her candles? Save your money maybe it will make it's way to cable in 2-3 years.

I do wish I was brought into the character's a little more, as there may be something lacking here, but perhaps that is the trade-off with a movie like this with no flash-backs to home in London, or past run-ins with the troops that would allow for that sort of thing here. 1917 is a bold and ambitious film of all sorts. We as America have lately become heavily involved in the practices and preparation of war, and it is going so far that it is hinging on our nationality and freedoms. This film will serve as a reminder of how warfare has evolved in over a century and what can still be sacrificed because of the violence. This film has a basic premise, in which two soldiers must deliver a notice to stop an attack on the Germans or thousands of life will be lost (with one of the soldiers being one of the protagonist's brother). This may be the film's only true downfall as it serves no other purpose other than to get our characters from point A to B. However, the detail to trench warfare, outstanding cinematography and the sense of urgency instantly catapult this film into a Oscar Best Picture contender (even though it may have to settle for a nomination). When one can invest themselves in a time like this where lives were lost and havoc wrecked everywhere, they become aware of the pandemonium that stands in our history books today. War is beautiful yet destructive. 
This film will not reach the heights of some other inceredible war films like Apocalyse Now or Dunkirk, but it holds a hefty message of immedicacy in times like then and now.
