1917 is a WW1 epic following the story of two soldiers, Lance Corporals Blake and Schofield, who have to go past enemy lines in order to stop an attack taking place so 1600 men don't walk into a trap. This film was written by Sam Mendes and Krysty Wilson-Cairns, the dialogue between the two protagonists is minimalistic in this film, and in events where other writers would add in explanations as to why something is bad, Mendes and Wilson-Cairns allow the audience to put 2 and 2 together, which invests us more into the story, feeling like the third person alongside Blake and Schofield. This script is also written so that the audience can never rest for too long, and feel that something bad is always going to happen. One critique of the script is that the two protagonists didn't get much character building, so if they did, we would've cared more than we did when they were in danger. Characters also sometimes refer to the protagonists as Lance Corporal and then sometimes Corporal, which is a slight issue in continuity. Roger Deakins does an incredible job in  shooting this film, with camera work letting the audience cover the characters back but when we don't see in front of the characters for a while this creates tension and the audience assumes a threat. The opening shot of this scene was mesmerically beautiful, the pan shots going through barbed wire and over a body of water in a crater towards the start of the film were good pieces of camerawork, and this alongside a shot following Schofield in a river approaching a rock make the audience jump out of their seat. This was easily the best shot film of 2019 and should walk away with the Oscar for cinematography. Alongside this, Lee Smith's (editor) work to make this movie seem like it was taken in one shot was a technical masterpiece. Sam Mendes' work in this film isn't seen as the acting seems very naturalistic even though it is meticulously planned out, from the shot list to how much of the set you could use in a certain set of time. Dennis Gassner does an excellent job in production design for this film and should also walk away with the Oscar. Thomas Newman's score shows once again why he's one of the best at his job, a prime example of this was, as Schofield and Blake were approaching the first German trench, with the music feeling fanfare like and that we could celebrate, but it was still really tense and we feel that they might be walking into a death trap. Dean-Charles Chapman (Blake) and George MacKay (Schofield) do a great job at portraying themselves as in the moment even though the moments are meticulously planned, however they didn't have lots of backstory to portray, however that's as this film focuses mainly on the events going on and not the characters backstory. The audience feel like the third person alongside Blake in Schofield in this film, looking for any possible threats like their lookout. We get fully absorbed into this film as an audience, and we always feel on edge, and when there are emotional moments, they hit all the more. This is one of the great war films of all time.

The Dolby format was a huge plus for this one and at times, in what was a packed theater, you could have heard a pin drop.  This one was tough for me to rate because with just the script and dialogue it would be average at best, yet what they were able to create visually easily achieves top marks and elevated all other aspects of the film.

1917 is a wonder from a film making perspective. I will take the unpopular stance that the "single-shot" nature of it isn't optimal, some shots leave your eye searching for the focus of the frame and some angles leave you waiting for the next interesting moment. This is most apparent at the beginning where the steady cam method of the film initially feels disorienting. It bobs with the characters as if you're walking with them but the camera is leading characters which have more similarities with a dolly or truck camera movement than a first-person perspective. So even though it seems like the intent was to make you feel as if you are walking with the character the camera is still hovering as if you are a neutral godlike observer. So from a film literacy perspective that can be disorienting since most films stick to conventional omnipotent camera movements and don't sit in this middle ground of third person/first person changing perspective.

However, that little nitpick is my only complaint. This film is always Engaging. Within 15 minutes I forgot it was "one-shot" and was glued to the plight of the characters on screen. The film is two hours and it is so full of story beats and progression that I marvel at how much they fit in it. And the progression of the plot makes it very easy to recount which moments occur when and how much the characters change during the film.

If I was not concentrating on the struggles of our protagonists, I was trying to find the hidden cuts that help mask the single-shot technique. And honestly, some of them are incredibly well hidden. Others are obvious if you know what you're looking for but most viewers won't have a clue. This film is the next logical progression from 2014's Birdman in retrospect. Taking that one shot framing device and applying it to a war reenactment seems obvious while watching 1917.

And the semi omniscient camera perspective lends itself to some amazing camera movements that will leave any filmmaker scratching their head. The camera leads and follows the action so well that it boggles the mind at how they, not only framed and timed some shots but also lit the scenes. And the angles are so wide and the focus pulling is so sharp that you rarely feel the events are "staged" and disconnect from the story. So much so, that I can only think of a handful of effects that were not practical. And as a filmmaker, each scene and camera move became a puzzle waiting to be solved.

If you like tense films, if you like war movies, and if you like picking apart cinematography, then you'll thoroughly enjoy 1917.

Hold on to your butts.  So this is about a pair of soldiers (Dean-Charles Chapman, George MacKay) in WWI.  They get tasked with delivering a message to the Colonel on the front line to let him know that he is leading 1,600 men (including one of the soldiers' brother) into a German trap.  They only have one day to hand-deliver the message and lots of ground to cover, so time is of the essence.  I finally made it; this was my most anticipated movie of 2019.  Sam Mendes is one of the most versatile directors out there, and the initial trailer looked nothing short of pulse-pounding.  I am extremely pleased to report that 1917 did not disappoint in the slightest, and if you only watch one movie this award season, this should probably be the one.  I purposely went out of my way not to read anything about this, but there was one element that I couldn't help but overhear: this movie presented in done in one continuous shot, and that did nothing but entice me even further.  In reality, this is closer to Birdman in that there are some sneaky cuts in the darkness, but I really only noticed about four spots where this was possible, and it did not take anything away from the overall effectiveness of the film.  It really pulls you in from the start, and it is not like this starts off with bombs and gunfire, it slowly guides you in as you navigate the land with these two soldiers.  The one-shot never feels like it is a gimmick, it is done for a completely engrossing effect that makes you feel like you are there on the battlefield with these men.  It isn't like there is a ton of room to operate in these trenches either, and it is mindboggling to me that they were able to choreograph not only all of these people moving at the same time but that they also somehow managed to figure out how to move the camera around everybody without interrupting the shot.  That in itself is a feat, and I'm not going to mix my words: this is some of the best modern filmmaking you will ever see, it is that well done.  The direction is the star of this, but that's not to discount the other pieces to this movie as well.  The score in this is amazing, and it really just keeps you filled with dread for what's around the next corner.  Also, it isn't just a two-hour battle because that would be exhausting, it finds quiet moments within the chaos.  This is so well-done that you don't want to take your eyes off the screen because you might miss something.  Theaters are notoriously chilly, but when I watched this, it felt about 5° warmer from all the nervous body heat coming off the audience.  1917 is one of the best movies of the year, and it really is something special.

Mendes handles his subject with conviction and deep respect. He provides an inquiry into the resolve of human endurance through an unrelenting portrait of the Great War, delivered with great esteem for soldiering. 1917 is an impressive technical accomplishment. The execution of its concept, the appearance of a ‘one-take' continuous shot that propels the viewer through the narrative into a meticulous designed environment. It demonstrates a level of ambition given the genre but feels natural for such a portrayal.


The continuous shot provides a subjective experience of The Great War. Often 1917 paints an abstract reflection of the Tommy's state of mind in its atmosphere. Its awareness almost primitive, operating on the fumes of instinct. The imagery conjures up Romanticism in its textual analysis provoking both beauty and horror. Mendes has command over the audience's senses with overwhelming audio-visual shock and awe!

Praise will no doubt fall, and rightly so, on the cinematic prowess of Roger Deakins and the design of Dennis Grassner. Grassner provides an authentic quality that complements Deakin's lens. All of which immerses the audience in Mendes's world building. This is a finely tuned collaboration.

This was an amazing movie and definitely a refresher from all the disappointments that came out this year. Im going to start of with the good because its easier than the bad. The acting in this movie is amazing, everybody gives such a great and realistic performance even for the characters with limited screen time. George MacKay is the stand out as he gives such a realistic and grounded approach to the role which makes you feel the horror he is experiencing during the war. Dean-Charles Chapman is also very good but is outshined by MacKay. The plot of the movie is that two young soldiers have to travel miles to deliver a message that can save 1600 men and it is executed nearly perfectly. For the whole movie you feel that you are in the war, you can feel that time is running out, the stakes are high and our characters could be shot from anywhere, there are great emotional moments which makes you feel for our heroes and the choices the characters are realistic and show that you have to make the hard choices to survive during the war. The fight scenes are really great and manage to be intense and epic without being highly choreographed. The score by Thomas Newman is absolutely stunning and was definitely one of my favourite parts of the film. Finally we have the cinematography which is the absolute best part of this film. Roger Deakins never fails to blow us away, the one shot idea was great as it put you in the shoes of our heroes, the imagery is absolutely mind blowing with the standout being the shot of the village being burned. It is quite obvious that Deakins will win the Oscar for his work as it is some of the best I have ever seen. There are only 2 major problems with the film for me, the first is that the stakes were very low during the second half of the film and that pulled me out of the movie a bit. The second problem is that none of the characters are really given much character. It makes sense in a contextual perspective but from a film perspective it lacks quite a bit. I have a few other nitpicks but they don't impact the movie heavily. Overall it is an amazing movie and is one of the best from 2019. I give this movie an A and is definitely a must watch.

1917's overlooked color, light, and set design lulls you into a subtle hypnotic trance that mesmerizes you throughout the entire film. The grand feat of Roger Deakon's cinematography evokes firsthand tension through secondhand meticulously visual storytelling. Though the minimal character building keeps the film from being an emotional classic, the extensive world building and methodical shooting techniques of 1917 will set a precedent for all future wartime epics.

1917: Saving Lt. Blake (and 1,599 of his mates)? The Red Badge of Courage? All Not Quiet on the Western Front? One mission, two corporals, one continuous shot. We have such a compelling story. It combines the duty of the trooper, the self-sacrifice in the face of possible death of the soldier, with the personal considerations of a brother, Blake, going all out to save his real brother. The setup, an order by a general, is as grinding and astonishing as the options foisted upon Meryl Streep in "Sophie's Choice" by a sadistic Nazi officer. But, OK, we buy in that Firth would play on a soldier's sense of duty but also his brotherly love to be more likely to succeed in this suicide mission. Maybe it made as much sense (little) as anything decided by the military brass and politicians in World War I, where millions were thrown into the meat grinder of a horrendous war. Spoilers: When the two corporals became one, the survivor, Will Schofield, decided he must die before quitting on his word to Blake, the trooper who had saved him along the way. And when he gave his milk and all his food to a French woman and a baby, he was purifying himself for the final push, conceding his life had to be sacrificed. And when he next ran from German soldiers, all of them firing at him but none of them sharpshooters, he jumped into a raging river, the water baptizing him and sweeping him into his new sacred role of a man out to save 1,600 Brit soldiers, including Blake's brother. And the water had somehow led him to his goal, the Yorkie battalions he was out to save. Schofield had won a valor medal and traded it for a bottle of wine, saying he didn't believe he'd make it home to show anybody. But after he by hook and crook got to their commander, who called off the last part of the attack after seeing his message from the general and actually saved some of the troopers including the targeted brother Lt. Blake, the commander, Cumberbatch, didn't commend Schofield for his astonishing completion of his perilous mission, but told him to "fuck off" after ironically and disgustedly saying the brass might change their minds and put the attack back on in the morning. When insanity is in charge of war, anything can happen. It is a scathing piece on the insanity of war and that war. The worst, most devoid of humanity moment, was after the two Brit corporals pulled out a German pilot from his crashed, burning plane, his pants on fire, the German thanked them by stabbing Blake to death. At the end, Schofield, who surely deserved the Brit equivalent of the medal of honor, met Lt. Blake and praised his dead brother, and after, sat leaning on a tree stripped of all green, all branches, discolored, a symbol of what war does to nature; he pulled out a picture of his Mum and sister and on the back, Mum had written "Come back to us," and for him, that is what mattered, where real life existed, as off in the distance he could see an array of trees with leaves in the woods, where nature had not been destroyed by war, a forest of hope. The scene when he was running to fulfill his mission on the battlefield and explosions were going off all around him for maybe a minute, I had tears in my eyes for his valor, persistence, determination, his self-discipline and his love for his friend. At picture's end, people clapped, which doesn't happen too often at the movies. Bravo. A wartime masterpiece.

The movie, unlike most films, was shot in a continual scene.  By doing this the director Mendes brings the audience, step-by-step, along with the characters on their mission.  I felt apart of their journey, experiencing their fear, how they experience both the inhumanity of war and the humanity of others that keep them moving forward.  While the characters were fictional, I did feel as though they could have been real young men, caught up in the horror of war.

Now that all the glittery dust has settled at the golden globes and 1917 has made away with best picture award and stolen the weekend at the box office with over 37 million I finally got to see it. And guess what it was great. Sam Mendes's execution of the WWI flick is a unique, edge of your seat ride that follows two men as they try and warn a battalion before they fall into an enemy trap. George Mackay of Pride(2014) is our guide through a horrific war torn landscape that's as nightmarish as it is beautiful. The execution makes you feel as if the entire venture is one non stop shot that you're unwillingly participating in. Theres not alot of development character wise and that's definitely a conscious decision but because of that I felt oddly disconnected at times. That being said the first half of the movie has an intense first person flow to it that's almost unbearable at times. But when it finally breaks for air, when our lead comes into contact with a young woman it reminded me I was in a theater. It was a solid scene but definitely broke up the pace. That being said it returns to its anxiety splitting pace not long after. When I say this movie is intense I mean it but it does stop and smell the roses so to speak. It is quiet and inspired. The lead performance from George Mackay is really fantastic and definitely deserves some award attention as does the film which I'm sure will ring it up at the Oscars and deservedly so. From the sweeping but intimate cinematography to the nerve shredding score. Its definitely one of 2019s best.

Mendes has somehow elevated the immersive war film between his very meticulous and clever staging and Deakins absolutely gorgeous, all-awards-in-the-fuckin-earth-deserving cinematography. Also, George MacKay is just phenomenal along the ride that you hang onto every emotional punch he endures. It holds up a lot a second time around.

1917 it's a breathtakingly magnificent film. Every carefully planned shot is some of the most gorgeous shots in filmmaking. Everything about this film is why I love the movies and the art of film. A dedicated cast and crew firing on all cylinders to make a classic. From George Mackay's phenomenal performance to Mendes' directing, to the camera operators. Everyone brought their A-Game and it shows. The idea of shooting the film like it's one single take isn't just a gimmick. It helps make you feel you're on this journey with these two young men, sneaking your way through no man's land and the trenches. It never feels like it's taking over the movie, they did a brilliant job of making it feel natural. The meticulous planning it took for these shots is nothing short of perfect. The production design is also gorgeous, every set feels like your there in French countryside at the front. The true star of 1917 is Roger Deakins and his gorgeous cinematography. His cinematography tells its own story. The shot in the ruined bombed out village coming out of the window with the camera panning down with the continuous flares lighting the village gives me chills every time I've seen the film. 1917 is what movies are all about, and everything I love about movies, it has the magic that makes the movies the movies and films art.

Good not great. Amazing cinematography and production in this film, that gives the viewer an up close look into the horrors of the Great War. The attention to detail is staggering and keeps you in awe throughout the entirety of the movie. The actual story however, is somewhat of a surprise to me and only offers a small bit of surface level development. You don’t get much depth from the characters and at times you wish the screenplay would drift away for a bit to explore the amazing backdrop that is World War I. It doesn’t, instead staying locked into these few characters pushing forward with the story in a constant, never blinking display of first person storytelling. 1917 delivers as promised in its purity, visual attractiveness and intensity. Go see this movie, even if it leaves at bit to be desired in overall action and storyline.

we don't get to hear many stories of this generation, and even our greatest generation, the WWII generation, are largely gone from us now. Movies like this are important. They aren't about the politics of why we are or were at war, they are about the people that fight in them, and die in them. War is ugly, but there are bonds forged there stronger than blood, and there is love, in spite of all the terrors that surround. we NEED these stories. we need to honor those that came before us. to forget them is to forget who we are as nations and people. I am an Iraq veteran,  and it saddens me how little today's youth have no idea about our fighting there, and it hasn't been but a little over 15 years. Or that we still have troops fighting in Afghanistan, some of which were barely or not even alive when we first stepped foot there. This movie is a must see. Lest we forget!

First off, I was so happy that we had reserved seats for tonight movie. It was packed. I was expecting a much older group, seeing WW1 was over 100 years ago. The theatre had every age group ! My wife and I were one of the fortunate ones. We had the privilege to talk to a family member (Pat's maternal grandfather)who fought in the War. 
Back to the film itself. It was terrific ! Need I say more but I will. The beauty of the continuous filming technique was you really felt like you were there with main character from beginning to end. Many times through the film you did not want to be there with them. The reality of combat used in this war was horrific. So many lives lost. The film portrayed each soldier with so many emotions... Scared, sad, nervous, angry, anxious, homesick and some hopeful.
Obviously our modern day wars are fought in a whole new fashion. I don't think that it will ever change the men and women who are fighting
This movie is a must see in 2020. Will be a top contender for Best Picture

It is a rare, rare thing for me to feel as though I need to unsheathe the "M-word" from my vocabulary after seeing a movie. Though, with Sam Mendes's "1917" freshly in mind, I find the experience impossible to describe without dropping it at least once. I don't think I've seen a filmic narrative since "The Revenant" that's more adequately aligned itself with the term "journey" than this one has. It is a wild, traumatic, and relentlessly thrilling, near-real-time chronicling of a fateful day in the lives of so many that I find infinitely more epic in scope and theme than any movie I've seen in the past few years -- and some of those had more than triple the budget Mendes had at his disposal. This is what moviemaking is all about. So many moments come to pass throughout where not only the acting and writing, but the camerawork, production design, music, and thematics are firing on all cylinders, welling up feelings of wonderment, terror, anxiety, despair and grief at various points in a magnificently well-paced 2-hour running time. They absolutely do not make movies like this very often, so do yourself a favor and immediately treat yourself to viewing this masterpiece in the biggest theater you have near you.

CON

Sam Mendes who is best known for winning both an Academy Award and Golden Globe Award for Best Director for his directorial debut, "American Beauty", produces his most ambitious feat yet. "1917" is a taut and unyielding 2019 World War I film about two young British soldiers, Schofield and Blake (wonderfully played by George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman), who set forth on a nearly impossible task of saving 1,600 men from unequivocal annihilation as they walk into a German ambush in northern France near the German front. The two soldiers must reach their destination and deliver the message in time, before the British soldier's attack the German infantry, Blake's own brother is amongst the soldiers charging. This plot twist not only heightens the suspense, but the film also operates like a ticking-clock. The two treking through booby-trapped trenches and going face to face with deadly German snipers adds raw realism to this deeply engaging film.
The film is made to leave the audience with the impression that the movie was filmed in one continuous take. This was an extreme challenge for both the director of photography, Roger Deakins, and the director, Sam Mendes; not to mention the toll on the cast and crew. The series of carefully orchestrated sequences had to be meticulously performed in order for Deakins and Mendes, to pull off such a cinematic achievement. This not only made the audience feel like you were living out the series of events, but we also become willing participants in suspending any disbelief, which allows us to accept the given premises of the story being told in order to empathize with the actors. This film is one of my frontrunners for best film of the year - a real tour de force. Sam Mendes other credits include "Road to Perdition" (2002), "Skyfall" (2012) and "Spectre" (2015).

I don't like war movies, never have. They usually play one of two ways - an effects-heavy love ballad to gore and violence or a hearty tale of brotherhood among men who can't wait to talk about the girls waiting back home. The ones that focus more on fact over fiction will hold my attention a little longer, but my historical interests tend to skew towards the royal court of Henry the Eighth. So no, I don't like war movies and I didn't like 1917. I loved it.

The story follows two British soldiers during the first world war and their journey across hostile territory to pass on a message that will save hundreds of lives - if they make it. Blake, played by Dean-Charles Chapman (Game of Thrones' Tommen Baratheon) and Schofield, played by George MacKay (Hamlet in the 2018 film Ophelia, which I only recently learned about and is now on my watchlist) are quickly likable and their easy, youthful friendship gives the movie a light start. Unfortunately, movies that attach you to the main characters so quickly tend to immediately send them into danger and 1917 is no exception.

Schofield and Blake are called to see the general who informs them that there is an attack planned for the next morning that needs to be stopped. Turns out the Germans weren't really retreating, they were luring the British into a trap and if the attack goes on, all 1,600 men will die. Unfortunately, the phone lines have been cut and they can't call them, so the only way to warn them is by a hand-delivered letter. This is where Blake comes in - with his expert navigation skills, he should be able to make his way past the German front lines and to the camp of the 2nd battalion. In case orders aren't enough, the stakes are made even more personal when it is revealed his brother is one of the 1,600 men.

They set off on their journey and we're quickly - too quickly - exposed to the horrors of war. The devastation is immediate as we are first introduced to the wounded, and then to the dead. As the pair begin their trek across no man's land, we see horrors that no man should ever have to witness and with each devastating visual, you are reminded that this isn't just a movie - this is someone's past, someone's memory. 

Though the story is a work of fiction, it is in fact based in some reality - director Sam Mendes' grandfather, Alfred Mendes went on his own life-threatening journey across no man's land in his time serving during World War I. These tales of war first relayed to Mendes in his childhood, stayed with him, eventually inspiring the creation of 1917.

And what a creation it is. Emotionally charged from start to finish, it's hard to not judge this movie from such a personal perspective. Beyond just being visually stunning, it's the way the visuals are presented that takes it to the next level - the entire thing is made to look like one continuous take.

I will admit, I was skeptical about the idea when I first heard what they were doing, but within minutes of the movie starting, I was hooked. Something happens when a movie unfolds in "real-time" and in such close proximity - you become a part of it. You're no longer watching two soldiers delivering a message during a war. You are the third soldier, a silent partner on a dangerous mission. There isn't that detached feeling of an observer, your emotions are heightened because you're experiencing it with them - the fear, the anxiety, the sadness, the determination. I will say this again and again - movies aren't just meant to be watched, they're meant to be felt and 1917 does this brilliantly.

There is so much to like about the movie - the actors, the music, the story, the sheer artistry of it all - but it's the emotional core that gives it such a high place in my heart and my rating scale. This is more than just a war film - this is a story of humanity, determination, loyalty, and friendship. It's a harsh but necessary reminder of the cost of war, a hope that we can be better than we were before. It's a testament to the bond between a grandson and grandfather. It is a truly wonderful piece of art, the kind of movie that awards are made for. The stunning package is just the pretty ribbon attached to the medal.

1917 is a remarkable cinematic achievement that deserves to seen on the best screen possible. The film's first 15-20 minutes alone cemented this film as the year's best for 2019 and everything after placed it into the conversation for film of the decade. Directed by Sam Mendes (American Beauty, Jarhead, Skyfall, Spectre) and in collaboration with legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins, who has 80 films to his credit, 1917 is an ambitious, gripping and stirring WWI epic about 2 young soldiers tasked with delivering a message before dawn telling a battalion of soldiers to stop their planned attack, which new intel says would be a trap and lead to the entire battalion's death. Filmed with the illusion of being shot in a single long take, 1917 takes audiences right into the heart of the action and makes us feel as if we're right there with the 2 soldiers from beginning to end. Every crucial and dangerous moment these 2 individuals experience, as a result of the one take, is amplified and a gorgeous sight to behold and experience. 
As expected, the film's camerawork or cinematography is the real star of this film. Through careful meticulous planning, Mendes and Deakins have crafted an epic that simply stuns and mesmerizes for the film's entirety. The film's best moment comes during a scene at night where the window we see a french village lying in destruction and ruin while flares are shot off-camera from behind which then casts an eerie flash of contrasting light and shadow onto the ruined village. As the camera exits the window and pans down to ground level, the film's orchestral score swells and flourishes for dramatic effect while the light and shadows continue to flicker in a haunting yet beautiful display of cinema. This powerful scene filled me with emotion I hadn't felt for a film in a very long time. I realized I was witnessing a masterpiece of beauty and technical prowess. This is what cinema is all about.

This movie is incredible. The horror of the war feels very real and not exaggerated. For the first time I watched a movie wondering what the characters were smelling (and simultaneously grateful I could not smell it). The visuals are that stunning, that I could imagine the horror of the smell. The story itself is victory laced with heavy sorrow. As a result, I left feeling weighed down. 
I think this movie is historically important. Without out-right saying it, it gives greater understanding as to why America emphatically did NOT want to go to war 20 years later. December 25, 2019 (limited)

Sam Mendes' "1917" is an exceptionally well-made war movie, told with heart and conviction, and rendered with exquisite special effects and high production values. Like many of its kind ("Saving Private Ryan," "Black Hawk Down," "Dunkirk"), it places viewers, as best as any narrative film can, in the thick of the characters' dizzying and incomprehensible situations, up to the point where we practically feel their intense pain, fear and fatigue. On the same hand, we acquire their resilience, not to mention their determination to complete the mission they've been given. On the whole, this film stirs us both physically and emotionally.

However, while I mostly have good things to say about the picture, I hesitate to lend it too much praise because of the obvious machinations embedded in Mendes and Krysty Wilson-Cairns' screenplay, which relies on common war movie tropes to raise tension and pull on our heartstrings. These familiar devices work, mind you, but they also hold the film back from true greatness because they confine the story to what seems like a definitive, crowd-pleasing trajectory. Amidst seeing so many Hollywood war movies over the years and the becoming privy to the conventions of the genre, I wish "1917" had been let loose and allowed to transpire more chaotically and unpredictably, as real wars probably do.

It's likely there was pressure from the studio to tie the narrative up into a neat and not-too-risky package, in which the people and events connect the way we hope they will, as if the filmmakers wanted to reassure us that everything in life has purpose and even something as disorderly as war can be made orderly. I'm sure this approach makes a movie like "1917" more marketable to a mass audience, but it also gives it a certain level of romance that dilutes the reality of the conflict, and maintaining realism should have been the film's priority. Alas, it opts to stay in safe and proven territory, despite having the talent in front and behind the camera to break free from it.

That being said, to the film's credit, once it starts, it doesn't stop. It opens in April 1917 on a quiet, serene flower field in Northern France. The camera pulls back slowly and reveals two twentysomething lance corporals in the British army: Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Schofield (George MacKay). Both are resting and it's evident they've already seen their fair share of war, although probably not the likes of which is to come.

A superior officer approaches the boyish-faced lads and takes them to General Erinmore (Colin Firth), who gives them orders to cross "No Man's Land," or the vast open space between the French and former German front lines (Erinmore assumes there will be no lingering German soldiers out gunning for them). They're to hand deliver a letter from Erinmore to Colonel Mackenzie (Benedict Cumberbatch) that instructs the colonel to call off a planned attack on the Germans, whose alleged retreat was part of a strategy to lure and entrap the British army. Erinmore has chosen Blake and Schofield for the job because Blake's eldest brother is a lieutenant among the 116,000-man battalion being set up for the German ambush, and Erinmore figures saving his older brother will give Blake even more incentive to complete the mission.

What follows is a harrowing adventure of sorts as Blake and Schofield embark on what's supposed to be a straightforward, hours-long journey between the opposing sides' trenches. It proves to be anything but, however, because the soldiers encounter obstacles and conflicts that become increasingly perilous. I would describe their ordeals in more detail but it would disclose crucial developments the film depends on for its many surprises and ultimately instilling fear and anxiety in the audience so that we might empathize with the protagonists more. 

What I can tell you, and what the film is has been justifiably touting as one of its strongest, more unique assets, is its long, uninterrupted takes effectively place us in the middle of the action. And even though this invisible edit strategy has been practiced many times before (Alfred Hitchcock's "Rope," Aleksandr Sokurov's "Russian Ark"), "1917" executes it in such a way that the technique doesn't draw undue attention to itself, likely because it's a war movie in which the tactic feels most appropriate, since those taking part in war hardly ever get a break themselves. 

After a while, we become aware we've been following Blake and Schofield continuously, without cuts to other characters or establishing shots of the surrounding environment, but this deepens our relationship with them and we genuinely come to care about these "kids" and sometimes can't believe two people who are so young could find themselves in situations so grim. Editor Lee Smith and cinematographer Roger Deakins do a remarkable job of masking the cuts that sometimes only occur up to 8 and a half minutes after following the leads. It can be exhausting but "1917" is meant to be a cautionary tale about the toll war can take on the human mind and body as much as an action drama.

The goal of "1917," and what it achieves, is to throw the audience into the world of Blake and Schofield and to make the abstract concept of war less abstract. It's an inherently captivating and thrilling experience, made all the more hard-hitting by Dennis Gassner's expansive production design, which does an especially outstanding job of recreating destroyed towns and disemboweled structures. These striking visuals are underlined by Thomas Newman's elegiac score, which is comprised of the usual but still powerfully grandiose waves of strings and horns, which get punctuated, to great dramatic effect, by a light, child-like piano theme that accentuates the innocence of the main characters and the idea that when it comes to war, perhaps everyone involved retreats back to their childhood, feeling scared, insecure and trying desperately to navigate a world that's dangerous, overwhelming and baffling. This is how we feel watching the film and it's gripping.

I've given "1917" a lot of compliments, but I'd be remiss if I didn't also mention its shortcomings, most of which exist at the screenplay level. Mendes has obviously made a very personal film—the fictional story was inspired by one his grandfather, himself a World War I veteran, relayed to him—but I wish he and Cairns had taken greater risks by not setting the plot  on such a traditional Hollywood war movie path. Its standard narrative developments and easy emotional payoffs actually undermine the film's attempt to be visually and atmospherically realistic, which it accomplishes through its technical prowess.

One of the scenes I had a hard time believing takes place when Schofield meets a young French woman and her newborn baby. She's hiding in a blown-out building and her baby is hungry, so it seems overly convenient that Schofield happened to grab exactly what the baby needed in an earlier scene. Don't get me wrong—this is a touching, sweet moment, and it reminds us of the soldier's unwavering humanity, but at the same time, it feels too "written," sentimental and forced, as if the filmmakers thought they were required to strike our emotional chords even if it meant ceasing the urgency of the characters' situation and succumbing to melodrama. 

Another extraneous albeit well-acted scene arrives near the end when Schofield hears a fellow soldier singing the gospel song, "Poor Wayfaring Stranger," and sits quietly beside a tree to listen. Again, this a reflective break from the surrounding madness, but it doesn't quite fit with the movie's overall exigent tone. "1917" works masterfully when it focuses on being a brutally pressing and unaffected war picture, but it loses credibility when it tries to be something else, namely a poetic drama or a suspenseful Hollywood thriller, the latter of which is most apparent during the climax when the hero faces one hurdle after another to the point where it becomes overkill.

Nevertheless, our admiration for "1917" outweighs our criticism of it. The scope of the film is enormous and Mendes and his team show they're in complete control of their resources. The nature and subject matter of war movies tend to make them easy to hold in high regard, but that doesn't make them any easier to pull or less deserving of our respect, and "1917" is one that merits recognition for its visuals, its score, its tempo, and the way it exercises our hearts, minds and viscera all at once. Its narrative inconsistencies hold it back from being a perfect film, but it's certainly a memorable one.

1917 is a remarkable cinematic achievement. It's a gripping film, a startling companion to the horror of war. A totally visceral and immersive experience that left me shaking by its conclusion. Sam Mendes has given us something that is quite unique, audacious and ambitious. The film is set in 1917, obviously, during the First World War. Two young British Lance Corporals are ordered to deliver a message to a battalion on the front. The order is to cease their attack as they will be slaughtered by a heavy Germam presence. To add further drama a brother of one of the corporals is a member of the battalion. So sets off a heart stopping expedition to deliver the message before the impending doom. To add to the drama the film is shot in 'one take'. Of course it appears this way with careful editing but the affect is quite stunning. The camera follows the two men through trenches and piles of mud and burnt out towns with maximum affect. You feel as if you are living with the men as the camera follows them. Of course some critics have dismiised this as gimmicky but I think it adds to the sheer drama of the situation. Every second feels life changing and imperative. Of course this could make the film a one trick pony but it is such an enormous trick that I was swept up in the panic and desperation of the events taking place. It really works, it had me on the edge of my seat through out. There are some big names spread throughout the film such as Colin Firth and Benedict Cumberbatch but it is the young actors in the main roles who shine especially the very impressive George MacKay. To aid the film the production design is impeccable. You can feel the flies and rats and dead bodies piling up. And of course the cinematography by Roger Deakins is incomparable. This is high wire film making. It shoves us into the face of war and makes us feel every breath and gun shot fired. Cinema can be many things and make us feel many things. This film is unique in its own way and for that I think it is essential viewing.
Powerful film. Fabulous acting and beautiful cinematography. Felt so real. Brought me to tears several times. Stayed with me long after I left the theater....

One continuous, neorealistic shot captures the futility of the individual's will against the momentum of war. Mendes keeps the camera low and steady, pitching up and widening the shot at the most bone jarring, horrific moments, emphasizing the characters as the tiny toy soldiers they are in a maniacal, war demon's playpen. We are never allowed to look away or rest, never allowed even the small mercies of escape in the beauty of falling cherry blossoms in a river, as the camera pans to bloated corpses we must swim through to reach land. Free will and sanctuary are absent from the moment the scene opens on the characters waking to their fate, forced to move blindly towards the death that surrounds them.

Starting on April 6, 1917 (the day the US joined the Great War although never referenced) and ending the next morning, two baby faced British soldiers, Lance Corporal William Schofield (George MacKay) and Lance Corporal Tom Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) have 12 hours to maneuver through enemy lines of the Western Front. Their mission is to deliver a “call off the attack” message in order to save 1,600 troops who are unknowingly marching into a German ambush that will result in the complete slaughter of the Devonshire Regiment that includes Lt. Joseph Blake (Richard Madden, Robb Stark from GoT), Tom’s big brother. If you feel you are running, jumping and zig-zagging right behind Schofield and Blake through northern France’s war zone of trenches, barbed wire, bayonets, snipers, booby traps, ash, mud, rats, bloated horse carcasses, rotting human corpses—“follow the stench”—bombed out fiery ruins of abandoned French villages, mortar and mayhem, you can thank the cinematography technique that shot the terrifying no man’s land dash to look like it was filmed in a single linear take. Action! It’s a wrap! No cuts. At least that’s how the 119 minutes feel start to finish. We don’t see or hear anything that Blake or Schofield don’t see or hear. They are not so much a duo as a trio, I was with them. When a foraging rat lumbers into the trip wire, I cringed anticipating the explosion. When a downed German fighter plane cartwheels towards the two young Brits, I ducked. When Schofield runs for his life plunging over a sheer drop into the river rapids below, I braced for impact. I stood and watched the eerily breathtaking beauty of the wartime night illuminated by bombs and flames. Think Apocalypse Now. The film was shot in Scotland, the landscape stunning, my senses satiated by a dramatic range of scenes, the gore of combat carnage to the beauty of cows and countryside. After the first fifteen minutes I was unabashedly in love with this movie. 1917 is defined, not by blood and battles but by bravery and brotherhood. The relationship between buddies Blake and Schofield was close enough for an engaging balance of humor and hubris to emerge that never felt forced or contrived. Yet I never warmed up to the characters. But this may be precisely the cool response the filmmaker sought. Blake and Schofield‘s friendship was situational, a camaraderie spawning from the killing fields of war where guarding a requisite emotional distance is as essential to foot soldiers as combat gear. I felt that distance. So when the inevitable strikes, “It’s better not to dwell on it,” advice given by Captain Smith (Mark Strong) to Corporal Schofield in a moment of dazed trauma, I could pick myself up and keep moving. No grieving, no lingering, the 12-hour clock is winding down. In fact I was so invested in the mission that it frustrated me when the two corporals kept making ill advised decisions when confronted by their German counterparts, predictably crushing carpe diem under the shadow of death. I even eschewed the tender moments, a pail of milk, cherry blossoms, an orphaned child, a haunting Wayfaring Stranger solo—scenes that were clearly drawn up to infiltrate a symbolic flavor of humanity into the chaos and destruction—but the poignant minutes lingered a tad too long for my liking, slowing the urgency of the mission. I was channeling Winston Churchill, “If you’re going through hell, keep going.” Don’t stop! Hold that baby later! You’ve got to get the message to Colonel Mackenzie (Benedict Cumberbatch)! Now! Towards the end I kept wondering if those sentimental diversions cost lives. Still, nothing veered me away from absolutely loving this movie. Don’t wait for Netflix or Amazon. This is the type of movie that demands the big screen. You will learn from the ending credits that the film is dedicated to Lance Corporal Alfred H. Mendes—the director’s grandfather “who told us the stories.” Mendes at the age of 20 volunteered for a terrifying World War I solo mission through no man’s land to locate three British companies separated from their battalion. It was this mission through the muddy Flanders fields of Belgium that served as inspiration for 1917. In honoring his grandfather, Mendes crafted an epic war drama. I predict more honors: Oscar goes to 1917 for Best Picture

A fantastic film and easily one of the best war movies made so far this century.  Some of the critics and reviewers insist on referencing "Saving Private Ryan" but that is a shallow, lowest common denominator comparison that reveals an ignorance of the genre.  This film, at is core, is a blend of "Gallipoli" and "Full Metal Jacket."  Gallipoli for its moral and human compass aka consequences and FMJ for its overall tone of isolation, danger, doom, and fear....that you cannot see (and never really do en mass) the enemy but you know they're there...so when they do appear its very powerful and terrifying.  There are also several scenes that highlight the zero sum game of war, and the horrible choices people have to make to survive and/or win. The best compliment I can pay is that my grandfather fought in WWI...and this film honors him by not reducing it to some simplistic political or moral platitude. It honored him through the Realism of what he endured. Most definitely recommended.

A true modern masterpiece, in a directionless age, a film of true progression. The most immersive movie I have ever seen. 

      The sets don't appear to be sets, but ‘the real thing'. That is the best way to put it. The movie is an anomaly. In a time devoid of epic tales of heroism, true bravery and courage, the film is a work of art that truly encapsulates the spirit of adventure. 

  One theme that is perfectly displayed by the film is sacrifice. Not glorious sacrifice, but the depiction of the rewards and consequences of mans commitment to his duty.

The film has an organic and authentic sense of scale. From massive and seemingly endless green fields to lines of chain link fence that continue to the horizon or city scapes that even in their limitation have a sense of being only parts of a whole. 

Perhaps it's best quality is it's artistic flourishing. SPOILER ALERT FOLLOWING: Right before one of the duo sent on the mission is killed, he reminisces about life back home. He tells his friend and partner in their mission about the different sorts of cherry trees and that his mother has an orchid back home. Further on in his journey, the surviving partner floats through a stream after the roughest part of the journey excluding the final push. A cherry tree blossoms as he is floating peacefully, creating a breathtaking display. 

Although it has been criticized as nationalist, it is almost the opposite, a depiction that portrays the Germans and Britains as not uniquely cruel or noble, but both as almost equal players in a tragic game. There is no enemy bashing, no assailing of the Germans as a unique enemy except for in maybe one scene where animals had been slaughtered to prevent the British army from utilizing them for food. Other than that, the film humanizes the German opponents. Showing pictures at the cots or abandoned German trenches. The British army is so devoid of British insignia and references that one could almost see it as any army, be it American or any other forces. The British army in the film features an Indian soldier and African-American soldiers and the Indian soldier is discriminated against in a bit of reflection of the actual historical climate and sentiments. It is sober in its treatment of history and does not seek to glorify war as many other films have done.
Absolutely riveting, not often do you see such a well put together depiction of The First World War.

While so many movies glorify war, turning their subjects into action heroes, this one deliberately does everything it can to remind us that they are vulnerable, mortal. The main characters are instantly likable, and the side characters have an astounding depth. I was expecting the colonial at the end to be a huge jerk, but with a few simple lines, he made it clear that he was defending a rational viewpoint, not just bloodthirsty. The pacing was excellent, the camera work was incredible, the special effects were subtle, and the score was on-point. All in all, it was a wonderful tribute to those who died over a hundred years ago

1917 is about two World War I soldiers (George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman) who are given a very important mission: travel across enemy territory and inform the leader of 1,600 of their brothers-in-arms that they're walking into a trap. This is an incredible piece of cinema!!!

This movie is really a ride with sort of a dreamlike feel to it as the characters are taken from one unpredictable situation to another unable to know if they'll encounter friend or foe.

Director Sam Mendes already showed in Skyfall that he commands an excellent visual style but this is a whole other level. The movie is filmed to give the illusion of one full tracking shot. Every moment the camera looks like it's following the characters. It is quite an achievement. Besides the tracking, the film also does a great job of deciding what elements of the scene to focus on.

The scenery in this is a thing of ethereal beauty. The characters travel through a constantly shifting landscape, from trenches to abandoned farms and so forth. Even the worse of environments look good. In my opinion, the war torn town at night scene is one of the best images in film history.

The one aspect that didn't always quite work for me was the music. Don't get me wrong. it's not bad. The issue is that the tracking shot gives a very natural, engrossing feel to what's going on. Suddenly, the music will boom loudly and take you out it.

Overall, I highly recommend this. This is a truly stunning flick.

This movie certainly deserved its Golden Globe win. The use of long takes, in order to make this film seem as if it was done on just one continuous shot, was a brilliant choice for shooting because it helps illustrate the tension and urgency brought upon by the mission that our two characters must succeed in. Cinematographer Roger Deakins has outdone himself once again, not only with this technique, but just with how he makes the film look gorgeous; it brought me memories of the same aesthetic look that he worked on for Blade Runner 2049. The script itself achieves a fine balance between the dialogue and emotions experienced by our two leads, and it helps to offer a pause between the dramatic, unbroken action sequences of these continuous shots. I've heard critics say that this film lacks character development, outside of the fact that one of them has to save his older brother, but I'd like to argue the film was nuanced and to the point. You don't really need Blake and Schofield to have their own story arcs; the war that they are immersed in is its own story arc. Plus, their actors, Dean - Charles Chapman and George MacKay, were brilliant through their use of subtle body language and their facial expressions were enough for me to gravitate towards them and understand what they are going through. Whether this film wins the big one remains to be seen, but there's not doubt that this film will take you on an incredible journey filled with a lot of tension and emotion.

1917 REVIEW

I haven't seen a war movie this phenomenal since Steven Spielberg's SAVING PRIVATE RYAN ! From the first scene to the last the film grabs you in. The gorgeous cinematography draws you in to feel like your right there in the suspense and horror brutalities of World War 1. Director Sam Mendes does a incredible job showing the nightmare side of war being very disturbing but also not going off the rails into a complete unnecessary gore fest. The action scenes are so intense it's teeth shattering. Some scenes were so intense I caught myself sinking in my chair. The film is made to feel like one consistent shot and Sam Mendes pulls it off remarkably. So well that some shots I couldn't believe were possible had me repeatedly saying to myself "How the hell did they shoot that !" The set pieces are absolutely gorgeous and are done so dam well in making them feel absolutely massive in size. The two lead actors do a dam good job and are met with a great supporting cast appearances by some juggernaut actors. Just when I thought I had a firm grip on the Oscar picture of 2020 Sam Mendes comes in like a force and makes his voice heard with a purpose. I thought Irishman had it locked but I have to admit after seeing this film your probably looking at the Best Picture Winner for 2020. The Directing, cinematography, acting, set pieces, score, costume design, realism, photography, special effects and so much more beauty spills from this incredible film. Overall, 1917 is a rare remarkable achievement of a film with master class level of Directing by Sam Mendes making it the must-see movie of the year !

This movie is a masterpiece. 

Sam Mendes with his cast and crew come through in every way. For fan a fan of war movies and a student of WWI in particular, I was looking forward to this movie with high hopes and expectations- I was snot disappointed in the least.

You experience what the Lance Corporal experiences in real time and it is harrowing event- reflecting the true reality of a never ending nightmare that was the Great War.

Yet, we are never far from the brief moment of shared humanity that made it livable- the reasons they were able to go on fighting. For each other.

Only really disappointed due to the hype surrounding this film. Strange that it’s cinematography is both it’s biggest strength and it’s fundamental weakness. I can’t recall a more harrowing and accurate depiction of trench warfare and the hell of no mans land ever being committed to film, the first 45 minutes are very strong indeed. The style of following the two protagonists continually on their mission is brave but ultimately flawed as it’s becomes impossible to condense a 12 hour mission into a 2 hours film when the camera doesn’t leave their side, the result is scenery changes that are unrealistically rapid and make the film feel more like you are are moving thought the levels of a computer game. That and some unbelievably inept soldiering by every German they encounter.

This film has restored my faith in the cinema to provide what writer/director Samuel Fuller noted about what film is all about: "Film is like a battleground....Love, hate, action, violence, death.  In a word: emotion." 1917 has an abundance of all of these emotions and more, including those rarely achieved in any film: wonder, astonishment, beauty, and the ability to stun with an immersive experience that ultimately results in a sense of empathy, compassion, and plight for those suffering from the madness that humanity obsessively indulges in from time to time: annihilation of itself by engaging in world war.  In other words, this is one of the best films I have ever seen.

1917 proves that great film's can be made. It shows that putting a little more time and effort can turn something that good into something that great. This film is by far my favorite film of 2019. This film is shot to appear as one long take. This approach is not only fascinating but adds so much to the story. You immediately feel the tension due to a strict time restraint due to the plot. As these characters get further to their goal, you can't help but realize the time is ticking. Following their ENTIRE journey because of the one shot makes this film feel like it's you going on this mission with these other soldiers. 1917 is a true masterpiece and should be looked upon as inspiration for those who make film.

1917 pulls the audience into the story through its raw imagery and technical prowess. The ambitious dedication Sam Mendes has to create this film is made very clear within the first minutes of the picture. With Roger Deakins, Mendes brings the audience into the film as participants, rather than observers. Deakins also captures the scale of the film with what may very well be his best camera work to date. For two hours, you are in World War 1; the tension and anxiety that the characters of Blake and Schofield experience is reflected well onto the audience. The moment when Schofield steps out of the trench on his own and begins to run felt like I was on a rollercoaster that's about to take the first plunge. A brilliant scene that was breathtaking to experience. See you at the movies.

The movie starts without much of a lead-in for the two main characters sitting near the trenches. The brother is asked to come to the commander's hole and they get orders to give orders to a commander who's about to get wiped out across the enemy lines.
The camera follows these two main characters through the trench and eventually to the barn where the "brother" dies and you're left with a protagonist you know next to nothing about. Is he married? Does he have children at home? Girlfriend? Career? Family? Siblings? Who knows?
You follow the character all the way to where he gives the orders from the general to call off the attack. That's the story. You learn nothing about the main characters, no secondary character development is present. Everyone he meets is gone in less than five minutes of screen time.
Think Death Race without a plot or character development. For the life of me, I can't understand why the audience is giving this movie a 92% (at the time of my writing) when you leave without learning one significant fact about any of the characters. I learn more in a single audition about the performers for Americas Got Talent than you do in 120 minutes of this movie.

A "worth a watch"  WW1 movie which tries (fairly successfully) to give the impression of being shot in a single take... something I found a little tedious to start with (but soon settled into) and felt was stuck to, somewhat unnecessarily (or maybe otherwise, should an Oscar go that way). The "trench eye view" scenes are original and add an interesting and impressive perspective (I felt these were the best part of the movie), and there is much spectacular cinematography as well as some originality in the scenes. Overall, I felt the film was let down by a mainly predictable plot, and the obligatory, but unnecessary appearance of St Benedict of Cumberbatch, ahead of the "pass me the bucket", overly slushy, final scenes (did we really need these Sam?). SPOILER ALERT...I also felt the move drew on too many scenes from other successful war movies, particularly those of the "Nam" genre (the sniper scene from Full Metal Jacket is almost a direct transplant). Overall, a WW1 impression of Apocalypse Now, but without any of Coppola's edginess...if only Cumberbatch had turned out to be a British version of Col Kurtz, shot the messenger, and sent them all over the top to face oblivion...now there's an ending.

If you're ever in the mood to watch a war film, there's an over-abundance of them throughout history. You can almost always find one that you haven't seen before. For this reason alone, I find myself being very cautious when one is about to get a wide release. With recent releases like Hacksaw Ridge or Dunkirk, my faith in the genre is always rejuvenated. Well, 1917 is yet another war film to come along and surprise me. For all the technical reasons to love this film on top of the powerful story itself, here's why I believe 1917 is one of 2019s very best films. 

The premise is nice and simple. Two young soldiers are given the task of sneaking through enemy lines in order to deliver a message to their commander, which will, in turn, save thousands of lives if received in time. This premise makes for a very tense ride. On top of being an engaging story, this movie is filmed in such a way that it makes it feel like one continuous take, for the most part, which ultimately begs the core actors to deliver the performances of their career.

Although I've seen him in great films like Captain Fantastic and Pride, George MacKay never really stood out to me as award-worthy, but I stand corrected. This may very well be the best performance he ever gives, but that's not a negative, because I'll always remember him for this role. Alongside him is Dean-Charles Chapman, who I've also liked in Game of Thrones and Blinded by the Light, so I knew to expect a solid performance from him. With that said, he also delivers one of the better performances I've seen in 2019, simply due to the devotion he has to his character. 

Now, this would absolutely be an incomplete review if I forgot to bring up how incredible the technical aspects of this film are. Roger Deakins is basically a god in the cinematography world, so his work astounds me every single time he brings his vision to a project, and 1917 is no exception to that. The way this camera seamlessly follows these actors in and out of small or big sequences was simply astonishing. Layered on top of this jaw-dropping cinematography is the superb score by Thomas Newman. The combination of being swept up in these performances, caring about the story, being impressed by the camerawork, and then finally being moved by how well the music was composed for each scene, I found it very difficult to criticize anything here. 

Overall, 1917 deserves a standing ovation for the technical aspects, but I would be remiss if I didn't mention the fact that this movie also wouldn't have been as good as it is without the careful direction by Sam Mendes. Between his work on American Beauty or Skyfall, it should come as no surprise that he would make a great film, but the crew around him took it to another level in my opinion. I was sucked in from start to finish and the two-hour run time flew by. I can't recommend this film enough. Easily one of my favourite films of 2019.

1917 is a World War I epic, directed and written by Sam Mendes, with cinematography by Roger Deakins. This film honestly may have been my most anticipated film of 2019, and the wait to finally have checked it out was vicious. Because this is truly one of the most breathtaking war epics, Ive ever laid eyes on beautifully and skillfully shot by Roger Deakins using long takes, so this 2-hour film appears to be one continuous shot with no cuts whatsoever. With Mendes and Deakins leading the charge here, these are masters at work. I cannot stress enough how stunning this film looks, how it feels so authentic and true to the time period. The costume design, hair and makeup, set production, the perfect score by Thomas Newman, everything blew me away.

George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman are absolutely fantastic as the films leads. They give such excellent performances making the audience feel uneasy as we are along with them on their journey. One of my favorite aspects of this amazing project is just how genuine and raw this story is, really getting across the point of what these British soldiers experienced in the middle of trench warfare. There is almost always something happening on screen, rarely giving you a chance to breathe. You are right there with these two soldiers, always on the move and in the thick of it. This is a gorgeous, excellent film, a technical achievement, and a nerve-racking experience that needs to be seen on the big screen. PLEASE check it out ASAP.

This movie held my attention from beginning to end. They take no time to dive right into the plot and there wasn't one dull moment that ruined the pace of the film. Can we talk about how they shot this movie?! I applaud whoever was the cameraman because having to do a one-take isn't an easy task. Here's all you need to know: Lance is asked to grab a comrade, they are given orders to deliver a message to Colonel MacKenzie to stop an attack against the Germans...and that's it. Once you are given that information just sit back and enjoy the one-shot experience. From the get-go, you feel immersed in the story and you feel as though you are right there with the characters. Even though you aren't given much detail and back story about the two soldiers, you still feel connected to them through their journey. I'm going to be thinking and talking about this movie for a while. I know it's only the beginning of 2020, but I'm already putting this as a top favorite for the year!

It’s on January 11th and I already have a contender for film of the year. Sam Mendes’ 1917 is stunning from start to finish. A visual tour de force is storytelling brought to life by one continuous tracking shot with a little digital stitching here and there. The camera basically follows two soldiers as they embark on a mission to deliver orders across No Mans Land. It’s a simple story brilliantly told. The cinematography by Roger Deakins is nothing short of extraordinary as the camera glides above and below our protagonists and sometimes even goes off in a different direction, then circles back to them. It’s unlike any war film I have seen in quite a while. Some are hailing this as the best since Spielberg’s masterpiece “Saving Private Ryan”, I’m not sure about that, I’d have to have a think, but it’s certainly a tremendous piece of filmmaking brought to live by a wonderful director who’s worked I have admired for years. Thomas Newman’s music is also profoundly moving and the ending is exhilarating and heartbreaking at the same time. “1917” manage to impress myself and my two mates and that’s a rarity these days. It’s a wonderful piece of cinema and I urge you all to experience it.

This is not a movie that glorifies war. It does not make its characters heroes. It does not demonize the enemy. It does however portray the hideous conditions of war, the waste of human life, and frankly the senselessness of it. I recommend this movie because today we need more than ever to understand that war isn't heroes and villains, not a storybook where the good guy always wins. And while the World Wars were terrible they would be insignificant compared to the horrors that could be unleashed by modern weapons.
The entire run time was naked realism. Too real. No CGI was evident, or at least I never thought to myself 'this is CGI'. The characters are not Rambo, mowing down the enemy, rather they are all too human, which is the point.
I'm obviously not going to include spoilers, I'm only going to recommend you experience it yourself, and think not only about the past and those who have died in senseless war, but consider the dangers we now face. Reflect on what movies like this tell us now.

This Is and may continue to be the greatest film I have ever seen. Never have I seen anything that has even come close to the detail shown in this movie. Not only did they do there homework, but they sculpted the movie perfectly, Literally and figuratively. The story was amazing, its authenticity is at question in the back of my mind, put is pushed further into the shadows because of the experience this movie gave me. I didn't just watch this film in a very crowded theater. I experienced it with people that were transformed into fellow humans whose hearts throbbed in sync with my own. By the end of the film no eyes were dry. many sat there as the credits rolled trying to process what they had seen. After my own deep contemplation I realized I had both seen and experienced history. History both being told and made. I have no doubt that this movie has raised the bar for anyone who dares to recreate again those dank, mud addled trenches again. To ever experience more closely any other story about World War One would mean we would go home with our own feet muddied from the tears shed on no mans land. Im writing this review at 1:09am and will soon go to bed knowing that I invested $11.67 into a memory I will cherish and look upon with fondness as long as I live.

This movie is impeccably acted, with a compelling story and empathetic characters, but the main draw comes from the fact that the entire thing is a oner. Of course there are several cleverly hidden cuts and one plot-based one, but the effect is more than just window dressing; it brings the audience with the characters on their urgent journey. The main characters have a few lucky escapes from bad marksmen, but that's a minor quibble at best in a film like this. The period costuming and set design is jaw-dropping, and everything comes together in an impressive and epic package.

Content warning: war violence

Closest comparison: Where Dunkirk (2017) shuffled its timeline, 1917's is seamless.

I went to see 1917 last night and was enthralled by the amazing art department work on sets, dead bodies and the CG of the airplane crashing near our two protagonists.  I know the cost, time and difficulty of creating war sets and effects.  

The long tracking shots of 1917 following the men through the trenches was mesmerizing but ultimately repetitive and tedious. I felt nothing for the story or the characters involved; the young actors felt generic, like human set pieces in a video game running through a lovely scenario.  I ended up only appreciating what the movie making crafts have produced and wishing Sam Mendes had cared more for acting and story.  Its an example of where you let one genius (the DP) dominate while neglecting what we are in moviemaking for:  to tell compelling stories.

This film already won a number of prestigious rewards, and they are well deserved. Its unique approach to storytelling shows in the fact that the whole 2-hour movie was shot so as to appear as one continuous take. The camera is always with the protagonists: sometimes in front of them pointing backwards, at other time behind them looking over their shoulders etc. without ANY obvious cuts. This changing perspective in one veeeeery long take required some well thought-out scene design and incredible acting. The actors deal beautifully with these enhanced requirements, the not so famous leads as well as the famous supporting cast, including Benedict Cumberbatch, Colin Firth, and Mark Strong. Recommended, although it is a bit gruesome at times, which should be expected of a war movie.

Marching Through a Labyrinth of Death
Two young British soldiers during the First World War are given an impossible mission: deliver a message deep in enemy territory that will stop 1,600 men, and one of the soldiers' brothers, from walking straight into a deadly trap.

There is a lot of beauty in 1917. The war is catastrophic and the casualties are sickening, but it's all presented in this gorgeous light through the intricate eyes of Roger Deakins (cinematography).Bravo Roger Deakins! Thomas Newman's score is gorgeously depressing with this layer of victory sprinkled in for good measure. This is quite possibly the most technically sound film of 2019.

1917 is a visual spectacle that is sure to be brought up again and again in the years to come. 9/10

In short:  Two guys have a walk and every 100 meters something ridiculous happens.

I am sorry but it felt like "1917 times I couldn't suspend my disbelief".
The camerawork is impressive but it gets so claustrophobic (and abused many times to leave out important information to later 'surprise' us).  Then the 24fps that close to the main actors, makes that with any little pan there's a huge motion blur smudge in the centre making my eyes burn halfway through the movie.  I watched the IMAX version and that was definitely a waste as it's 2 hours of watching one guy's derriere on screen with very thematic dust and dirt.

1917 is a World War I epic, directed and written by Sam Mendes, with cinematography by Roger Deakins. This film honestly may have been my most anticipated film of 2019, and the wait to finally have checked it out was vicious. Because this is truly one of the most breathtaking war epics, I've ever laid eyes on; beautifully and skillfully shot by Roger Deakins using long takes, so this 2-hour film appears to be one continuous shot with no cuts whatsoever. With Mendes and Deakins leading the charge here, these are masters at work. I cannot stress enough how stunning this film looks, how it feels so authentic and true to the time period. The costume design, hair and makeup, set production, the perfect score by Thomas Newman, everything blew me away.

George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman are absolutely fantastic as the film's leads. They give such excellent performances making the audience feel uneasy as we are along with them on their journey. One of my favorite aspects of this amazing project is just how genuine and raw this story is, really getting across the point of what these British soldiers experienced in the middle of trench warfare. There is almost always something happening on screen, rarely giving you a chance to breathe. You are right there with these two soldiers, always on the move and in the thick of it. This is a gorgeous, excellent film, a technical achievement, and a nerve-racking experience that needs to be seen on the big screen. PLEASE check it out ASAP

Right now "1917" having already winning the Best Picture Golden Globe is the front runner for Best Picture Oscar. After seeing the picture it is obvious that the visual technique of director's Sam Mendes's collaboration with cinematographer Roger Deakins is what makes this movie rate so high.  It looks like the picture has been made in one continuous take with 2-3 exceptions which are carefully explained in the script by Sam Mendes, with the help of Krysty-Wilson Cairns and based on stories told by his uncle Alfred Mendes.

The story is a basic one of two young British soldiers who have to deliver a message to stop a raid which would be a deathtrap for 1600 men, one being a brother of one of the soldiers. One of the illogical parts of the script is that the two men are are too inexperienced to take on a task but 1) going to the movies in most cases you have to park your logic out in the lobby and 2) this takes place at the beginning of the movie when you are caught up in the film's technique so by the time you get involved with the story itself they have picked up much needed experience along with many coincidences that might not ring true.

The two leads, Dean-Charles Chapman and George MacKay, are more than adequate, with one carrying a heavier load than the other, while there are many cameos from such actors as Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Richard Madden, Daniel Mays and Claire Duburcq.

"1917" is interesting for the way it appears to have been filmed but there have been much better war movies in the past and certainly better movies in 2019.
